PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 9 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's `White Paper' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains Tax
Hidden Death Tax described as `Capital Gains Tax after death'
Gift Tax
Increased Company Tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject these tax proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that the proposed Fringe Benefits Tax recently introduced into the House of Representatives by the Labor Government will increase the costs and inhibit future growth of small business in this great Nation.
Your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject this regressive Legislation as a matter of utmost urgency in the interests of the well being of all Australians.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas

We do not believe there are any legitimate grounds for Telecom to increase its charges to the public, most especially in view of its own demonstrated inefficiencies in being unable to provide the basic services to the public for which the existing charges are already excessive.
Members of the Australian Small Business Community express concern at the effect the inefficiency of Telecom has on the day to day operation of business in Australia.

Any business enterprise in order to justify an increase in charges for its services would need to demonstrate an ability to improve such services. Telecom would need to provide such proof in order to justify its present level of charges.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable Senate will: reject the principle of increased Telecom charges and inefficiency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisement Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of wide-spread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 32 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose utterly the proposed Bill of Rights because this Bill will
Transfer to government powers not given nor intended to be given by the Constitution
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this and any future Government
Turn the Human Rights Commission into a political Star Chamber with unjustifiable power
Abrogate Common Law and common liberty
Set the State above the individual
Restrict Rights to those specified by the Bill
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject a Bill of Rights in this or any other form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the proposed Bill of Rights because it adversely affects areas of the liberty and freedom of Australians. It will operate against:
The States and our Federal system of Government
Criminal Justice
The Police
Education
Families
Employer/Employee relations

It will remove the power of the people through Parliament, by giving power to a new more powerful Human Rights Commission which is not elected, but can act as a Star Chamber. We do most earnestly wish to keep our system of Common Law.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned members of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees' Association and Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. The Sex Discrimination Act., passed by Parliament in 1984, will automatically make unenforceable from 1st August, 1986 the weight lifting limits applicable to women employees and contained in State laws, regulations and awards.
2. These weight lifting limits have applied throughout Australia for many years and have acted to prevent many injuries at the workplace, thereby avoiding much suffering and loss of working time.
3. The removal of this protective legislation will increase the rate of injury among women employees and lead to greater Workers' Compensation costs for employers.
4. The weight lifting limits do not in any way hamper the achievement of equality and equal opportunity in employment for women employees in the workforce.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament will amend the Sex Discrimination Act to enable the weight lifting limits for women employees to continue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under Common Law,
2. Deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. Give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. Could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should:
Completely reject both the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chirita Family
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

Your petitioners, as in duty bound will humbly pray. That a public inquiry be conducted for the migration of the Chirita family (father) Marin Chirita and (fiancee) Marc Codruta to be allowed into Australia and that the rights of Ion Chirita be recognised in Queensland.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilization.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 337 citizens), Hamer (from 108 citizens) and Macklin (from 245 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Reid (from 63 citizens) and Ryan (from 55 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Hail Mary
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembly in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned in the State of Queensland respectfully showeth . . .
That the film ``Hail Mary'' is pornographic and blasphemous and gravely offends our religious beliefs and those of the vast majority of Australian Christians.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament will . . .
Respect the will of the undersigned and have the pornographic and blasphemous film ``Hail Mary'' banned in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hail Mary
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned in the State of Queensland respectfully showeth the film ``Hail Mary'' is blasphemous and gravely offends the religious beliefs of the majority of Australian Christians.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray the Federal Parliament will respect the will of the undersigned and have the blasphemous film ``Hail Mary'' banned in Australia,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and the Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from 21 citizens) and Harradine (from 43 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board: Appointment
PETITION.PARA: To: The honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia assembled

We the undersigned, plead that Parliament will revoke and replace with family-oriented persons, all appointments to the Film Censorship Board prior to 1985, and thus improve the nurturing home environment of Australia's children, because we have read pages 149 to 152 of the Official Hansard Transcript of Evidence to the Select Committee on Video Material, and we ask you to read it.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, a petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That the present practice of embryo experimentation as a byproduct of in vitro fertilisation programmes throughout Australia, defies the obligation of our community to protect human beings from the first moment of their existence as specified in the principles of the Human Rights Commission of Australia and the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will legislate to outlaw embryo experimentation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE DETERMINATION No. 14 OF 1986SOUTHERN BLUEFIN FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLAN (AMENDMENT)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my notices of intention given yesterday, I now withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for this day of sitting for disallowance of Defence Determination No. 14, Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 2 standing in my name for this day and Notice of Motion No. 3 standing in my name for 22 August 1986 for disallowance of Plan of Management No. 5 Southern Bluefin Fishery Management Plan (Amendment).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, reaffirming that-
(a) the ANZUS Treaty is of great importance to the security of Australia; and
(b) the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty is vital to the control of the movement of fissile material for peacetime purposes and for the prevention of the spread of nuclear weapons,
rejects the outright opposition by the Australian Democrats Party to these two treaties, an opposition the effect of which would be to weaken the peace and security of Australia and the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to make proper provision for the self-government of the Australian Capital Territory by the establishment of a freely and democratically elected assembly with legislative powers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, noting that in view of the many anomalies, inconsistencies and mistakes in drafting of the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Act and the Fringe Benefits Assessment Act, which were evident during the debate in the Senate and which are becoming increasingly evident to practitioners, taxpayers and their representatives, calls upon the Federal Government to make plain its intention to deal with these problems and, in particular, make clear its intention with regard to the apparently unintended effect of S160zm of the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Act which prevents unit trusts passing on to unit holders the benefit of a taxation deduction for depreciation and building allowance deductions which are available to other entities holding real property in similar situations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, noting the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-
(a) that the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service (QNPWS) had issued several hundred thousand killing tags in excess of its 1985 quota;
(b) that no attempt was made to monitor the kill;

(c) that the QNPWS had failed to distinguish between the various species of kangaroo when it approved the 1985 and previous quotas-and there was a `real possibility' that at least one species might now be in danger of becoming extinct;
(d) that the administrators of wildlife protection legislation of the Federal Parliament had totally misunderstood the effect of that legislation; and

(e) that the Australian and the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Services seem to be only concerned with getting formal approval for a plan to enable culling of kangaroos and export of kangaroo products to continue,

urges the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) to enforce the laws passed by this Parliament to ensure the protection measures for Australian wildlife imposed by legislation are implemented in accordance with its provisions and in a manner likely to achieve its objectives.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SOCIAL WELFARE: REPORT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare report `Children in Institutional and Other Forms of Care-a National Perspective'. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Statement on the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare on ``Children in Institutional and Other Forms of Care-A National Perspective''.

For the information of Honourable Senators, I present the Government's response to the Report of the Senate Select Committee on ``Children in Institutional and Other Forms of Care-A National Perspective'' of June 1985.

The Report examines in a sensitive and thoughtful manner the provision of institutional and other forms of substitute care for children. There can be no doubt about the importance of the quality of planning, provision, monitoring and evaluation of this type of care. However, the Government considers this care the responsibility of State Governments. Further it believes State governments and the community organisations involved take this responsibility very seriously and devote considerable attention and resources to the provision of institutional care where this is necessary, to foster care programs and to the supports needed by families and children prior to, during and after substitute care has been provided. All have the aim of providing care and development opportunities which will fit the children to grow into well integrated adults who can play a useful role in the community.

Despite the sincere intentions of State governments and community organisations working in this field new needs are identified and new approaches to meeting needs emerge. This Report highlights the requirement for careful planning, constant monitoring and evaluation, and high quality training for those working in the field. It also stresses the need for greater sharing of knowledge and experience and co-ordination of effort.

The Government believes the Report is worthy of close consideration by Commonwealth and State Ministers and arrangements will be made for it to be drawn to the particular attention of all Commonwealth Ministers. Additionally, I will seek to have it placed as an Agenda Item on the next Meeting of the Council of Social Welfare Ministers; a body comprising Commonwealth and State Ministers with responsibility in the social welfare field. By these means the Government believes action which takes account of the good work being done will be able to be carefully considered and any co-ordinated action required at the Commonwealth and State levels identified.
The Committee identified 10 major areas and developed recommendations within each of these areas.
This response identifies each area together with recommendations and provides an outline of the Government response to each recommendation.
Foster Parents' Allowance
Recommendations 1, 2 and 3
1. The Commonwealth Government introduce a national foster parents' allowance to replace existing allowances for foster parents
2. The national foster parents' allowance-
(a) fully compensate foster parents for the cost of maintaining children placed in their care;
(b) be automatically indexed on a regular basis in line with variations in the cost of living; and
(c) include a separate component representing the Family Allowance that would otherwise be payable to the foster child's natural mother or father.

3. The Minister for Social Security in consultation with State and Territory Ministers responsible for child welfare matters determine appropriate administrative arrangements for the payment of the national foster parents' allowance.
Government Response

The Government does not support the introduction of a national foster parents' allowance. The introduction of such an allowance would mean the Commonwealth entering a well defined and accepted area of State Government responsibility.

Foster care is viewed as a key service within the State's child protection and child welfare systems and it would seem quite inappropriate to remove one facet-the payment of the foster parents' allowance-from those systems.
The Committee recommendation was based on two arguments:
that introduction of a Commonwealth allowance would ``avoid the variations in value of the allowances paid by the various States and Territory Governments'' and
``ensure uniformity of practice in the payment of Commonwealth Family Allowances''.

In response to these arguments the Government is of the view that the variations of allowances between States is not sufficient justification to enter an area of child welfare so critical to State and Territory Government responsibility. It considers current family allowance arrangements pay due regard to the rights of both natural and foster parents and are sufficiently flexible to adequately cater for the range of situations that can arise in fostering cases.

The Government has noted the Committee's recommendation in respect of the level of foster parents allowances and the need for indexation of the allowance in line with variations in the cost of living. It believes these matters are the responsibility of State and Territory Governments.
Recommendation 4
Children in Residential
Institutions Program

4. In determining an organisation's eligibility for funding under the Children in Residential Institutions Program, the Commonwealth Government requires State and Northern Territory education departments to place greater emphasis on (a) projects that encourage and assist children in institutional care to participate in education or training at least until they have completed a full secondary education or its equivalent; and (b) projects that prepare and equip those leaving residential institutions with independent living skills.
Government Response

The Minister for Education is presently considering the Schools Commission's report `Quality and Equality: Commonwealth Specific Purpose Programs for Australian Schools' which reports on its review of specific purpose programs. This review was sought by the Government in its 1983 guidelines to the Schools Commission.

The Report takes into account the Review of the Children in Residential Institutions (CIRI) Program undertaken at the request of the Schools Commission by Professor Ward and others and the views put forward during consultation with interest groups (government and non-government) and State Committees responsible for administering the CIRI Programs.

The recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare is consistent with the recommendations of the Schools Commission and the Senate Committee's proposals will be considered by the Government when it gives consideration to the Schools Commission's Report `Quality and Equality: Commonwealth Specific Purpose Program for Australian Schools'.
Recommendation 7
Training programs for
substitute care personnel
7. The Commonwealth Ministers for Community Services and Education, in consultation with State and Territory Ministers responsible for child welfare matters and non-government welfare organisations-
(a) investigate the needs of government and non-government substitute care agencies for both pre-service and in-service training for personnel;

(b) review existing pre-service substitute care training courses and programs in technical and further education institutions and other tertiary institutions and, where necessary, support the development and implementation of suitable diploma and certificate courses; and

(c) examine the need for government financial assistance to meet the cost of replacing substitute care personnel participating in in-service activities and determine the most appropriate means of providing support for staff release and the replacement of staff attending in-service training programs.
Government Response

The Government considers the investigation of the training needs of staff of government and non-government agencies concerned with substitute care are primarily matters for State governments in co-operation with the non-government agencies.

It believes any reviews of existing pre-service training courses (where these are appropriate) should be conducted in the State concerned under the aegis of the course advisory committee attached to higher education institutions and TAFE authorities and colleges.

It is noted, however, that if further higher education places are needed for the training of staff working with children who are in substitute care, State and Territory Governments should submit proposals for the triennium 1988-1990. Data on such needs is collected over the 12 month period ending March 1987 when the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's advice to the Government is due to be provided.
Recommendation 5, 6, 8 and 9
Evaluation of substitute care services-

5. The Commonwealth Government promote the evaluation of substitute care services by assisting State and Territory government and non-government welfare departments and agencies to determine appropriate evaluation criteria and develop procedures for the establishment and maintenance of on-going evaluation programs.
National statistics of children
in substitute care-

6. The Minister for Community Services, through WELSTAT, give priority to the expansion of the present range of statistics on the characteristics of children in substitute care to include data on such matters as the reasons for children being placed in care (ie apart from whether they are placed in care because their welfare is at risk or because they have committed an offence), the duration of care arrangements, the number and nature of successive admissions, and the outcome of substitute care placements.
Assessment and planning of substitute
care placements

8. The Commonwealth Minister for Community Services seek the co-operation of State and Territory Ministers responsible for child welfare matters and non-government welfare agencies to establish a set of universally acceptable guiding principles for (a) the initial and continuing assessment of children requiring substitute care and (b) the development of a planned approach towards the placement of children in care.

9. the Commonwealth Government introduce a special substitute care grants program to assist government and non-government welfare agencies in the implementation of proper assessment and planning procedures for the placement of children in substitute care, including the design and maintenance of appropriate client data collection, storage and retrieval systems.
Government Response

State and Territory governments have primary responsibility for welfare programs concerning children and so also retain primary responsibility for monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness of these programs. As such, it is a function of State and Territory governments to develop appropriate planning and assessment procedures (Recommendation 8) and evaluation criteria, and to develop procedures for the establishment and maintenance of ongoing evaluation programs (Recommendation 5).

Nonetheless, the Government is making considerable efforts to improve the monitoring and evaluation of welfare programs by providing assistance at the national level in establishing sound and useful data bases.
The Government considers the collection of reliable and nationally consistent welfare statistics to be essential for the effective monitoring and evaluation of welfare services across Australia.

The Government assists in establishing data collections in this area through its membership and financial support of the WELSTAT Project. The primary aim of WELSTAT is to develop standardised definitions and classifications for the collection of national welfare statistics.

The Government supports the role played by WELSTAT in the collection of welfare statistics. The Commonwealth Department of Community Services provides a full-time officer to the WELSTAT Secretariat; contributes to the funding of another member of the Secretariat jointly with the States and Territories; and provides considerable administrative support to the Secretariat. (The WELSTAT Secretariat is located in the Department of Community Services in Canberra.) The Australian Bureau of Statistics also provides an outposted officer to the Secretariat.

The Government sees its considerable financial and administrative support to the WELSTAT Secretariat as the most appropriate form of assistance it can provide to State and Territory governments and non-government organisations to assist in establishing common standards and statistics for the use in assessing and planning the placement of children in care (Recommendations 8 and 9).

Since its inception in 1976 WELSTAT has achieved a great deal. In particular, WELSTAT has developed statistical standards on a range of welfare matters which directly impact upon children viz; Children in Care, Adoptions, Children under Detention, Child Maltreatment and Emergency (financial) Assistance.
Data on Children in Care, Adoptions and Children under Detention has proved particularly valuable to State and Territory governments.

WELSTAT National Working Party meetings are held regularly to review progress in all WELSTAT standards and statistical collections. The most recent meeting was held in Adelaide on 1-2 May 1986 for representatives of the Commonwealth and all States and Territories to discuss progress on the above standards and statistical collections relating to children.

In particular, WELSTAT has been examining the range of data which is included in its Children in Care collection. The current Child in Care standards include statistics on, among other things, characteristics of children in institute care, and the reasons are placed in care, whether for offence or for care and protected reasons. WELSTAT is considering the feasibility of collecting data on the duration and type of care arrangements, and the number and type of successive admissions (Recommendation 6).
Recommendation 10
Dissemination and exchange of information-

10. The Minister for Community Services seek the co-operation and assistance of State and Territory Ministers responsible for child welfare matters and non-government welfare agencies in devising appropriate mechanisms for promoting the dissemination and exchange of information concerning new developments and exemplary practices in the provision of institutional and other forms of substitute care (eg through the establishment of a national clearinghouse for studies related to children in substitute care and the joint sponsorship of regular national seminars, workshops or conferences).
Government Response

It is considered that mechanisms for promoting the dissemination and exchange of information exist. Peak bodies such as the Australian Early Childhood Association, the Australian Council of Social Service (both of which receive assistance from the Government) contribute to the dissemination and exchange of information. Additionally, the Institute of Family Studies, the Australian Institute of Criminology and the Social Welfare Research Centre which are funded by the Commonwealth Government contribute to this distribution of research and other information.
Recommendation 11
Family Support Services Scheme
11. The Family Support Services Scheme be continued and expanded by the Commonwealth Government.
Government Response

The Government has decided to continue the Family Support Services Scheme and negotiate with State and Territory governments in respect of a new cost shared program. These negotiations are proceeding and it is hoped to announce details of a new program shortly. It should, however, be mentioned that any new cost shared program will not cut across the responsibilities of State and Territory governments for the provision of institutional and other forms of substitute care. It would be hoped, however, that the development of family support networks would lead to a strengthening of families' ability to cope with stress and a lessening of need for substitute care for children.
Recommendation 12
The Child Care Act 1972

The Government does not accept that the Child Care Act 1972 should be amended or replaced ``to reflect more accurately the Commonwealth's present and future role and policy direction'' related to child care and family support. It believes the present Act accurately reflects the Government's purpose in respect of the provision of centre based day care for children who are primarily of pre-school age. Other services e.g. family day care, outside school hours care and vacation care and services to children who have special needs are provided for under the general provisions of Children's Services Program (CSP) and family support services under a specific appropriation.

It should be noted that funds provided under the Child Care Act or the provisions of the CSP are not directed at services which provide substitute care - rather services which provide care (generally in working hours) which complement the care provided by parents.

Since the Senate Committee's Report was tabled, I have advised the Parliament that the primary objective of the Children's Services Program is to ensure that parents and children have access to quality children's services that are appropriate to their needs regardless of their income level, cultural background, disability or geographical location.
Within this broad objective the Government's priorities are towards providing non-profit services that:
promote the developmental, social, emotional and intellectual needs of children without substituting for the care they receive from their parents;

are consistent with the Government's policies of equal opportunity and affirmative action, and are predominantly directed towards meeting the needs of children of working parents or parents who are undertaking vocational training to enter the workforce;
encourage parent participation in management;
are accessible to low and moderate income earners;
focus on under school age children but also provide older children with care out of school hours and during school holidays;
assist those with special needs such as Aboriginal, migrant and disabled children and children in remote and isolated parts of Australia; and
are accessible to the general community.
Recommendations 13-18
Establishment of a national children and
families commission

13. The Commonwealth Government introduce legislation providing for the establishment of a national statutory authority to be known as the Australian Children and Families Commission to advise the Government on matters of policy concerning the development of welfare programs for children and families, and to develop strategies to improve the overall planning and co-ordination of such programs in co-operation with other Commonwealth departments, State and Territory governments, local government authorities and non-government agencies responsible for the provision of these programs.
14. The Australian Children and Families Commission be directly responsible to the Commonwealth Minister for Community Services.

15. The Commission comprise no more than nine members, including two representatives of State or Territory government welfare authorities, two representatives of the non-government sector, one Aboriginal representative, two representatives from other client groups, one representative with specialist qualifications, and a chairman appointed by the Minister for Community Services.
16. The Commission consult regularly with interested community groups and organisations, and establish an appropriate consultative mechanism for this purpose.

17. In addition to providing advice on child and family welfare policy matters and developing strategies to improve the planning and co-ordination of welfare programs, the Australian Children and Families Commission have the following functions:
(a) the development of a set of guiding principles and national goals for the promotion of the well-being of children and families;
(b) the on-going assessment of the effect on family functioning, including the economic status of families, of Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation and programs of family support;
(c) the provision of advice to the Minister for Community Services on the effectiveness of such legislation and programs, including the formulation of recommendations to-
(i) the development of improved methods of family support, including measures aimed at preventing family disruption, and

(ii) the allocation of financial assistance to government and non-government organisations for the development, establishment and maintenance of appropriate specific purpose programs for children with particular needs such as those in institutional and other forms of substitute care, children who have offended against the law, homeless children, children who are victims of abuse, and children disadvantaged through intellectual or physical disability, ethnic or cultural background, or geographical isolation;
(d) the provision of technical assistance and advice to the States and Territories for the evaluation of children's welfare programs and associated community services for families;

(e) the conduct, promotion and co-ordination of research, together with the exchange of ideas and the dissemination of information, in relation to developments occurring within the child and family welfare field both in Australia and overseas; and
(f) the continuing review of the education and training needs of persons involved in the delivery of child and family welfare programs.
18. The Institute of Family Studies be incorporated as the research arm of the Australian children and Families Commission.
Government Response

The Government quite clearly needs to monitor the effects of its existing welfare policies and practices on children and their families, review these policies and practices and, as appropriate make changes to them. However, it does not consider that the establishment of a National Children and Families Commission with the responsibility for advising the Minister on welfare programs and services relating to children and their families is an appropriate mechanism. Policies and practices which affect children and families are considered far wider than those which can be categorised as `welfare'-they include income security, taxation, and many (if not most) other areas of Commonwealth government responsibility. Reviews such as the present Social Security Review which is to give special attention to the needs of families with dependent children and the Schools Commission review of specific purpose programs (response to Recommendation 4 refers) are considered more effective means of focusing attention at present policies and practices and considering recommendations for change.

The Government also believes there are mechanisms in place which afford it advice both in the broad social welfare field and the more specific field discussed in this Report, the child and family welfare field. In this respect the National Advisory Council on Social Welfare was established to advise the Ministers for Social Security and Community Services on current issues in social welfare and provide assessment and reviews of social welfare priorities.

The Institute of Family Studies, fully funded by the Commonwealth with the object of promoting the protection of the family as the natural and fundamental group unit in society, undertakes research, promotes discussion of important areas and is another valuable source of advice. Amendments presently before the Parliament, implementing the recommendations of a review of the Institute in 1985, will enhance its ability to provide that advice in a way which will meet the needs of Government, by allowing the Attorney-General to refer specific issues for research. The Policy Co-ordination Unit which reports to the Minister for Community Services also provides advice on and promotes the co-ordinated development and review of, policies and programs in the broad field of health and welfare.

This recommendation viewed a National Children and Families Commission as not only providing advice but also developing strategies to improve the overall co-ordination in the provision of programs for families and children. The Government recognises the importance of greater co-ordination but considers existing mechanisms such as the Policy Co-ordination Unit, the Conference of Social Welfare Administrators and the Council of Social Welfare Ministers and the various committees which are established for specific tasks are providing a valuable service in this respect.

Finally, organisations such as the Australian Council of Social Service and the Australian Early Childhood Association, both of which receive financial assistance from the Government, work to assist co-ordination in the field and to give advice to all levels of Government.

The Government considers that a National Commission such as that recommended in this Report would have the potential to duplicate functions of existing bodies and conflict with other bodies which have responsibility for specific areas of child and family welfare and it is doubtful whether a Commission could be effective given the scope of its function and the need for it to be involved not only in Commonwealth but also State policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I have supplied a copy of my statement on the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities concerning the implications for Australia's defence to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp). The statement is available to other honourable senators. I regret that, along with a number of others, I was not here after the usual time of adjournment last night and, therefore, it is necessary for me to make this statement now. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The release of the Dibb Report on the future shape of Australia's defence forces marks a watershed in the development-or disintegration-of Australia's defence and foreign policies.

Combined with the economic crisis into which our country has been plunged, the essentially introspective view taken by the Dibb Report of our national security policies has brought us to a point in Australia's history which has profound implications for our national destiny.

At such a moment, it is important for us to concentrate on the central principles relating to the defence of Australia and not be diverted by subsidiary issues such as force structure and equipment needs.

I also regard questions about strategy as secondary. While strategy determines force structure and equipment requirements, strategy is itself determined by higher consideration. In other words, by how one resolves the question: what interests and positions should we defend in order to provide for Australia's security? We should focus on answering this.

This is a question not for defence bureaucrats and academics to decide. It is the business of the Federal Government and Parliament to determine this issue. To set Australia's national defence goals is our primary constitutional responsibility. No-one else is charged with the care of this grave matter.

Unfortunately, however, a succession of governments, both Labor and Liberal-National Party, have chosen, in effect, to abdicate responsibility for defence. For all intents and purposes, they have left defence to the Defence Department. The role of Government has been to set the defence budget and that of the Department to generate defence policies tailor-made to fit the budget.

Combined with an emerging isolationist instinct among defence bureaucrats, the vice of letting budget policy determine defence policy has been turned into a virtue. How this metamorphosis took place has been explained in the Strategic Basis papers. According to these, Australia is not directly threatened by any power and will not be for the foreseeable future. The upshot of this (though not clearly spelled out, and perhaps deliberately so) is that Australia does not need, for the time being, a defence force which could actually defend us. Such a force would only ever be developed and deployed to meet a direct threat to the continent.

To give the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, his due, he is attempting to put his own stamp on the Defence Department and to restore to Government its role in defence planning. But the effect of this has been to give (with the addition of a few personal touches) a more concrete realisation to the Defence Department's incipient policy of undefended neutrality.

This is not to say that the Dibb Report is without value. On the contrary, it has merit precisely because it is a systematic and coherent national defence policy, one which begins with a judgment about what we need to defend and ends with a conclusion about the forces needed to do the job.
Moreover, the Dibb Report recommends an important development of the Minister's existing policy of welding together the separate services into a more co-ordinated defence force.

Nevertheless, the Dibb Report is profoundly influenced by the Defence Department's indifference to Australia's real security problems. One of the grounds for this complacency lies in the conceptually inadequate way in which defence planners and academics have understood Australia's geographic position.

According to the alleged experts, Australia's greatest defence asset is its ``strategic isolation''. Because we are so isolated, they tell us, we are hard to attack. Only countries with superpower maritime resources could contemplate invading us. In any case, the argument goes, we could make the passage of invading forces to our shores so expensive that even superpowers would have to think twice about the attempt. So Australia is a pretty safe place to live.

It is true that our isolation is an advantage. However, our isolation is at least equally a disadvantage. Some may think that Australia is so geographically remote that the big military problem for an enemy would be getting his forces to us and supplying them. Far from it. Australia is so isolated that an enemy need not send any forces at all. Instead, he can bring military pressure to bear on us more effectively and more economically from afar.

The question Australia's geographical position poses for any common-sense enemy is this: why face the risks of invading this far-away country when I stand a good chance of achieving my objectives simply by isolating Australia further, by cutting off, or at least interrupting, the long, slender lines of communications which attach her precariously to the rest of the world?
The enemy who asks himself this question is the enemy Australia needs to fear, much more so than the one who would contemplate the costly, impractical plan of invading us.

Except as a strategy for the last-ditch defence of the mainland-a strategy which concedes, in advance, the failure of our defence and foreign policies to preserve Australia's security-the Dibb plan is virtually irrelevant to the defence of this country.

The reason is this: Australia is a nation whose economic life blood flows through its sea-lane communications with the outside world. Whoever controls those sea-lanes, controls Australia. Thus, any power which wants to subdue Australia would NOT plan to invade us. An enemy could achieve its objectives simply by going for our jugular-the sea-lanes which the Government, through the agency of the Dibb report, is telling us we should not, in principle, defend.

With the strategic theory postulated in this report, I have no argument. It is coherent and logical; in itself, it makes sense. The problem is that it is a strategy for some other country, not for Australia. The Dibb strategy is fine for a country with a large population which does not rely on maritime trade. But we are a big country with a small population and we rely on our sea-lanes being safe, not just in the immediate vicinity of our most important harbours, but thousands of miles from our coastline and well beyond the refuelled range of our FA-18s. Dibb makes for interesting reading in strategic theory. But his report is not relevant to the principal defence needs of this country.

How could the Minister and his adviser have got it so wrong? The problem is an intellectual blind spot, one which the Dibb Report shares with the Strategic Basis papers, and the Cross Report on The Australian Defence Force. All these documents have been pre-occupied with direct threats to the Australian mainland. All these documents have been concerned to make the obvious point that Australia is not directly threatened and that such a threat is unlikely to mature in circumstances short of a third world war. In this respect, all these documents are painstakingly learned and beside the point. What has been missed in each one of them is a most important issue: that of indirect threats.

Indirect threats are potentially the most dangerous because in the history of warfare the indirect approach to dealing with opponents has produced the most clear cut results. In judging its defence needs, a nation which ignores indirect threats does so at its peril.

While the Australian mainland is not threatened directly, there are very serious potential threats developing, under the influence of Soviet imperial expansion, against areas vital to Australia's defence. These threats are indirect (in that they threaten Australia's life-supplying lines-of-communication) and are every bit as dangerous for Australia as direct ones. Indeed, they are more dangerous because they are more subtle and easily overlooked.
Because Australia depends on the sea-lanes for its economic survival and for military resupply, the areas of greatest strategic importance to Australia are the following:
1. our trades routes to Japan;
2. the Persian Gulf and our sea communications to that area;
3. the narrow waterways between the Pacific and Indian Oceans;
4. the land adjacent to these waters;
5. Australia's sea and air links with the United States.

If these waters, or the lands adjacent to them, were controlled by hostile forces-for example, the Soviet Union or its regional clients-and if our resupply routes to the United States could be severed, this would amount to a indirect threat to Australia of strategic proportions. If such a development occurred, the enemy who had this advantage over us would not need to threaten our mainland. In such circumstances Australia could lose its power of self-determination without firing a shot.

The inescapable conclusion is that these lands and waters are crucial to the safety and independence of Australia. Our country is geographically isolated from, but economically dependent on, the outside world. We are a nation dangling at the end of long, vulnerable threads which hang from the Asian sub-continent. Cut these and Australia is gravely endangered.

To go back, then, to the question I posed at the outset: what must we defend to ensure Australia's security? The answer: our foreign and defence policies must be directed at securing the sea-lanes, particularly where they pass through waters which wash the shores of our South East Asian neighbours.
It is another question, of course, whether these areas of paramount defence significance for Australia are being threatened at the moment.

Contrary to the benign view taken of our strategic environment by the Dibb Report, the past decade has witnessed a Soviet penetration of our region which is potentially threatening to our most valuable geographic and economic defence interests. It would require much more than another speech to do justice to these developments. But, for the moment, one can at least nominate them:
1. a Soviet lurch toward the Persian Gulf in the form of the Afghanistan invasion;
2. Soviet navel penetration of the Indian Ocean;
3. the development of Soviet bases in Vietnam;
4. the beginnings of Soviet activity in the South-West Pacific, either on its own account or through the agency of clients, such as Cuba, or allies, such as Libya.
Other potential threats to our strategic interests come from within the region.

One is the situation in the Philippines. It is by no means certain that Mrs Aquino's ``People's Power'' will guarantee the survival of democratic government. It is not certain that Mrs Aquino will induce the NPA to lay down its arms. Nor is it a certainty that, should it refuse, the NPA could be beaten.
Another is the way Australia has shot itself in the foot over relations with Indonesia.

Our most important sea-lanes pass through the Indonesian archipelago. Moreover, the Indonesian navy is on the way to being the region's most advanced and powerful. The RAN is becoming inferior, in several important respects, to the navy the Indonesians can deploy across our lines-of-communications. Given the attitude of the Defence Department and the present Government toward the Navy, the capacities of the RAN will continue to weaken relative to those of regional naval forces-not that the Indonesians conceive of having to use these against us.

The sharp turn for the worse in Australian relations with Indonesia has less to do, I suggest, with our free press and with the alleged unfriendliness of Indonesians, than with the visit by the Minister for Defence to Jakarta. He went there to explain the Dibb Report and it seems he failed.

From the Indonesian viewpoint, the Dibb Report looks like an Australian withdrawal from our region. This must suggest to Indonesia that Australia does not care about its ASEAN friends or about the interests they share with Australia. Or Dibb could even suggest to Jakarta that Australia regards Indonesia as its real potential enemy because Dibb's whole preoccupation is with an improbable scenario of raids and other so-called ``credible contingencies'' which could only be mounted from Indonesia.

These are reasonable inferences for Indonesia to draw. Consequently, rather than contributing to Australia's security, the Dibb Report creates perceptions of Australia which must isolate us in our region and further weaken our strategic position.

The simple answer to our defence problem is not, however, merely the American alliance. Although it is a crucial factor in our defence, we can not rely on the United States as heavily as we have sought to do since World War II. Instead, we need a defence capacity independently to project force deep into our regional waters and adjacent territories. While freedom of action in our own defence demands independently sustainable military forces, we are, nevertheless, not strong enough to provide on our own for the security of our vital interests.
This is because our safety depends upon the security of the ASEAN (Association of South East Asian Nations) region through which our chief lines-of-communication pass.
Australia needs, therefore, both the friendship of our ASEAN neighbours and the military capacity to act in concert with them to defend the security of the whole region.

It would be an act of folly for Australia to leave the defence of its vital interests to others, especially to countries whose defence potential is considerably less than our own and who will see in the Dibb Report an Australia indifferent to the security of those on whom we expect to count.

Moreover, it would be absurd to claim, as this Report does, that Australia contributes to regional security by protecting Indonesia's southern flank, when there are no threats to Indonesia from the south, when there are potential threats maturing to the North-West, North, and North-East of the region, and when Australia refuses to do more than take an innocuous intellectual interest in these developments.

But the main point I want to make in this speech is that, threat or no threat, it is imperative for us to get clear what lands and waters must be defended to make Australia secure. They lie well outside the 1,000 nautical mile defence zone recommended by the Dibb Report. When we understand this central point, then we can begin to talk intelligently about foreign relations, about strategy, force structure, and equipment.

Unless we get the crucial questions right, however, our deliberation about defence will be like the Dibb Report, an academic exercise of considerable value in itself but with little relation to the actual defence problems posed by our geographic situation, economic needs, and regional responsibility.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vigor) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to establish an authority to undertake reinsurance business, and for purposes connected therewith.
Bill presented by Senator Vigor, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Background
Australia is sinking into debt at an escalating rate. For years, we have depended on foreign services, causing a trade deficit in ``invisibles''.

We are also depending more and more on imported goods, and going deeper and deeper into debt on our trade in goods. The collapse of world prices for our farm produce, minerals and oil has proved how much we rely on these primary products to balance our books.

World trade in invisibles, or services, is doubling every four years, and is now of equal value to half the trade in goods. By the 1990's it is expected to equal the trade in goods. General insurance, with its principle of spreading risks, is a world service trade and probably one of the largest in terms of money flows. Australia's deficit on trade in invisibles is growing, and the associated ebb and flow of capital through our markets is highly disruptive.
Purpose

This Bill sets up an Authority to manage a local reinsurance market, made attractive through government guarantee, to attract some proportion of this international insurance business to Australia. Currently there are no official international conventions or agreements covering trade in invisibles, it is every one and every country for himself. There are no remedies for damage in international law, no overall standards of business conduct.

For these reasons and others, many countries including Japan and the E.E.C. do not allow residents to insure directly on overseas markets. Yet Australians last year doubled their direct placement of insurance overseas, that has doubled Australia's import of insurance cover.
The Australian Democrats want a strong local insurance industry, so that Australians don't run the risk of buying cheap insurance abroad. What a crazy thing, to run a risk in insuring a risk!

We need to stop loose money floating about and destroying our dollar's value and our financial credibility. I would like to see us move to a system of tying our costs of imports to what we earn from exports, taxing heavily the excess money leaving Australia. We need to introduce investment controls to make sure that money coming into Australia is used to encourage manu- facture and business. We need to develop exports of services, in insurance, banking, communications, information, and tourism. We need to create in Australia a reinsurance market to earn us money in the ``invisibles'' sector of our economy.
Invisibles

Currently Australia suffers from an increasingly large overseas debt burden, while our trade balance with the rest of the world slumps further and further into deficit. The major portion of this deficit is due to a loss in our invisibles account.
The invisibles account includes:
insurance,
banking services,
trade in technology-i.e. patents, royalties, etc.,
aid,
investment income and interest payments,
shipping and air freight,
travel and tourism,
telecommunications and information services,
consulting and engineering projects, and
education.

Typically Australia has had a balance of payments deficit over the past twenty years which has averaged around 3.3 per cent of GDP. The current account deficit has usually resulted from a slight trade surplus more than offset by a net deficit on invisibles. This invisibles deficit has been mainly due to interest and dividends payable on capital borrowed abroad, and to a net deficit on tradeable services such as insurance, banking, transport and travel.

I have frequently raised the problem of Australia's increasing national debt. This problem needs to be solved urgently, but the Government seems to be impotent. Less and less of the capital coming into Australia is used for productive investment, more and more is used for financing the increased costs of imports, the refinancing of debt, the take-overs and the sale of Australian assets to foreign interests.

I have suggested that a tax on ``moneys'' leaving the country could help to regulate this undesirable and destabilising inflow of foreign capital into Australia. Such a tax would encourage international barter, and would give business an incentive to trade goods for goods rather than goods for money. This would reduce pressure on our dollar.

The causes of the deficit on tradeable services are more complex, but would also be decreased as a result of such a tax. Once again, international barter would be encouraged, and our service imports would be paid for by a balancing export of services. We must improve Australia's ability to provide such services by establishing in Australia a credible market for insurance, banking, shipping and travel services. This is the only permanent solution available, and the Australian Democrats are working to make this happen.

The world market for services has expanded dramatically in the last decade, yet Australia's share of this trade has decreased. This is against the world trend! The world trade in services is not regulated by official internation agreements, and there is no international protection for Australians who purchase services from overseas.
Insurance
Like most other invisibles, insurance services are not adequately regulated on international markets. Consequently, information on internation insurance transactions is very difficult to obtain.

Since Australia now has no controls on direct insurance business placed abroad, it is similarly very difficult to obtain information on the extent and nature of the transactions, treaties and contracts which are entered into with overseas insurers or underwriters. This has meant that previous governments have put the problem of trade in insurance into the ``too hard basket''. But pressure has been building amongst the Australian owned insurance companies; and the Commonwealth Insurance Office, for better information about what are essentially ``insurance imports''. Pressure is also mounting from these same organisations and from the general public, for better controls on reinsurance and direct insurance overseas.

The increasingly aggressive marketing of overseas insurance and the increasing number of cases of problems associated with unscrupulous or unsafe foreign insurance firms has contributed to this perceived need. Insurance can only flourish when people have confidence in it. Bad experiences with insurance reduce public confidence, even if those bad experiences are caused only by unscrupulous foreign companies.
The 1984 Report of the Trade Development Council Panel 75 on Invisible Trade makes several recommendations concerning the insurance market in Australia.
Need for Reliable Information

Its first recommendation is to improve the collection and publication of statistical information on international insurance transactions, and this also has been vehemently requested by the Australian Insurance Commissioner.

Large volumes of Australian direct insurance business are placed overseas, something that is not permitted in many of the larger markets of the world such as Japan and the E.E.C.. Australian-owned and controlled companies hold only 33 per cent of the total private enterprise insurance market in Australia, thus the invisibles trade balance is affected even more as the profits and dividends from foreign-owned companies are sent overseas.

Australia is a net exporter of insurance risk, that is we are a net importer of insurance contracts on the invisibles account, according to Mr Grahame Bond, President of the Australian Insurance Association. He points out that published statistics are not available to provide a comprehensive picture of Australia's overseas insurance purchases. Some of this business is apparently for insurance of complex or unusual risks for which the Australian market has no tariffs or statistical tables available. However, much of this insurance is ``direct standard risk'' insurance. These contracts which are written overseas may appear to be cheaper, but are not in any way guaranteed and are hence not secure. The only thing worse than no insurance is unreliable or insecure insurance.

Australian truckies have found this out to their severe cost. Quite a number of Aussie battlers insured their trucks with an overseas company through a local agent, who did not adequately spell out the extra risks of this type of insurance. The American insurance company in turn, offset its risks by reinsuring with another American company, which eventually defaulted. The original insurer then refused to pay any claims, on the basis that he could not recover his claims from the reinsurer. Many Australian truckies with claims on the American company were sent into bankruptcy as a result. These truck owners had no come-back on their insurer, on the agents, on the brokers or on the underwriters.
International Justice

Overseas companies are beyond Australian law if they write insurance business overseas, rather than through a local subsidiary. There is a growing trend for more and more of this type of ``insurance'' to be sold through agents in Australia, although many overseas countries outlaw such uncontrollable insurance contracts.

The problem of justice, the lack of international remedy for wrongs, is probably the major barrier to international trade. In trade in invisibles, and particularly in the area of insurance, until there are adequate means of international arbitration, and adequate standards of service, Australia cannot afford international free trade in insurance.

This very problem of insecurity in international trade can be Australia's opportunity. By offering the same protection and guarantees to its overseas clients as in its locally regulated insurance business, Australia can attract risk insurance to our local market. We foresee that the Australian Reinsurance Market will offer a service to negotiate treaties on behalf of Australian companies wishing to reinsure overseas, and will also offer a service to vet and approve treaties negotiated between bigger registered groups who have registered with the Australian Reinsurance Authority to negotiate their own treaties.

In this way, Australia will help to set adequate international standards for the future. Australia will pave the way for negotiating international trade agreements on insurance which give the same protection to people all over the world.
Incentives for an Australian Reinsurance Market

The second major recommendation of the Trade Development Council Panel 75 on Invisibles Trade was for the Government to look into establishing a reinsurance market in Australia, and to examine the balance of incentives and disincentives for the insurance and reinsurance industry in Australia.
Fire Service Levy

Currently, stamp duty and fire service fees are levied on international insurance written in Australia as well as on local risks. This increases the cost of insuring in Australia. It makes Australian insurance companies unable to compete in international insurance, so that the balance of insurance is always against Australia-we write Australian insurance overseas, but do not write overseas insurance in Australia.

The Trade Development Council Panel 75 reported that in Queensland over 50 per cent of companies are avoiding fire service levies by insuring overseas through their parent companies or directly through overseas insurance companies. This results in a narrowing of the tax base, and places an unfair burden on private people and small Australian businesses. As the per capita fire service levy rises for those who continue to insure locally, the competitiveness of Australian fire insurance is further eroded, and the vicious cycle continues.

I recommend that we discontinue the practice of charging fire service levies against insurance, that this service be provided at general community cost, and that the alternative of charging for actual fire service calls be considered. This would encourage people to insure against this extra fire-fighting cost in addition to insuring against the loss or damage of property caused by fire. The same end would be achieved but with the costs falling where they are due.
Stamp Duty

The practice of charging stamp duties on fin- ancial transactions is more difficult to resolve. These charges fall heavily on the finance industries, particularly banking and insurance services, while transactions involving visible goods are not taxed to the same extent. However, it is important not to introduce more anomalies into the taxation system by starting to allow selective exemptions which distort the decisions of Australian business.
Taxation Incentives
Reinsurance business is exempt from tax in certain countries, or is taxed at a lower rate. These countries thus gain a cost advantage on international reinsurance markets.
Other countries offer the advantage of government guarantee of their reinsurers, and thus also have an international advantage.

Merely offering tax incentives to foreign companies to establish locally owned subsidiaries will divert a proportion of their international business through Australia, but this will in no way solve this fundamental problem of acceptable trade practices and standards, nor will it solve the problem of adequate consumer protection and international arbitration. The alternative of taxing moneys leaving the country will achieve the same end, by encouraging these companies to balance their Australian risks insured overseas with overseas risks insured in Australia, thus balancing the business so that no money to be taxed leaves the country. But the second incentive approach brings revenue into the Treasury, whereas tax relief eats into Treasury receipts.

While tax incentives could attract more international business through Australia, that business would ebb and flow as other countries counter-offered with even lower tax incentives. Ultimately we would be blackmailed into a discriminatory tax policy, taxing only those transactions from local Australian risks. The price for foreign cash flow would be inordinate, as all the costs would be offset against this tax on local business, while tax relief would be claimed for all overseas trade. The alternative of completely exempting the insurance industry from taxation would create other anomalies of a similar kind.

Although the Panel 75 Report recommended that tax concessions be considered for Australian reinsurers, such positive discrimination in favour of one industry would set a precedent for similar tax cuts in other areas, and lead to a yet more complicated taxation system than Australia already suffers.
Government Guarantee
An equivalent advantage can be provided through Government guarantee, with the added bonus of Australian control and sharing in some of the profits of reinsurance.

The Australian Insurance Association Review highlights the alarming imbalance between Australia's visible and invisibles trade account, particularly over the last ten years. One of the major services showing a deficit is the insurance area, although the Australian insurance market is one of the most competitive in the world, according to Mr Grahame Bond, President of the Australian Insurance Association.

Overseas the picture is not so rosy. The United States of America is undergoing a crisis in its insurance industry, with exploding premium costs as lawyers win increasing amounts of damages for clients in the courts. The insurance com- panies from the United States have used this as an excuse to put up their premiums world-wide. Australian consumers of insurance are likely to suffer as a result, as American insurers try to make up for deficits in the U.S. business by increasing their profit margins and cash flows abroad. There is also an increased likelihood that more and more underwriters in America will go to the wall, and American insurance companies will fail to pay up.
The Bill

This Bill sets up a body to be known as the Australian Reinsurance Authority, a corporation to carry on the business of reinsurance in Australia, and to encourage insurers both in Australia and overseas to reinsure their risks with the Australian Reinsurance Authority.

The Board of the Authority is to be representative of the insurance industry in Australia. Four of its members are to be directly elected by insurance corporations and underwriters. Another three members of the Board are to be appointed because of their expert knowledge in the field. In addition, the Board will have a Presiding Member, a Deputy Presiding Member, a Managing Director and the Chairman of the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Board. The Managing Director is to be appointed by the Board, while the other non-elected Members of the Board apart from the Chairman of EFIC are to be appointed by the Governor-General.

The Minister for Finance may fund the Authority out of moneys appropriated by the Parliament, and profits of the Authority will be applied as the Minister sees fit. The Authority will also have the ability to raise funds on its own behalf. These funds may be guaranteed by the Treasurer on behalf of the Commonwealth.
Advantages of the Bill

If we attract foreign insurance business into Australia because of our reputation for stability, high standards of service and guaranteed security, then we protect our Australian citizens at the same time as we set international standards for insurance business.

Another form of protection for our Australian insurance industry which could be considered is to require that a proportion of all reinsurance of risk be done through the Australian Reinsurance Authority. We could consider an invisibles offset program. One advantage of such a requirement would be the opportunity provided to collect information on overseas reinsurance transactions, which currently are not properly monitored.

This problem of lack of adequate information about Australian insurance has been raised by the Australian Insurance Commissioner, as well as by the Australian Insurance Association. The same concerns have also been raised internationally by the OECD and GATT, which have asked member nations to collect and assemble information on insurance, and on other invisibles transactions, so that negotiations for freeing up international trade in invisibles can begin. Until this information is reasonably complete, GATT cannot set up workable standards for multi- lateral trade agreements for invisibles, nor can the OECD sponsor more restricted bilateral agreements between OECD member nations under appropriate OECD codes.

The Australian Reinsurance Market will provide a control point at which information on insurance can be collected without distortion, and provided in a form useful for government decisions on trade policies.

However, this Bill is not intended to set up protective measures for the Australian insurance industry, but merely to enable a local reinsurance market to be established on terms which will make it competitive with other already established world reinsurance markets.

Australia's annual net deficit for insurance varies from year to year. In a year of big natural disasters in Australia there may be a net inflow of insurance money into Australia, as it is normal to reinsure such risks in other parts of the world. These anomalies completely hide the constant outflow of premiums overseas. To collect adequate information on insurance business, it is important to collect statistics on gross premiums paid and gross insurance payments received, both for insurance bought abroad and for overseas insurance sold in Australia.

The Trade Development Council Panel 75 estimated that Australia's apparent deficit of only $417 million in the balance of insurance payments in 1981/82 in fact represented between $750 million and $1,000 million of total premiums paid abroad in that year, out of a total of $3,500 million of insurance business placed in Australia.

Spreading risk beyond country borders is an essential element of insurance. Reinsurance of risk in this way provides security and stability. But the cost of laying off Australia's insurance risk overseas can be more than recouped by establishing a successful reinsurance market in Australia to cover foreign risks.

Currently, although there is one significant Australian reinsurer, plus several very small operations, they handle only half as much Australian business as overseas owned companies. The Australian Insurance Association in its 1985 annual report stresses that Australian-owned insurance companies tend to reinsure also with the locally-based reinsurance market. The Australian Reinsurance Authority will not take business away from existing reinsurers, but will provide a service in amalgamating small reinsurance business into larger group treaties. It will provide an opportunity for underwriters in Australia to take on reinsurance risks from overseas, using private consortia of underwriters backed up by a government guarantee. Provided treaties are approved, they will be guaranteed.
