The Insurance Commissioner, in his 1984/85 Annual Report to Parliament, stated:

``On those occasions when I do review the underlying documentation (of reinsurance arrangements) in many instances it becomes apparent that the treaties are not understood and lack accurate and effective wordings. The experience of general insurance liquidators tends to bear this out also.''
And later on, he reported:

``I continue to receive from time to time notification of reinsurance arrangements that can best be described as artificial contrivances intended merely to reduce premium income as defined in the Act and hence the insurer's required solvency margin.''

He went on to discuss the accounting problems in the area of reinsurance, and the lack of any clear statement of liability of a company to its policyholders, because of the practice of reporting the net liability after deducting the amounts recoverable from reinsurers, and failure to separate amounts payable to reinsurers from amounts recoverable from reinsurers.

An Australian reinsurance market, guaranteed by government, trading on Australia's stability and security, with adequate supervision of our terms of contracts and treaties, can attract international insurance business into Australia, and give us the opportunity to offset our large risks overseas on favourable terms of trade.

On Wednesday night, we heard Mr Hawke underline Australia's trade difficulties, and our growing balance of payments problems, with remarkable rhetorical flourishes. It was disappointing that there were no real solutions beyond the rhetoric.

This Bill is a positive measure, which will be a positive contribution to turning the corner and making our trade position positive, by creating an international reinsurance market in Australia. This Bill, if passed, will bring Australia into a positive balance of trade at least in the insurance area. I entreat the Government to support and implement the proposals as soon as possible, for Australia's sake. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Coates) agreed to:

(1) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has completed any of its Reports, the Committee may send the Reports to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, and, in that event-
(a) the Reports shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate;
(b) the publication of the Reports is authorised by this Resolution;
(c) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the Reports; and
(d) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, shall lay the Reports upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(2) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, insofar as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry and Trade: Certain Aspects of Australia's Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation.

My Committee is very concerned about the need for our manufacturing sector to become more internationally competitive and export-oriented. The Committee has been holding discussions with employer and employee representatives who have identified specific concerns and possible lines of inquiry. To simply cover all aspects of manufacturing industry revitalisation would be way beyond the resources of my Committee. It would also duplicate work that has been done or is being done by other organisations.

The Committee wants to make a worthwhile contribution to the debate on manufacturing, therefore it is very mindful of the need to formulate appropriate terms of reference. The Committee is considering issues such as competitiveness, investment, development of manufacturing skills, industrial democracy, research and development, marketing and export development, infrastructure support systems and impediments to manufacturing. This list is by no means exhaustive and each issue warrants a major inquiry in its own right.

The Committee will continue to discuss these matters with various people and organisations during the recess with the view to identifying and firming up on the most appropriate terms of reference. The Committee will therefore report back to the Senate at the commencement of the Budget session of Parliament on what course or courses of action it will be pursuing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Bills be referred to the following Standing Committees for report on the first day of sitting in August 1986:
Standing Committee on Education and the Arts:
Australian National Maritime Museum Bill 1986
Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations:
Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986
Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986
Standing Committee on Industry and Trade:
Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1986
Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment:
Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1986
Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Amendment Bill 1986.

I think I should explain very briefly the purpose behind this motion. The question of referring more legislation to Senate standing committees has been under discussion now for more than 50 years. I have been feeling around recently for some method of getting this done on a more systematic basis. I think it is universally agreed that Bills that have been referred to committees for public examination have normally been greatly improved thereby. Difficulties and defects that have escaped public servants in the ministerial system have been revealed. I think anyone who has been on one of these committees has been very impressed by the value of the public exposure of a Bill and the public and informed input into its provisions.

We have eight legislative and general purpose committees. In the past they have almost exclusively dealt with their general purpose role and they have not properly performed their legislative role. This proposal will remedy that defect. We have a Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which was set up against initial government opposition because governments never like legislation being examined. It is up to this place to decide to examine legislation, not for the government to decide that. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee was set up, after great difficulty and opposition from the then government, but I think no one would now dispute the very great value of the work which that Committee does on its very limited front. This proposal attempts to extend that front to the general structure of a Bill, its purpose and implementation, as well as the narrow legal front under which that Committee operates.

One of the objections in the past to referring Bills to a committee has been that it might delay legislation. Therefore, the Bills that are proposed are ones that the Government has said it does not propose to proceed with this session. The reporting date is the first sitting day in August. What will happen in many cases is that the Committee will expose a Bill, find no difficulties with it and will report back to the Senate. Bills will have been publicly exposed, looked at by experts, and the Senate will know there is nothing wrong with them. If serious defects are found and if the Committee wishes to extend its investigations, it will need to get the permission of the Senate to extend its reporting date. Therefore, the future handling of these Bills and any possible delays remain in the hands of the Senate.

I have spoken to all of the Opposition and Australian Democrat senators who are members of the relevant committees and all of them are satisfied that it is feasible for the committees to do these investigations and that it would be desirable for them to do so. I have also informed all the Senate chairmen of the various committees and none of them to my mind had cogent objections; they may have different views. It is true that if they did more legislative work, which is supposed to be half of their functions, it would probably delay some of their other general purpose investigations. These are legislative and general purpose committees and this reference would improve the balance, which has been right out of line in the past, and make them do more very desirable legislative work. In any case, I do not think it proper that a Government chairman of a committee should think that he has the power of veto over what Bills should go to a committee. It is up to this place to decide what Bills go to a committee. I recommend my motion accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose Senator Hamer's motion. As Chair of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, to which Senator Hamer is proposing that two related Bills be referred, I make it clear that it would be virtually impossible for us to consider these two Bills during the coming recess. As I explained to Senator Hamer a day or two ago when he approached me about this matter, we have about five or six urgent reports which we are desperately trying to finish in order to table. I had hoped to table some of them before the end of this period of sittings but that has proved not to be possible. We have not even begun consideration yet of one reference which came from the Opposition at the end of last year because of the pressure of other business. I am not suggesting that it is never appropriate for Bills to be referred to standing committees because in fact the Finance and Government Operations Committee in the last couple of years has dealt with one or two Bills when it has been appropriate, that is, when there has been a real value pointed to in referring particular Bills, because of the particular nature of them or the way they have been dealt with in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Hamer's proposal is inappropriate because there is no particular reason for these Bills to be referred, except for the fact that they are not urgent in terms of the Government's legislative program. He has advanced no particular reason in respect of each Bill. He has made the proposal merely on the basis of it being a good idea that Bills be referred to standing committees. If my Committee was forced to deal with the Bills relating to the Institute of Sport, our consideration of them would have to be very skimpy indeed, because of the pressure of other work. This would bring into disrepute the very idea of standing committees dealing with Bills, as these Bills would have to be dealt with in an inadequate way because of lack of time. Of course I do not suggest that chairs of Senate committees should be in a position to veto references. That has to be a decision in this place. But if we are to have a general proposition to refer Bills to standing committees there ought to be a change in the way that committees operate generally rather than doing this in an ad hoc way. Committees would require more resources, more staff and more time to deal with these sorts of matters properly.

Senator Hamer said that he had contacted Opposition and Australian Democrat members of various committees. If he had talked to Opposition members of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations he would have found out from them that what I have said is correct. We are trying to finalise five or six matters during the recess. If Senator Hamer had approached Senator Vigor from the Democrats he would have discovered that Senator Vigor had joined the Committee only in the last week and would be only vaguely aware of our program. I suggest that it would be inappropriate to adopt this motion. I oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion moved by Senator Hamer. I wish to indicate briefly why we do so. In the history of the reference of Bills to committees, Mr President, you would be very hard-pressed to find an example of a Bill being sent to a committee other than with the opposition of government senators. There always seems to be a reason why committee consideration of Bills should not be undertaken. Usually lip service is paid to the fact that it would be desirable if the Senate scrutinised legislation more closely but once one gets down to trying to make a decision it is almost automatic that there be resistance. The whole development of the Senate committee system has tended to be in the face of government resistance. I acknowledge that that resistance has been from governments of my colour as well as those of a Labor persuasion.

SPEECH.PARA: The most recent institutional change to our committee system occurred when the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was established over the objections of the then Fraser Government. Those objections which were that it would slow down legislation, prevent the Government getting its program through and so on proved to be unfounded. Senator Coates very properly is concerned about the work load of committees. But in supporting this motion the Opposition says that at least some of the objections which are usually raised cannot be raised. All the Bills which we seek to refer cannot be dealt with by the Senate until August in any event. So there is no question of delay to the Government's program. We believe that the Bills warrant additional examination. Our history of committee examination of Bills has been that in virtually every case worthwhile improvements have been able to be effected.

It is my view that at the moment the Senate committee system is not developing. That is a pity. One of the areas with which we should be very anxious to experiment is having more detailed consideration of Bills than is able to be given in the Committee of the Whole. The general principle that we tend to support that the Senate should give legislation careful review can be put to practical test during this recess. It may well be that some committees will report back in a satisfactory and complete way and others in a less satisfactory and less complete way. But it is important that we cease what has been happening over the last two years at least, namely, a total resistance to any real development of the Senate committee system. Our capacity to look at legislation in the Committee of the Whole is less effective than is our capacity to look at it in a committee context. I hope that given that there can be no delay to the Government's program the Senate on this occasion will support what is a very modest proposal from Senator Hamer. It certainly has the strong support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose Senator Hamer's motion. It is just not good enough that Bills be referred to standing committees in this way. The idea could be of benefit to the Senate in the future, but before we followed such a course the staffing position would have to be completely reviewed. It is impossible to do that at this time. As I see it, the number of committees would have to be increased to at least eight. Members of each committee would have to break up into sub-committees in order to look at legislation. At the moment all committees are working very hard on their particular references. The Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare hopes to present a report on retirement incomes to the Senate in August. That Committee would have virtually no time-I do not think Senator Hamer has referred anything to that Committee-to deal with another matter by then. The work load of all committees is great, and if we force too much more work on them we will not see value in the reports presented to the Senate. That is an important point.
—Your Committee is not referred to.

—I realise that. All I am saying is that all committees are in the same position. That is an important point to remember. If it is envisaged that Senate standing committees will look at all legislation, a lot more work has to be done before that happens. We cannot do this in a haphazard way. The staffing position is very important and should be considered by the Senate. To give the committees more work at this time is totally irresponsible.
—Oh God!

—Senator Chaney may think that is not so, but I believe that the Senate standing committees do a valuable job for the Senate. It is important that these committees report to Parliament and to the people, and I have always believed that those reports should be first class reports. Reports should not come into this place in a negligent way.

SPEECH.PARA: It is time the Senate looked at where the committees are going. Maybe the reports are too complicated. We do not have adequate staff. I oppose the motion and I ask honourable senators to think carefully about it. I am not saying that I totally oppose the idea, but to go about it in a haphazard way, off the cuff, is not right. More planning is needed before this can be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the concept of the motion with enthusiasm. I say that that enthusiasm is not necessarily shared by all my colleagues. I commend Senator Hamer for the way in which he has pursued this matter for many months now together with his Leader. I must say-I do not want to be unkind-that the enthusiasm shown by senior Liberals to refer matters to committees was not shown by them when they were in government. It is a good thing for oppositions to do, but one has to consider whether the proposal is a good idea overall for the Senate. One must say that, theoretically, contentious Bills should be referred to Senate committees before coming into this Senate so that there is an added watchdog on legislation brought before the Parliament. I agree with Senator Elstob that at present the resources of committees and the time available to them is totally inadequate to do this job in a big way. I see this as an opportunity to test, or to experiment with, Senator Hamer's concept. I do not think any harm will be done by doing this. As Senator Coates and Senator Elstob have said, all the committees are hard working, undermanned and underresourced, and maybe they will not have the time to look at these Bills. As I understand the Hamer motion, if the committees do not have the time to consider them they will simply report back on the first day of sitting in August that they have not had time and no harm will be done. The Government can then proceed with its legislative program.

SPEECH.PARA: I understood from Senator Hamer-I am not criticising him-that he had received agreement from the various committee chairmen on this concept. That was a simple misunderstanding; possibly it was my fault for misunderstanding him. However, on that basis I reported to my Party and we did have agreement. Apparently my understanding was not correct. Notwithstanding that, for the reason I just said-that is, that if the committees are too busy, if they have too many other things to do and if the amount of resources available to them is not adequate-all they have to do is to report back on the first day of sitting after the recess that they have not had time to consider the reference.

Mr President, before I resume my seat may I say that, with all the strength I have, I commend you for the work you have done in trying to get additional resources for committees. You have been outstandingly successful, but you could be still more successful for the committees' sake, as you know. We commend you and ask you to continue your efforts in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the proposal put forward by Senator Hamer, which I have certainly looked at very seriously. I have no difficulty with the prospect of examining legislation, but one of my committees has a particular problem that is typical of that experienced by other committees. Two excellent researchers are leaving my committee to go to greener fields and this is a problem that Senate committees have all the time. Mr President, particularly at the moment I would like to see you look at the career structure of researchers because it seems that we train researchers and they are then plundered by other parts of the bureaucracy. That is a real problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer is proposing a qualitative change of which, in effect, we have been given only a few days notice. For that reason I believe we would be wise not to accede to the motion at this point. We need literally months to adjust to any changes that would occur. I have announced a proposed reference to one of my committees of a very serious and important topic. We are also struggling to complete a series of reports, including a final report on a matter on which we have spent a great deal of time, several years in fact-the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand. For all of these reasons I feel that I must oppose the motion. At this point the proposal would impose an unnecessary strain on my committee. It is something that needs to be examined and planned for more carefully. We need to have a balance in legislation and other references so that we know where we stand.

I notice the gung ho approach of the Opposition front bench. The same honourable senators as Ministers have resisted this sort of proposal. I acknowledge that this approach would advantage Oppositions, but it is something that governments want to see the value of before they agree to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Hamer's motion. I draw attention to the fact that the Bills which he seeks to refer to committees are not in any way contentious Bills. They have all gone through the House of Representatives with the support of the Opposition parties. They do not raise major areas of policy and therefore will not impose upon the committees major questions of a policy and research nature. I will go through the Bills very briefly. The only issues arising from the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill 1986 appear to be ones of cost and methodology, which have already been looked at in their very initial stages by Estimates Committee D and which could be further investigated. The Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986 relate only to the question of whether the translation of the Australian Institute of Sport from a company limited by guarantee to a statutory authority is the correct way to proceed. The Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1986 deals only with the question of the levels of foreign takeover applications requiring the approval of the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1986 is a technical matter updating the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species provisions. The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Amendment Bill 1986 is a technical Bill which simply seeks to bring some greater degree of efficiency into the way in which the action Minister and the Minister responsible for the legislation interact. Therefore, they are not contentious issues. Nevertheless, they are issues which require some scrutiny just to see that the aims of the legislation are in fact being effected by the proposals in the legislation. Certainly, therefore, it will not require any investigation of the policy issues which underlie or underpin the legislation which is being referred to the relevant Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, they are not contentious Bills because all of them have been through the House of Representatives with the support of the Opposition parties. Of course, the Australian Democrats understood the value of this system when their Deputy Leader, Senator Haines, moved the reference of the Opposition's amendment on the Copyright Amendment Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for investigation. That was a matter which, in fact, raised substantial contentious policy issues. It is interesting that there should be a concern among some of the Australian Democrats that they do not mind referring a Bill which is a highly contentious Bill and which will, in fact, take a degree of examination by the Committee but mind, however, referring the purely technical matters, matters which I would have thought could be dealt with in the course, probably, of only a brief interview with the departmental officers concerned for report back within the same sort of time constraints as the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills is able to give to these things. I would have thought that that would have been most advantageous.

The only other point I want to make is that because the committees are legislative and general purpose committees they do not appear to do very much by way of a legislative nature in terms of the actual text and terms of the legislation which comes into the Senate and, which I believe, would be properly referred. It is to be remembered that while, for instance, the members of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee have to make themselves familiar with certain general principles and then apply them to a whole range of Bills, what we are seeking to do is to take Bills appropriate to a particular committee and let the members of that committee who have already developed some expertise in that particular field bring their expertise to bear on the whole thing. It is perfectly true that governments of our persuasion, as well as Labor governments, have resisted this. Nevertheless, some of us would like to claim a degree of purity on the matter. The Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was established because I and a number of other then Government back benchers crossed the floor to ensure that the Committee was established. The final point I therefore make is that in every one of these debates one seems to find that Government benches are absolutely populated with a surfeit of Saint Augustines, all of them wishing to be made virtuous, but none of them wishing to be made virtuous just yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about the motion before us. When Senator Hamer came to see me about this matter I was rather taken aback because I did not know that this proposal was in the wind. I point out that there was no agreement from me on this matter. The conversation went something like this. Senator Hamer said: `We would like to put this Bill before your Committee during the recess to report by the first day of August. We will do so unless you have any major objections'. I replied in words to the effect that I would normally be pleased to take on a reference such as that. However, we have a major inquiry before us as the moment-the education of gifted and talented children. We have scheduled two public hearings on that reference during the recess.

SPEECH.PARA: On Wednesday night amendments moved by Senator Durack to the Copyright Amendment Bill were referred to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. We have been given a deadline of 28 August to report on that reference. As well as that, we are trying to finish another report. We have finished the public hearings but we want to write up that report. It deals with a very contentious matter, as honourable senators will see when it comes down early in the Budget session. It relates to certain sporting broadcasts of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. That reference is but one of the examinations of annual reports with which we are proceeding.

I cannot see the Committee of which I am Chairman having the resources to take on any further reference between now and when we come back in August. It was difficult enough to find a date when all senators on the Committee could come to a meeting on the reference that was given to us the other night in the Senate. I think it would be almost impossible, now that our diaries have been filled, for us to pick a date for a public hearing on a reference given to us now.

I suppose that in principle I am not upset about Bills being referred to this Committee, but the Bill that is proposed to be referred is not a contentious one, as Senator Chipp implied. We were told that this reference would probably require no public hearings, or very few public hearings, and that we would then be able to bring back a report to the Senate. Quite honestly, I cannot see much point in going through that sort of exercise. If it were a contentious Bill-one on which the Senate wanted advice-there would be some justification for its being referred to the Committee, just as there was justification in giving us that reference the other night so that we can bring down a report on what was regarded as a fairly contentious piece of proposed legislation. If we are going to go down this road, we should make a decision to do so; then the Senate committees would be able to schedule their activities in such a way that they can take on these references. But this is not the time to look at a reference that is made on the spot because we have a lot of references before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am opposed to the reference of legislation to the Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment of which I am Chairman.
—You would support it if you had had a nice early night.

—I do not think I really did but we can deal with that later. The reason I am opposed to the motion is that it is an ad hoc way of making references to a committee. We have to look at the fact that the Committee has planned what will happen in the recess. It has planned its program. We also have to take into consideration the other activities of honourable senators in the recess and the demands of the other committees to which they belong. We had to try to set Committee meeting dates to suit those members of the Committee. I believe that on Monday our Committee is travelling to Mount Isa for a hearing and an inspection in relation to a reference that is before us.

SPEECH.PARA: We are also in the process of finalising a report on a reference before the Committee. I think one has to take into consideration the amount of work being put in by the staff or the people who are attached to our Committee. When one plans what will happen with regard to a reference or a reference that is to be taken up by a committee or what will happen in the recess, one has to take into consideration the amount of work that honourable senators have, the other committees to which they are attached and the amount of work being undertaken by the staff attached to the committee. While I have no great argument with the principle of legislation being moved to the Committee, to do it in this way will certainly put a large load on the Committee, a load that will not allow the Committee to carry out any reference to it in such a way that would be of any value to the Senate. The Committee has a planned program for the recess which will put a fair burden on the staff attached to the Committee, and it would be quite unfair to those staff, unless the resources were increased, to take further references at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-This matter has been the subject of debate and discussion in the Senate for over 50 years. Every time a reference is proposed, we get the same sorts of objections: `Yes, but not yet; a good idea, but we will do it at some time in the unspecified future'. What is proposed here is in the nature of an experiment. None of these Bills is likely to cause a large work load on the committees. We are looking for a better balance between the legislative function and the general purpose function of these committees. The committees have resources which they have allocated at their whim entirely on general purpose activities. It is proposed that they should take on a modest legislative examination activity so that we can see what happened. I would say for certain that the exposure of these Bills to public examination will reveal unexpected flaws. It is to the benefit of the Senate that that should be done. It is to the benefit of the Government that that should be done. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hamer's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations: The procedures of the Commissioner of Taxation and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, with particular reference to-
(a) raising and amending assessments;
(b) the imposition of penalties and interest; and
(c) systems of dealing with objections and appeals against them, and
to recommend changes to present taxation systems in order to streamline and simplify them and to safeguard the rights of taxpayers.

I have discussed the motion with both the Australian Democrats and Senator Coates, the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. Certainly the present work load of the Committee would not enable it to undertake an immediate inquiry on this matter, but I think Senator Coates will be indicating that we will discuss this matter again in the Budget sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take up only a moment of the Senate's time in order to say that, as explained in the previous motion, the work load of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is very heavy at present. I do not want to have on the Committee's list of references a matter which cannot be dealt with but which has been referred to it in June. It would look as though the Committee were slack if it had not dealt with that matter after a few months. After seeking leave to continue my remarks, I intend to move that the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for 17 September 1986. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for 17 September 1986.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered-
(1) The hours of sitting of the Senate on Friday, 13 June 1986, be varied as follows:
(2) The Senate meet on Saturday, 14 June 1986 and that-
(a) the hours of sitting for that day be as follows:
(b) the Order of Business for that day be as follows:
(i) Petitions
(ii) Notices of Motion
(iii) Ministerial Statements
(iv) Formal Motions-Discovery of Formal Business
(v) Government Business as set down on the Notice Paper.

A motion of this type has been moved by the Manager of Government Business or the Leader of the Government in the Senate on every occasion at the end of a session since I have been there. The reason is simple-we may need that time to complete the legislation. We see no reason why we should not complete it in the next day or two. I will not bore the Senate with a long and heart-rending speech on why the motion should be passed; I merely urge the Senate to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will oppose this motion. I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out Order of Business in paragraph (2) (b), insert the following order of business-
(1) Petitions
(2) Notices of Motion
(3) Formal Motions-Discovery of Formal Business
(4) Postponement and re-arrangement of Business
(5) Government Business, Notices of Motion and Orders of the Day, or vice versa, as set down on the Notice Paper
(6) At 2 p.m., Questions
(7) Any proposal pursuant to Standing Order 64
(8) Consideration of Government Papers pursuant to Sessional Order
(9) Further consideration of Government Business, Notices of Motion and Orders of the Day, or vice versa, as set down on the Notice Paper

The reason for the Opposition opposing this motion is that we regard the further extension of the current three-week period of sittings as being quite unreasonable on the notice which has been given by the Government. A couple of weeks ago we sat down with the Government and agreed to extensions to the then arranged sitting hours and arranged to sit in the evenings and on appropriate mornings. Indeed, we had a five-day week last week. This was done because the Government had a very considerable amount of business, including a very substantial volume of taxation legislation to deal with. We are now in the position where senators have made their arrangements on the basis of the sitting arrangements made some weeks ago. I think it is unreasonable to expect a total rearrangement at this very late hour.

I would like to make it quite clear on behalf of the Opposition that the Opposition has now, as in the past, indicated that it will, of course, in general sit whenever the Government requires legislation to be dealt with. However, we have taken the view that more than three weeks in a row of sittings is thoroughly undesirable for reasons of health and, indeed, I think for reasons of rational examination of the issues which face the Senate. I would like to make it quite clear that the Opposition has taken the view that, if the Government has a program which it must get through before the winter recess, the Opposition, whilst insisting insofar as we can that we have an up week next week, would be prepared to come back on the following week. We do not seek that, but we are--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish. That is rubbish and you know it.
—I am getting great assis-tance. On the reading I have made of unparliamentary language over the last 10 hours, I suspect that comment is unparliamentary.
—No, that is not so. You are all ready to catch your flights.
—Order, Senator Coleman!

—Mr President, I am being chided by Senator Coleman on the basis that senators have suitcases downstairs for the afternoon flights. In fact, I am leaving tomorrow so it is no skin off my nose. The point I made was that senators have made their arrangements on the basis of what the Government laid down two weeks ago, and both Government and Opposition senators have arranged to leave Canberra this afternoon. I make no secret of that. I am asserting that they are perfectly entitled to do that because that is the arrangement the Government laid down.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to prolong the debate because I think it is important that we get on with the business which we have to deal with before this Parliament rises. Nevertheless, I think that senators are entitled to have some predictability in their lives. They are entitled not to have the sittings of the Senate prolonged to a point where it is damaging to health and to sanity. I think we would be better to maintain the arrangements which were entered into some weeks ago. For those reasons, the Opposition will be voting against this motion. We have moved this amendment so that if the motion is carried we will confirm the principle that, again, the Opposition has always put forward; that is, that if the Senate is sitting it is not right for the Government to put down an order which precludes the Opposition, independent senators and Australian Democrat senators from exercising their normal rights as senators and from having the access which the Opposition traditionally has to a part of the parliamentary day. Were we to sit tomorrow I think it is likely that people might want to do something other than mount a matter of public importance or an urgency motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can bet on that.
—I think that is probably right.
—You would mount an MPI on a Sunday.

—I might mount one this afternoon if the honourable senator keeps this up. The position is that the Opposition believes that it is an important matter of principle that should go beyond the irritation of the moment. It is an important point of principle that we should not deprive members of the Opposition, independents and Democrat senators of that part of the program which is reserved for them for very good reasons. For that reason, I hope there will be support for the amendment. I hope also that there will be support for opposing this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Chaney's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FERTILIZERS (SUBSIDY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:TOBACCO CHARGE (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1986TOBACCO CHARGE (No. 2) AMENDMENT BILL 1986TOBACCO CHARGE (No. 3) AMENDMENT BILL 1986AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986WHEAT MARKETING AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed 11 June, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that it may be convenient for the Senate if the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 2) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 3) Amendment Bill 1986, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1986 are debated cognately.
—There being no objection, that course will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 2) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 3) Amendment Bill 1986, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1986, but I wish to speak briefly to the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill and the tobacco Bills. My colleague Senator Brownhill will speak on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill and Senator Crichton-Browne will speak on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The fertiliser Bill continues the subsidy on nitrogenous and phosphate fertilisers at the current rate. This subsidy was due to expire on 30 June 1986. I point out that this Bill was brought in after the cut-off date of 30 May, a move which the Australian Democrats instigated and the Opposition supported. However, through Government inefficiency, this Bill was not brought in in time. I must say that the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, gave notice of it in his economic and rural policy statement of 15 April. I suppose that we are in times of confession when it comes to Bills that concern us individually and, once again, I must declare a self-interest in this Bill as I would ultimately be a recipient of the nitrogenous fertiliser subsidy in particular and, to a lesser extent, the phosphate subsidy. I also point out that I was responsible for putting the dairy Bills through the other night which imposed a levy. So with these two lots of Bills I am still down the drain. The subsidy which I will get will in no way make up for the levy which I will have to pay because of the dairy Bills.

I point out that the tobacco Bills are necessary only because of a Government blunder. The Rural Industries Research Act 1985 negated the levies in the original 1955 Act. The Government, by regulation, had to declare the new levies before 1 April 1986, and it did not do so. Because of its inefficiency or because of a blunder or something else it had to bring in these new Bills to enable the levies to be declared. As I have indicated, the Opposition will be supporting all the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Collard, Leader of the National Party of Australia, has already said, the Opposition will be supporting the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Bill 1986 and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1986. These Bills are two of a series of Bills that will make significant reforms to the administration of the wheat and meat industries and the statutory marketing authorities of other farm industries. Of course, at this stage the Federal Government is continuing the good work which was first started by the previous Government to enable government business undertakings to operate in a more commercial manner. I believe that the question of accountability is essential to any business operation, whether it be private enterprise or a government department or business. I am pleased that the present Federal Government also appears to accept the concept of accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: I do need to remind the Senate of the very significant role that the wheat industry has played and will continue to play in the economic development of this country. Wheat is one of our major exports in spite of the crippling government policies which have not only affected rural Australia but also set Australia on a disastrous path to economic ruin. There can be no argument that rural industry and, more particularly wheat growers, are in severe financial difficulties. Of course, that is only the start as things will get a lot worse. The Government's own Bureau of Agricultural Economics has predicted that the real net value of rural production is likely to decline by about 40 per cent in the two years to June 1987. The average farm cash operating surplus is forecast to fall to $20,000. In 1983-84 this figure was $29,000. Average farm incomes on family farms are expected to fall to $7,000, and this figure was up around $23,000 in 1983-84. The proportion of farms assessed by the BAE as being at risk-that is, those that have negative cash margins and less than 70 per cent equity-is likely to rise to 7 per cent. In 1984-85 this figure was only 5 per cent. The rural community is under a great deal of stress and strain at the moment. This figure of 5 per cent might seem very small but it means that some 12,000 farm businesses are in real trouble.

These figures are not something that have been dreamt up by farmers' organisations; they come from the Government's own department and fly in the face of constant denials in this chamber by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) who would have us believe that there is no farm crisis. More significantly perhaps than those figures is the fact that the worst affected industry is wheat-the rural crop that provides a significant part of our export earnings. Twelve months ago the average debt across all farms was some $67,000. For the wheat industry it was $124,000. However, within that industry, 25 per cent of growers had debts greater than $155,000. That was 12 months ago. Since then expected returns from agriculture have slumped still further. Since June last year there has been an estimated fall in rural returns of 31 per cent; the estimated fall for this year is 18 per cent. Acknowledging the appalling state of agriculture and the problems it has, I support any actions by this Government that will help the industry, no matter how small they are.

The Australian Wheat Board has not had an easy time in its attempts to sell Australian wheat. The fact that it has made very important sales into new areas such as Pakistan and Colombia is to be applauded. Recent news that the United States of America has moved into the Arab Republic of North Yemen, which up till now has generally been regarded as Australia's traditional market, should be of great concern to all people in the Australian community, not just wheat growers. I do not believe that this sale of cheap American wheat will be an isolated instance. I do not share the confidence of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the assurances he was given recently in the United States when he expressed concerned over the United States farm Bill. The United States farm Bill is a major worry for Australia, and the fact that America has just sold 50,000 tonnes of wheat at a discounted price to one of our traditional markets supports that concern.

An article by John Stanton in today's Australian quotes Mr Clinton Condon as saying, on his return from a trip abroad, that Australian wheat exports will fall by some $640m in this coming year and that in the last three months the price of wheat has fallen by $US30 per tonne. The wheat growers of Australia obviously are going to be under a lot more stress and strain than even that I have instanced in the last minute or so. The article quotes Mr Condon as saying:

The European farmer has a cozy little nest and the US farmer is deeply in debt. Neither of them want their governments to stop subsidising their production and neither government is about to suddenly turn off the subsidy tap.

Australian farmers are having to compete with those people all the time. This legislation is unlikely to assist in solving the problems we have with the protectionist policies of these countries; but, provisions that will allow the Wheat Board to establish or become involved in subsidiary companies perhaps will enable Australia to improve still further its marketing skills to combat unfair competition. The legislation will also enforce more accountability by the Board to its growers, by requesting that it meet at least annually with the Executive of the Australian Wheat Growers Federation. This, too, can only be good for the industry and those involved in it.

The reforms to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation are similar to those to the Australian Wheat Board. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill will provide more autonomy to the Corporation in the lending of its reserves. Accountability to the industry will be maintained through annual plans and three- to five-year corporate plans. Both bodies will be subject to a reserve power of direction from the Minister. Both bodies will be allowed to appoint outside auditors instead of the Auditor-General. The Opposition supports the safeguards written into these Bills, which include the option for the Auditor-General to intervene, if necessary, but at the Government's expense.

As I said earlier, these Bills are only two of a number of similar Bills to apply to a range of farm industries. I think they are a step in the right direction. I wish, however, that the Government could be equally as progressive with its economic policies because, frankly, there will be no point in statutory marketing authorities such as the Wheat Board or the AMLC becoming more accountable to their respective industries if there are no industries to account to. This Government will eliminate the wheat and meat industries-indeed, all rural industries-unless it takes heed of the economic problems that now beset this great country of ours. I support what Senator Collard said in support of the Bills and I commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 2) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 3) Amendment Bill 1986, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1986 relate to various areas of primary industry. The Australian Democrats support these Bills. The only comment I wish to make is with regard to the three-year extension of the fertiliser subsidy. I believe that this is an area in which we need more imaginative policies. Fairly obviously, the extension for three years is welcome, but it does not come to grips with the overall problem. It certainly looks as though it is simply another holding operation, because the decisions that need to be taken are probably too difficult to take in the current climate. We hope that the subsequent work the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is doing and undoubtedly is doing with Senator Button in his area, and the legislation which we have discussed in this place within the last couple of weeks, will give the Government wider powers with regard to operating in this area. I hope, however, that we will soon see from the Government a decision rather than the non-decision which basically is contained in the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats support all of this legislation. The legislation has the support of the relevant industry bases and in discussions with them each of those relevant industries indicated that support. Therefore, we wish these Bills a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing cognately with the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 2) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 3) Amendment Bill 1986, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1986. I would like to refer particularly to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. It is designed to make certain reforms to the operation of the Australian Wheat Board and to make certain amendments to the Rural Industries Research Act 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: With the indulgence of the Senate, I would like to make some brief comments about the wheat industry in Australia. Whilst the changes the Government intends to make to the Australian Wheat Board, which are designed to make it operate with a more commercial outlook, are certainly commendable, they represent only a fraction of what this Government needs to do for the wheat industry generally. This Government has stood idly by while its policies have contributed to a malaise amongst Australian wheat farmers, which is even worse than that of farmers in general. Agriculture has suffered under this Government perhaps more than any other government in recent history, and the sector which has been hit the worst has been the Australian wheat farmers. With the possible exception of the rice industry, the wheat industry is the most debt ridden farming sector in the nation. In 1984-85, one in four wheat farmers was in debt in excess of $155,000, and one in eight farmers owed more than $268,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much of that is attributable to the stupid policies of Liberal governments in Western Australia?

—If Senator Button would like to articulate in precise terms what he refers to as stupid policies of the Government of Western Australia, I would be happy to debate it. The only comment I make is that there is a Labor government there, which has been in office for over three years, and I just wonder when the time arrives when it is no longer relevant for the sins of the previous Government to be referred to as being visited upon the industry.
—As here, so there; the same thing applies.

—Absolutely. The present Government has been in power now for more than three years. The levels of inflation, of interest rates and of unemployment, the continuing levels of protection and the continuing level of foreign debt are matters which must be visited upon the present Government and not the previous Government. If we are going to talk about the previous Government, as Senator Button did yesterday in Question Time, perhaps we ought to talk about the Whitlam Government. Senator Button talked about unemployment going up 16 per cent in one year. Has Senator Button forgotten about the level of unemployment in 1973-74 under Mr Whitlam? Perhaps we ought to stay within the realms of relevancy in terms of the timeframe allowed to debate this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying, one in eight wheat farmers has a debt of more than $268,000. Inevitably, it is the wheat farmers who suffer more than other sectors of the rural economy as a result of this Government's high interest rate policies. Even now, with interest rates having fallen marginally, the rates which Australian farmers have to pay for finance are hopelessly uncompetitive when compared with the rates paid by our wheat producing competitors. Yesterday the Westpac Banking Corporation quoted an interest rate of 17.5 per cent on overdrafts, regardless of the size of the overdraft. If, as is normally the case, the farmer wants a loan for a greater period the interest rate will increase. For finance over five years Westpac advises that an additional interest rate of between one and 3 per cent can be added to the overdraft figures. Just how much the premium will be ultimately will depend on the bank's assessment of the risk of the client. So the greater the risk the higher the interest rate; the greater the difficulty the farmer is in the greater the difficulty of refinancing and trading his way out.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics considers that in 1985-86 in Western Australia one in five wheat farmers is at risk. It seems reasonable to assume that many farmers will be paying around 20 per cent for long term finance from traditional banks. If that is not bad enough, we should pity the poor farmers who cannot obtain loans from banks and are forced to obtain finance from finance companies. For finance negotiated on a seasonal payment basis the Australian Guarantee Corporation, for instance, advises that it charges 22 per cent for finance for the purchase of new goods. An almost unbelievable 25 per cent is charged for second-hand goods. These interest rates mean that many farmers with debts of $100,000 are paying about $20,000 per year, or $400 a week, just in interest repayments. Considering that interest rates charged in countries which are our major trading partners, our major competitors, are more in the range of 12 per cent, the competitive disadvantage which faces farmers, thanks to the policy of this Government, becomes starkly obvious.

This Government, which has been in office now for more than three years, has failed to address the issue of domestic costs. Of the many examples I could mention, because of time I will discuss only two. In 1982-83 the average cost to the wheat industry of bulk handling authorities in each State was $12.77 per tonne of wheat. In 1985-86 the BAE projects that this cost will be $16 a tonne. The average annual increase over the three years is 8.4 per cent. The average real freight charged in 1982-83 was $13.83 per tonne. In 1985-86 this has increased to $19.10 per tonne. The average annual increase over three years in this case was 12.7 per cent. If these figures are not alarming enough by themselves, when it is considered that the inflation rate in the European Economic Community in 1985 was 5.5 per cent and in the United States of America 3.5 per cent, it becomes very obvious that Australian farmers are being made less and less competitive, or more and more uncompetitive. Not only are Australian freight rates more expensive than those in the United States and Canada but also our freight rate charges are increasing at a greater rate than those of our competitors. Rising costs and high interest rates have absolutely decimated wheat farmers' incomes. On average, on BAE figures, wheat farmers are expected to lose this year $7,500. The average income of the average wheat farmer is minus $7,500 a year, and many farmers will be losing a great deal more.

What is really frightening for the entire rural community, and for wheat farmers in particular, is that the industry is in a malaise while seasons have been relatively good. In 1983 there were record sowings of wheat. Almost 13 million hectares of wheat were planted in that year. That was a good season. The 1985-86 season had the fifth highest level of plantings on record. If reasonable seasons have occurred and the industry is still in the doldrums, how many wheat farmers will be driven off their land if this year we are again stricken by drought? In my view this potential catastrophe could already be on the way. Although, thankfully, Western Australia has received adequate rainfall in recent months, much of the eastern States has not received normal rainfall. Should this continue yields will fall. The situation confronting wheat farmers at present will pale into utter insignificance compared with the combination of high debts, high interest rates and drought. As Senator Button would know better than most, the prognosis for this season is poor. The symptoms of a drought are already with us. Levels of rainfall are considerably below average. Projections are that they will not improve. This year we may well find that we are in the grip of another major drought.

It has become fashionable recently to say that farmers just have to accept their plight, that there is nothing governments can do about the difficulties associated with world oversupply of agricultural products. Recently in a 60 Minutes television program I managed to see Dr David Clarke, an academic from the University of New South Wales. As one would expect, he indicated that farmers ought not consider that the taxpayer has to pick up the costs of enabling Australian farmers to stay on their farms despite world agricultural market problems. The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, has also indicated that in his view farmers are being unrealistic in the grievances they have brought to the Government. Displaying a total lack of understanding of farmers complaints, with his cavalier attitude to their economic well-being, he said at the New South Wales Labor Party Conference that if farmers choose certain lifestyles with attendant risks they can hardly complain about the consequences. That is not the view of a sensitive, understanding, not to say caring, Minister. The Minister either does not understand the problem or simply does not care about the problems of the rural sector.

The essential point that Mr Kerin and Dr Clarke miss is that farmers regard themselves as businessmen who have to produce their commodities at competitive prices. They are not asking the Government to treat them differently from other people. They are not asking for an entitlement to live off the taxpayer. Farmers are saying that the policies being pursued by this Government are making it harder and harder for them to compete in an already fierce world market. To use the most recent example, Mr Kerin can hardly blame the agricultural policies of the EEC or the United States for the reduction in farm income caused by the fringe benefits tax. This Hawke Government-inflicted measure will cost farmers $1,760 per year if they provide an employee with accommodation and that employee does not contribute to the rent on that property. That tax will apply even to the average wheat farmer who already has a negative income this year of $7,500. We can increase that negative income of $7,500 by $1,760 if the farmer provides a cottage rent free to his employee to attract him as part of a package which makes it possible for the farmer to employ somebody.

The fact that this Government will be supporting a 3 per cent productivity increase and a national wage increase which is expected to be of the order of 2.3 per cent is another example of rural problems being compounded by this Government. These are the fundamental issues which this Government must deal with to enable the successful marketing of Australian wheat. As I said from the outset, changes to the Australian Wheat Board to enable it to operate more effectively are welcome, but if wheat farmers are facing domestic costs which will make them more competitive it does not matter how many changes are made to the Wheat Board, the plight of the Australian wheat farmer can only worsen.

I would like to look at a number of overseas aspects of the marketing of Australian wheat. Regardless of claims by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) following his recent visit to the United States, reports of sales of 50,000 tonnes of United States wheat to North Yemen, which was referred to by Senator Brownhill earlier, clearly indicate that the United States does not regard Australian markets as being in some way exempt from the effects of its rural subsidisation policies. The Prime Minister came back glowing, bloated and euphoric about the consultations he had had with the President of the United States, saying that the United States Administration now understood the problems of the Australian rural economy and that we in no way would be affected by its policies. Already, half of our normal rice export market in Papua New Guinea has been undermined by the United States selling its rice at half our price. That loss has cost us about $20m. Also, as I said, 50,000 tonnes of United States wheat has been sold to North Yemen, which is a traditional Australian market. There are indications that we will lose other markets as a result of United States Administration policy. Yet the Prime Minister got off the aeroplane and said that our problems had been solved, that the panacea was at hand, and that the rural economy need no longer worry about United States rural policy.

It may well be that Australia must apply more effort to finding new markets. The Australian Wheat Board has indicated that the growing markets for our wheat are in the Middle East, Asia and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I agree with that 100 per cent. In the early 1970s these markets took 50 per cent of Australian wheat exports; they now take 80 per cent. There is great scope for increasing Australian wheat exports to the Asian region. China, as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, would know, is one such example which springs immediately to mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are joking.

—We provide China with two million tonnes of wheat annually and it imports seven million tonnes of wheat. The Wheat Board takes the view that that is a market into which we can make further inroads. At the same time, it ought to be recognised that only last year a Chinese wheat mission was in Egypt trying to sell wheat. As Senator Button's advisers, whom he is now consulting, will tell him, it is anticipated that by the turn of the century China will be a net exporter of food. There are many other countries in Asia which could, in my view, be a market for Australian wheat. Bangladesh, for instance, imports 2,000 kilotonnes of wheat and flour. Of this amount, Australia supplies only 262 kilotonnes. Australia supplies only 528 kilotonnes of the 1,400 kilotonnes of wheat imported by Indonesia. With the present relationship between Australia and Indonesia, I wonder what has happened to that very fragile market. I would have thought that, with the freight advantage we have and with what used to be close ties with our South East Asia region neighbour, Indonesia should have been a market for us which had the potential of being substantially increased. We supply less than half of its present import needs.

SPEECH.PARA: The USSR is another market with potential for more Australian wheat sales. It is a consumer, but it is one of the few importing countries which will not be permitted to benefit from the United States export enhancement program. Last year the USSR, as I recall-I will stand corrected, but I am certain I am right-took record sales from us. Last year it was our biggest single market. But it is a very volatile market. The year before it took less than half that figure. It certainly is a market which we ought to be cultivating and working hard to expand. To capitalise on any of these opportunities which become available we need to come back to the fundamental issue; that is, being competitive so that wheat farmers can sell their products at the low world prices which are presently prevailing but still manage to show a profit. In the Asian region this competition will be particularly fierce because Australian wheat producers will have to compete not only with the exports of other countries but also, in many instances, with the growing domestic production of wheat by those countries.

As I said last night, there is a very real glut in wheat which is likely to continue and increase. For instance, in 1965-66 India produced only 12 million tonnes of wheat; in 1986-87 it is producing 46 million tonnes and is now the fifth largest producer of wheat in the world. The interesting thing about India is that 20 years ago 80 per cent of its total production was lost to insects, rats and mice. Only 20 per cent was consumed ultimately by the people of India. They are simple matters, but the sophistication of its transport and the adequacy of its storage facilities are such now that its on-ground losses are in the region of 20 per cent. India last year had, I think, 26 million tonnes stockpiled. It is now in a position to export wheat from time to time. China has performed similarly. In 1966 it produced 26 million tonnes of wheat. It is now producing 88 million tonnes and is the world's largest wheat producer.

In addition to the continual need to be competitive for the future successful marketing of Australian wheat, Australia will undoubtedly need to look at opening more of its markets to imports of Asian-produced goods. This is something which I am quite sure Senator Button is very well aware of. This is because in addition to the normal dislike which countries display for running enormous trade imbalances with other countries there is a growing reliance on counter-trade by Asian countries. Australia will have to take greater notice of that fact. In its simplest form, counter-trade involves the bartering of one product for another rather than settling in foreign currency. This practice is particularly popular in developing countries because of their frequent shortage of foreign currency.

The Australian Wheat Board's senior marketing manager, Mr R. J. Storey, has indicated that, although counter-trading was almost insignificant or of little importance only two years ago, today its use is becoming widespread. Australia has already sold large quantities of wheat to Pakistan in return for Pakistan's cotton and fertilisers. This form of trade is already popular with China. As many of the countries in Asia experience foreign currency shortages, it is reasonable to predict that counter-trade will become an increasingly popular form of trade in our Asian markets. Australia may well have to look to further liberalisation of its trade laws so it can take more Asian products and in return sell more of its own goods, such as wheat.

The final matter I would like to raise relates to the research aspects of the Bill before the Senate. In a paper presented to a grower seminar in Western Australia conducted by the Australian Wheat Board, the Board's senior wheat quality chemist, Mr P. G. Downie, stated:

It can be categorically stated that there is overwhelming evidence that markets are becoming more `quality' conscious, and the `quality' is going to play a continuing role in the marketing of Australian wheat. This is especially true in the areas of the world where wheat consumption is increasing, that is South East Asia and the Middle East.

Inevitably such a trend in Australia's wheat markets will place extra emphasis on the Australian wheat research effort. In view of this fact it is particularly disappointing to me, to the Opposition, to the wheat industry in general and to the rural economy in general that the Government has not proceeded with the introduction of some form of plant variety rights in Australia.

I support this legislation. As I have said, I regret that we do not have plant variety rights. Australia has typically relied on a high proportion of research being carried out in the State departments of agriculture and the universities. In a report on Australia's plant breeding needs Professor Alec Lazenby indicated that nearly half of Australia's professional plant breeders are located in State agriculture departments with one-fifth in the universities. Only 12 per cent of the resources available for plant breeding are in private industry. Professor Lazenby was particularly critical of the haphazard way research was taking place across the country. He criticised State agriculture departments for lack of co-ordination. In many cases he found several State departments pursuing the same type of research independently rather than making more effective use of resources by combining their efforts. Professor Lazenby was critical of the lack of private sector research in many areas of plant breeding. He also stated:

Amongst the excellent reasons which I believe exist for encouraging the private sector investment in crop improvement in Australia, the introduction of an element of healthy competition to the public sector activities is one of the most significant.

Professor Lazenby ultimately concluded that Australia would benefit more than it would lose with the introduction of plant variety rights. If such a system of rights were introduced into Australia I believe that it would stimulate private sector research far more than the Government could hope to do by its own continuing errors. In this way I believe that the Australian agricultural industry and wheat, in particular, would be more capable of adapting to changing world market demands. As I said last night, while I accept that many of the problems facing the rural economy are outside the scope, the capacity, the competence, the ability and the framework of government policy there are many matters on which this Government ought be properly dwelling to ensure that in times of depressed market prices, in times of oversupply, we will at least be competitive so that we will be able to compete on world markets. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- I thank honourable senators for their warm and generous support of the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 2) Amendment Bill 1986, the Tobacco Charge (No. 3) Amendment Bill 1986, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 and the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1986 and their kind comments about the Government. I refer particularly to Senator Crichton-Browne who excelled himself today; he is usually much worse. This Bill and the associated Bills are important, and I commend them to the Senate.
