SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill 1986. The purpose of this Bill is to replace the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 and provide a new basis for continued Commonwealth assistance to local governments. Firstly, I start off by making it clear that I am a very strong supporter of local government. I believe that any form of government which is very close to the people is the best form of government and clearly local government is best on that basis. I give an example of the sort of thing we have not yet been able to take advantage of in this country, and I think that is a great pity. One of the worst crises for a family with young children is the death of a mother. Mothers seem to be able to cope with the loss of a breadwinner father, but working fathers are placed in a desperate situation on the death of a mother who has been caring for young children. Quite frankly, in my view, remotely controlled social services are just not able to cope with that sort of problem. From my experience as a country legal practitioner I am aware of the help which local communities are able to provide. I believe that if local communities could get some assistance from local government in providing help in crisis situations it would be a marvellous thing.

SPEECH.PARA: State governments seem to me to be unable to provide that sort of assistance because even they are too remote. In Victoria the Cain Labor Government seems to think that the State of Victoria ends at the tram terminuses. So in Victoria we have laws dreamed up by city dwellers-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—I acknowledge that Senator Button said that that is right. I agree with him. Both the Cain Labor Government and Senator Button think that the State of Victoria ends at the tram terminuses. In Victoria we have laws dreamed up by city dwellers to cover their problems in the city of Melbourne and municipality, and those laws are applied quite inappropriately to Victorian rural areas. The worst form of government, of course, is the remote centralised formal government we have here in Canberra. It is quite clear that the best action that State and Federal politicians can take for local governments is to provide them with some funds and allow them to get on with their work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill does not face up to any of the problems I have raised in regard to this area. What it does is attempt to implement some of the recommendations of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance. That inquiry produced a report of some 482 pages resulting in 50 recommendations. Not all those recommendations are addressed in this Bill. Although the Opposition will not oppose the Bill, we point out that in our view there are better ways of carrying out those recommendations. In particular in the Bill I think we can see the heavy hand of Mr Wran in the way the Federal Government has failed to address the recommendation of the Self committee for the elimination of rate pegging. That would have been a source of particular embarrassment to the New South Wales Government, of course, which uses this device for political manipulation.

As I have indicated, I believe it is far easier for the third tier of government to deliver services efficiently, because at this level local needs are known, waste is more clearly identified, and the ratepayers, who are footing the bill, are more readily able to identify the operation of Parkinson's law. This Bill seeks to abolish the guaranteed share of personal income tax introduced by the Fraser Government and replace it with a short term measure that maintains untied grants and real levels of funding for a period of two years. Since the introduction of the personal income tax sharing method of funding allocation some local governments have enjoyed windfall increases in their personal income tax collections. Unfortunately, some State governments have taken advantage of those benefits to the detriment of local government. Councils have had a number of State functions passed on to them without adequate funding for those functions. The binding of grants to the separate tiers of State and local government should stop this nonsense. We certainly hope it does.

The decision to allocate money to the States on a per capita basis may, on the surface, appear to be fair but in fact it does give preferential treatment to some States which previously have fared badly under the earlier system. In particular, I refer to my State of Victoria, which fared very badly under the Hamer-Thompson Liberal Government. I acknowledge that the proposed new system will take money away from some other States. In particular, as my Tasmanian colleagues will no doubt tell the Senate, Tasmania will suffer a fall in funding of about 11 per cent. The main problem is that this new system of allocating money to the States for distribution to local government really fails to take into account the physical size of some States; their geography; the density of their populations-in other words, the degree of their decentralisation; the stage of their economic development; or their distances from or ease of access to sources of supply. So the per capita payment will involve significantly different provisions for some States.

I point out that there are arguments both ways so far as some sort of rationalisation or per capita payment is concerned. I recognise the merit of the criticisms my Tasmanian colleagues will make in regard to the per capita equality of payment system. On the other hand, I point out to them that they choose to enjoy the unique quality of life of Tasmania and they should not complain too much-I know that they will complain-about the lack of some of the services provided in large metropolises. Of course, this argument is as old as Federation and is not resolved by this Bill.

The fact that there will be no review of the process until 1992 is another matter of some concern. It is an unnecessarily long period in which to enable the process to get settled. There will be no general response until that period has elapsed. Perhaps a more appropriate time for review would be in about five years, especially when we take into account the time lag in government inquiries.

General purpose grants have been retained with the declared purpose of correcting the so-called horizontal imbalance that allegedly exists between wealthy and poorer councils. What is a poor council? Is it an inner metropolitan council with much industry in the suburbs of a large city or is it a shire with marginal farming land? I do not know the answer to that question, and the Government fails to give any indication of how local government State grants commissions should go about making the judgment. However, we do know that Labor governments in our States have favoured inner city councils in their electorates and endeavoured to enforce amalgamations, regardless of local desires. To correct this so-called horizontal imbalance, each State is allowed to submit its own principles for approval. If it fails to do so or if the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services finds those principles unacceptable the Minister will have the right to impose guidelines of principles of his liking. The Commonwealth Grants Commission has conducted a number of dry-run allocations but the Minister has not told us what principles were used. We suggest that the Government ought to come clean and tell us about the principles and the results and let the State and local governments know what principles the Minister expects the State grants commissions to use, or at least to consider.

Pressed by the Opposition, the Government has clarified the relationship between the increases in the general purpose funds to local government and the increases in general purpose assistance to the States. We thank the Government for that. The Government has accepted the Opposition's amendment, which formalises consultation procedures between the representatives of local government associations and the relevant State Minister and the Federal Minister. That was a sound amendment and we acknowledge the Government's recognition of that. We will not be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendment concerning what future governments should do. That will be a matter for future consideration and debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill 1986. This legislation replaces the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976. As you will be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Act followed the introduction by the Whitlam Government in 1974-75 of general purpose assistance for local government. In fact, it was the initiative of a Labor government which led to today's situation, where local government in Australia receives over $500m annually in untied assistance from Canberra. In that first year, the general purpose assistance given by the Whitlam Government for local government was, I believe, of the order of $40m or $50m a year. As I have indicated, funding is now in the vicinity of $500m to $600m annually.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us this morning arises out of the report of the Government's National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, known as the Self report. That inquiry was commissioned by the Hawke Government to improve the program of general purpose financial assistance for local government-a program which has not been reviewed for a decade. Commonwealth assistance to local government in this form-untied, with no strings attached-is vital for the important tier of government in Australia. In fact, in my State, I believe that there are three local country councils which receive more in untied assistance from Canberra than they do from rate revenue. One of those councils is the Carrieton Council in the north of South Australia, which receives more assistance from Canberra than it does from its rate collections. Clearly, this assistance is vital.

The Government has accepted the findings of the Self inquiry. It has accepted the overall finding that the Commonwealth Government should maintain a program of general purpose support for local government, but that the character of the program should be changed in certain respects. Under the Act that is being replaced, grants for local government from the Commonwealth were tied to a percentage of personal income tax receipts, and one of the big disadvantages of that approach was the sheer instability in the annual rate of growth of personal income tax collections by the Commonwealth Government. For example, in 1982-83, personal income tax collections grew by some 21 per cent-a very rapid rise indeed. In the very next year, 1983-84, the growth in personal income tax collections slumped to some 8.2 per cent. Because local government finance was tied to personal income tax collection, there were very large variations in the rates of growth of funding to local councils from Canberra. That fluctuation and the high degree of instability made sound financial planning that much more difficult for this very vital level of government in Australia.

Under the new legislation there will be a base level of funding, equivalent to the level of assistance received by local government in the States and the Northern Territory in the current financial year-1985-86-plus an adjustment to bring the Northern Territory per capita payments into line with those in the States. This provides for a base figure for local government assistance of some $540m. Next financial year, as a result of this legislation, the actual payment for local government shall be the base figure, that is, the $540m, multiplied by either-I stress the word `either'-the increase in the consumer price index as a measure of price rises, or inflation in the community for that year, or the percentage change in Commonwealth Government general purpose payments to the States, whichever is the greater. Local government will get funds based on either the rate of growth in assistance to the States or the guaranteed figure as provided by changes in the consumer price index. So local government will receive a guarantee in real terms that its assistance will be protected from inflation.

At the very moment that we are debating this legislation, in another place the six State Premiers are holding discussions with the Commonwealth Government about the percentage growth in their funding for 1986-87. It is expected that they will receive a 2 per cent growth in funding in real terms. I stress that if that is the case local government could be looking at a 2 per cent real terms growth in its funding in 1986-87. For the subsequent financial year, beginning on 1 July 1987, payment calculations for local government assistance from Canberra will be made on the same basis as those for 1986-87. For all subsequent years-that is, after 1987-88-payment calculations will be based simply on the percentage change in Commonwealth general purpose assistance to the States.

I believe, and I am sure that most honourable senators believe, that these new financial arrangements will provide a stable financial base from which local government can plan with more certainty, more precision and more accuracy than it could under the previous arrangements. In making that comment, I refer to a front page story in the Adelaide Advertiser of 24 March 1986 which quoted Senator Jessop. He tried to get a fear campaign going in the community. He tried to perpetrate a fear campaign among local councils by suggesting that there would be massive cuts in local government funding in this year's Commonwealth Budget and that councils would suffer as a result. He said that as recently as 24 March. That is the sort of short term fear campaign and short term publicity grab that is carried out on a regular basis by conservative politicians in this country. Senator Jessop's claims have been exposed in the past two or three months as having absolutely no foundation.

Senator Jessop, in his comments as reported by the Adelaide Advertiser, warned that because of a tough financial situation, local government funds from Canberra could be cut and there would be a sharp rise in local council rates in South Australia. That is what he told the local community. He said that local government funding from Canberra would be cut and then he went on to say that ratepayers in local councils in South Australia should not be surprised if increases in rates followed as a result of tough budgetary measures imposed on local government by Canberra.

In the article in which he made those outrageous claims, he was quoted as being a secretary of some committee on local government. The article did not make quite clear what that committee is. It is certainly not a committee of this House. It is certainly not a committee of the joint Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. Presumably, Senator Jessop was making some partisan political comment based on his being secretary of a political committee. His claims have been completely exposed as having no foundation.

I wish to refer in this context to a letter I received dated 28 April from the Secretary-General of the Local Government Association of South Australia in which he said that the Local Government Association believed that the proposition of local government funding increases being tied to those of the States was both realistic and acceptable in the current economic climate. So the fear campaign has been exposed.

Under the measures in this Bill, each State's share of the total grant, from 1989-90 onwards, will be equal to that State's share of the Australian population. In the preceding years, the shares of each State will gradually be changed from the present relativities basis to a population basis. As a result, it seems as though the States of Victoria and South Australia will increase their share of total local government grants paid by the Commonwealth Government in Canberra. The other States will have a reduced share in total national local government funding, but there will be no reduction in money terms in the payment to any of these States from one year to the next. So they will be protected in money terms while the new shares of the national local government cake are phased in by the Commonwealth Government.

A principal objective of the new program is to provide financial assistance to those local councils most disadvantaged in their ability to raise revenue and to provide services. In other words, more of the local government funds provided by the Hawke Government in Canberra will be paid on a needs basis, according to the needs of those local councils. I believe that is a very welcome move, and it is certainly a much more equitable approach to distributing local government funding.

The States will be required to allocate funds in a way that equalises each council's ability to undertake its functions with respect to the average standard performance of other local councils in the State concerned. However, the Government recognises that local government as a whole has a restricted base from which to raise revenue to finance its expanding functions. Therefore, the Government has ensured that every council in Australia will continue to receive some assistance under the program. What that boils down to is that 30 per cent of funding under the program will be paid on a per capita basis within each State.

This year-1985-86-local government in Australia will receive some $534m from the Commonwealth Government in completely untied funds which will be made available to local government to spend as it wishes. The total level of funding, including the untied and some tied funds, amounts to $1,000m. This is a very big increase in the funds paid to local government compared with those paid in the Fraser years when the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, was Treasurer.

In conclusion, the Bill before the Senate will provide continuity and certainty for an important element of local government finance, while at the same time providing a more equitable distribution of funds for local government. The Bill will guarantee local government funding for the years ahead. It is a vitally important measure for all councils in Australia and accordingly, I believe, is a very welcome measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill. We are not particularly happy with the outcome, but we recognise that in the current economic climate and with the House of Representatives in recess there is not much that can be done about giving a better funding deal to local government. We believe that councils should have received a guaranteed 2 per cent real terms increase in untied funds, at least for two years. I shall explain shortly why that is justified and why we will not proceed with the draft amendment which we had set out to achieve that guarantee. We believe also that councils should receive a fixed proportion of all Commonwealth revenue. I will move a second reading amendment so that we can vote on that principle. I want to establish why such an expression of views by the Senate is important. The amendment is to make certain that local government gets a fixed proportion of Federal Government revenue. I understand from Senator Lewis that the Opposition will not be supporting that amendment, which disappoints me.

SPEECH.PARA: On 28 May last year Liberal Party of Australia and National Party of Australia senators assisted the Government in abandoning the commitment to provide 2 per cent of personal income tax collections in untied funds. Without that change to the personal income tax sharing legislation the Self report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance would have had a clean slate on which to carry out its assessment of the impact of revenue sharing and to make recommendations for the future. Professor Peter Self, the Chairman of the National Inquiry, said in his keynote address to the Australian Council of Local Government Associations last November:

We believe that there is a very respectable case to be made for the hypothecation of revenues for local government. It is a perfectly good case in the sense that it recognises the political weakness of local government and the small scale of local government and the need constantly for as much stability as possible.
Professor Self went on to say that the Inquiry decided that equality with the States-another thing that local government wanted-was a better option. He continued:

I suppose our reason for saying this was partly political realism. We feel that the PITS system is going to find it very difficult to survive in the tough financial climate in Canberra but also more positively because we believe it is time local government came of age and was prepared to accept the same process of periodic reviews and renegotiation of terms with Canberra as the State . . .

It is of course still policy in both the Australian Labor Party and the Opposition platforms that local government should receive 2 per cent of personal income tax revenue. Councils have accepted the sacrifice thrown upon them at the last minute. Last year New South Wales councils were nearly halfway through their financial year when the cutbacks occurred. Councils around the nation have adopted an extremely responsible attitude. They are used to difficult times and facing up to hard decisions. In New South Wales those decisions were even worse because of the infamous rate pegging operations which were set up by the Wran Government.

Councils have known also that the Department of the Treasury and Department of Finance representatives on the interdepartmental committee which examined the Self report did not resile from their antediluvian attitudes. Those departments had shown an amazing lack of awareness of the principles of equalisation when officers gave evidence before the Inquiry. There seemed to be an attitude that councils were creatures of the States and, therefore, ought to be part of a State program in some way or other. Treasury officials placed major emphasis also on statistics from the period before the introduction of personal income tax sharing. They then made various erroneous conclusions or assertions on the basis that they could not see how the general picture had changed much since that period. The members of the Inquiry commented, in part of the report, on their heavy reliance on those outdated figures. Even when the Office of Local Government was able to produce updated statistical material on aggregate financial flows, Commonwealth and State financial assistance to local government and local government's own rating effort, Treasury and Finance continued to dig in their toes.

I am pleased that the facts eventually prevailed on this occasion, but I am somewhat disturbed by the apparent intransigence of both Treasury and Finance. Indeed, at the time they appeared almost to have an ideological hangup about local government. I believe that such prejudices should be thoroughly exposed so that the proper questioning will always take place. The processes of government really need a thorough clean out. If this is the way in which Treasury goes about its financial work and planning, we really have a problem. Indeed, the assessment is hard to make because questions on notice to the Department of the Treasury are rarely dealt with in a prompt and effective manner.

The Australian Democrats believe that in this atmosphere and in the light of what has actually happened in the past year or so, it is useful for the Senate at least to address itself to the question of principle. That is why we will be moving a second reading amendment that local government, in principle, should get a fixed proportion of total Commonwealth Government revenue. The acceptance of that principle by this Senate, particularly if the Government endorses it, will put the matter on the agenda when revised arrangements for funding of local government are discussed. Total revenue is more predictable than personal income tax collections and would enable councils to plan ahead much more effectively.

Having dealt with the second reading amendment, I turn to some important findings of the Self Inquiry on the conditions under which councils are currently operating. The Shire Clerk of the Shire of Severn in New South Wales wrote to me earlier this year pointing out how astounded that council was by last May's decision by this Parliament to hack at its funding base. The Shire Clerk said:

I am sure that you will appreciate how difficult it is for a rural council such as Severn, to provide services to a population scattered at the rate of one person to every 1.8 square kilometres! Yet these people really deserve the same degree of local government services as enjoyed by people living in more closely settled areas. While it is not possible to provide exactly the same standard of local government services, the revenue assistance grants do in some measure help to equalize the standard of services.

That is what fiscal equalisation is about; giving all councils the opportunity to make their own decisions about which services are needed by the community. Local government has a rather limited revenue base and it is currently tied to rates. It needs some type of top-up if we are to avoid greater divisions in the nation between the haves and the have nots. This division is generally based on geographical areas. As Senator Lewis has said, it is very difficult to recognise the difference between a poor council in a city and a poor council out in the sticks. The word certainly went around local government circles that even real terms guarantees were under threat as long as Treasury and Finance continued to show their hostility on the interdepartmental committee. For instance, I received a telegram from the Riverland Local Government Association on 25 March 1986 drawing attention to the delay in getting a decision on the report of the National Inquiry. I seek leave to have that telegram incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The telegram read as follows-
Berri Sub SA 84/76 12.20P
Senator David Vigor
Parliament House Canberra

Riverland local government association very concerned at the delay in getting crucial federal revenue sharing legislation consequence upon the (self-report) in place for 1986 stop Rumoured cuts in these funds would spell further financial stress for the rural sector as well as those dependent municipalities and cities stop Would you please give urgent attention to using your best offices to secure a remedy to these very real concerns
Riverland Local Government Association

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Corporation of the Town of Hindmarsh in South Australia pointed out the effect of any possible cutback in funding. All of the choices such as the wind back of human services commitments or massive rate increases would be disastrous to those communities. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter setting out those problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF HINDMARSH
File No.: 215-2
Enquiries: Mr. Spencer
27th March, 1986
Senator David Vigor,
10 Pitt Street,
Adelaide, S.A. 500
Dear Sir,
Re: Self Report-National Inquiry Into Local Government Finance

I write on behalf of Council to bring to your attention the very serious ramifications to this Council should the Federal Government move to cut or abolish revenue sharing for Local Government in the following year or years.

Council's present allocation of monies received through revenue (allocated by State Grants Commission) is equivalent to 19.2% of the 1985/86 rate revenue. Should this allocation be cut or more importantly, abolished, the effect on this Council's low socio-economic community would be disastrous.
In the event of this happening, council would have to proceed with one of the following options:-
1. Reduce all existing service levels.

2. Cut out all of its human service commitments, i.e. Community Co-ordinators, Community Nurse, Welfare Officer, Library etc. to maintain its traditional services of road, rubbish, drainage, reserves etc.

3. Pull out of its agreement with the State Government to develop 25% of the Town which has been blighted by 20 years of Government inaction caused by the M.A.T.S. Plan. This would certainly make living conditions in Hindmarsh even harsher than they presently are. Council has a commitment to this scheme in excess of $300,000 p.a. which is equivalent to our Revenue Sharing grant.

4. Put up its rates accordingly to accommodate for the cuts. The worst scenario would be 19.2% plus the normal yearly rate increase which has averaged 13.19% per year since 1974. This larger than average rate increase has been necessary due to Council having to play a lone hand in redeveloping a depressed, low socio-economic area of the western region of Adelaide.

The attitude of the community of Hindmarsh to a rate in excess of 30% in one year would have serious repercussions for the Federal Government. There could be no denial as to the major reason for such an excessive rate increase in one year.
5. The Council could simply tell the State Government that it could no longer be effective without Revenue Sharing and close its doors to business.
To alleviate this Council's concern for the continuance of Revenue Sharing, Council implores that you impress on the Federal Government the necessity to at least guarantee the following four issues.-
1. Council wants the issue of Revenue Sharing for Local Government resolved to their satisfaction in this financial year.

2. Council is willing, in the current financial climate to accept a financial agreement for 3-5 years limiting the increase in the total funds for Local Government to: the previous year's allocation, plus a percentage increase equivalent to 2 p.c. above the rise in the C.P.I.

3. Council believes the funds should be allocated by the South Australian Local Government Grants Commission on an equalisation basis on criteria and against standards set at a State level in consultation with Local Government (Element B).
4. Each Council should continue to be guaranteed a per capita share of 30 p.c. of the funds available to South Australia (Element A).

Your support in obtaining the above elements on behalf of Local Government will certainly mean the continuance of good Government and community service at the vital grass roots level of our three tiered system of Government.
More than 15 million Australians are covered by the services provided by Local Government. Cutting back or abolishing Revenue Sharing will affect all of them to some degree or other.
In Hindmarsh, 8,000 people will be affected more severely than the average.
Hindmarsh Council hopes that it can count on your total support in regard to this most important matter.
Yours faithfully,
P. J. SPENCER
Town Clerk
PJS/rej

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Town Clerk also set out what councils believe would be a fair package for local government. He said that a financial agreement to cover three to five years was essential to stability. Councils believe that a 2 per cent increase in real terms is appropriate in the current climate and that each council should participate in a per capita distribution of the 30 per cent of untied funds. The Government accepted the last of these proposals. This means that every council gets some Commonwealth funds that are not tied. The local government grants commission in each State will be required to work out an equalisation entitlement for each council and to ensure that the sum allocated is not less than the per capita entitlement. If 30 per cent of the funding were distributed on a straight population basis councils must get at least that as a minimum. It is important to understand that the equalisation is not done on top of the per capita component; the per capita element is an inbuilt guarantee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats share the councils' disappointment that there was not the guaranteed 2 per cent real terms increase built into the untied funding for the next two years. The deal struck with the States last year was for a 2 per cent real terms increase for two years. The Government is apparently sticking to that this year. But what will happen the year after? The Australian Council of Local Government Associations pointed out in March of this year that about 350 jobs hinge on every $10m that councils receive. Of those jobs, about 190 would be in works programs including roads, 80 in community health and welfare and 50 in sports and recreation. At the last ACLGA conference Professor Self said:

. . . it is the case that there are a number of growing services in Australia which may be best performed at the local government level-I refer here to the human or people services. In fields of health and welfare there is now a move away from institutional care which is everywhere primarily a State responsibility to domiciliary care and local community care which in some States is now handled to an appreciable extent by local government.

He could certainly foresee a substantial growing role for local government and I support that role. This has definitely happened in the children's services and housing areas which were virtually untouched 10 years ago. I also draw to the attention of the Senate the endorsement of both Professor Ronald Henderson and Professor John Power of the role of local government in the provision of personal welfare services. This can be found in chapter 6 of the Self report. Professor Power said that municipal involvement is a necessary condition for the attainment of co-ordination and integration of community services. Professor Henderson said:

In our first poverty study . . . we found that many of the Commonwealth and State agencies were so specialist that they did not provide for the total needs of a family and there were a lot of access problems . . . The people who did seem to be making a major contribution to meeting the needs of those who needed some help were at that time a small number of . . . municipal social workers . . . They were making a real effort not to provide all the services themselves, but they knew what was available in their community from local groups, from voluntary groups as well as from statutory sources, and they could guide, direct and lead people in need of help to the help that was available. That is why I have been enthusiastically trying to encourage the growth of this sort of thing ever since.
What better recommendation could we have for those interested in social justice? Professor Henderson said that welfare funds can be spent extremely effectively at the local government level.

It was these considerations and the 2 per cent real increase offered to the States that caused the Democrats to believe that local government should have had 2 per cent real terms guarantees for two years built into this legislation. We consulted several prominent people with years of local government experience about the usefulness of an amendment requesting a guarantee that an extra 2 per cent be included. Their view was that, if the amendment passed, Treasury and Finance might use the long period between now and when the House of Representatives returns to continue their campaign of attacking and undermining the positions of councils. We have decided not to put the Opposition to the test, nor to offer the knife-wielders an opportunity to be vindictive. In relation to other matters of concern to councils across the nation, I draw the Senate's attention to an important resolution from the last ACLGA conference. It reads:

. . . that the Australian Council for Intergovernment Relations be asked to consider appropriate forms of contractual arrangements between councils and government agencies for use when negotiating joint programs.

Councils feel that they are too often taken for granted or that the Commonwealth or State governments unilaterally alter the terms of programs and force local government to carry an extra burden without any warning. The investigation proposed is the type of short sharp, practical inquiry that ACIR must get into the habit of undertaking if it is to stave off the attentions of all the people who would like to see it abolished.

The other general matter relates to local government grants commissions which recommend the allocation of the funds available to councils in each State. I have found their staff most co-operative and quite able to explain their procedures. The task may be difficult when those inquiring do not have a mathematical background. The use of average standards rather than a weighted average for the top 50 per cent of councils in various categories in New South Wales, or the use of a weighted average of the top 25 per cent in Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania, will make some differences in the individual allocations. The councils with fewest resources and greatest need will benefit from the adoption of the lower standards. Other councils with quite legitimate needs will find that their grants have dropped because the extra assistance is being channelled to those assessed as being more at disadvantage. I believe that the grants commissions should hold seminars and use all other means to let councils know just how the procedures will operate because I am not certain that they understand them. Otherwise, there will indeed be screams of anguish when the recommendations come out. I have some questions which I would like cleared up in the Committee stage. But in general the Democrats will support the Bill. We will seek undertakings from the Government in certain areas. I commend the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, Mr Uren, for the work he has done in this area in the positively quite hostile environment of cutting funds. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:

`, and the Senate recognises that local government bodies should be entitled to a fixed percentage of Federal Government revenues, and urges that this course should be followed in future legislation'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —After hearing Senator Vigor canvass the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill so thoroughly, one wonders what is left. However, I rise to speak on this Bill because there are some matters of concern to the councils in my State. While, first of all, I declare that we will support this Bill, it is nevertheless of some concern to us that some of the recommendations in the Self report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance were not implemented. Some of the ways in which the Bill will provide for future funding are obviously of more concern to some States than to others. The funding being allowed to continue at the present level in general for the whole of Australia for the next two years is good. That it will be adjusted in accordance with changes to the Federal Government assistance to the States thereafter is another matter.

SPEECH.PARA: There are problems when we look at the general distribution between the States. The main principle and the main problem is the unweighted per capita basis. This takes no account of the population density or the special problems in certain areas such as road costs, distances and that sort of thing. Western Australia, New South Wales, Queensland and particularly Tasmania all suffer a decrease in their share of the pool and they will all suffer because of their decentralised populations. The per capita method of allocation will be phased in over the next couple of years. I draw honourable senators' attention to the fact that Tasmania will suffer a reduction over those two years in its share of the funds of 10.42 per cent. In a small State with a small economy that is particularly harmful. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the percentage distribution of Commonwealth general revenue sharing grants to the States. It is based on the information contained in clause 7 of the Bill.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The loss to Tasmania of 10.42 per cent over the two years is very clearly demonstrated by that table. There is a 2.76 per cent loss to New South Wales over that period, a 0.62 per cent loss to Queensland and a 1.33 loss to Western Australia. The Northern Territory does all right. It has a plus of 3.26 per cent; South Australia has a plus of 3.14 per cent and Victoria has a plus of 4.98 per cent. So my friend and colleague, Senator Lewis, does not quite have the feeling about the allocations between the States as we Tasmanians obviously must have. The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) has claimed that changes in relativities will be made in such a way that the States will not lose but they will, in fact, lose in real terms. The Minister is quoted in the Examiner of 28 May this year in response to a telex which he had received from the State Minister, Mr Braid. He said that Tasmania would benefit by the new arrangements. He claimed that under the old scheme the State received $17.15m and that under the new scheme Tasmania would receive at least $18.3m in 1986-87 and at least $18.6m in 1987-88. Using the Minister's own figures, this is approximately a 1.6 per cent increase between 1986-87 and 1987-88. We know that inflation is currently running in the area of 9 per cent, so Tasmania suffers a considerable loss in real terms.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the President of the Municipal Association of Tasmania, Councillor L. J. Mooney, estimates that the reduction from 3.17 per cent now to 2.83 per cent over the next two years would mean a reduction of at least $1.7m in real terms. He stated:
With such a dramatic reduction of funds available to Local Government, services and facilities would have to be cut or rates increased . . .
I also quote from a statement from the Secretary of the Municipal Association of Tasmania, Mr Armsby, who said:

The adjustment necessary to rectify this loss would be of a minimal effect on the other States-$1.7m of Tasmania's $17m is a ten per cent reduction, but $1.7m to some of the other States is less than 2 per cent of their grant and would not be noticed.

That is our problem in a nutshell. The lack of regard for the different revenue raising abilities that has been referred to earlier in the debate is just not fair or equitable. The small isolated municipalities that we find in a lot of decentralised States have limited revenue raising abilities but they have very high expenses with big road costs and other areas of concern for their community which cannot be easily met.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such as climatic conditions and the like.

—As Senator Harradine says: `Such as climatic conditions and the like'. It is a matter of real concern and it is not something which can perhaps easily be understood in Canberra where the Bill is drafted and where these decisions are taken and are pretty remote, as I see all the kerbs, gutters and community facilities, from what the average provincial towns and country centres of Australia have to cope with and face.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, the Self national inquiry has made a number of worthwhile recommendations but unfortunately they have not all been incorporated in the Bill. The Self report recommended that local government should receive a long term real terms guarantee. The Federal Government has only undertaken to adjust the total pool of funds by changes in the general purpose grants to the States. Nowhere in the Bill is a real terms guarantee given at all. After 1988-89, our allocations will depend solely on our share of the Australian population. Self acknowledged that the distribution on that basis was simple and predictable, but he also recommended that consideration should be given to adjustment for functional differences between local authorities in different States and the differences in State attributes, such as revenue raising capacity and road needs. The Self report states:
The interstate distribution of funds should be reviewed before determining grants for the period 1986-87 onwards;

Prior to any such review, and after consultation with the parties involved, the Commonwealth may request the Commonwealth Grants Commission to prepare proposals for revised relativities. If no request is made to the Commonwealth Grants Commission, the suggested set of relativities will be per capita; and

In a review of relativities the Commonwealth Grants Commission, within the limits of reasonable cost, should consider the implications of differences of functional responsibility and consequences of the equalisation purpose of the grants . . . and should call for submissions from the parties involved in the review.

That was the recommendation. We find in the Bill that the Government has taken the easy way out and has gone for this strict per capita distribution. That is a matter of sadness and concern to us. The other matter of concern is that there will not be a real review until 1992. We can only hope that at this late date this inappropriate form of distribution will be replaced by a more equitable system. The reduction in the Tasmanian share of the Federal revenue has caused widespread concern in Tasmania. One of the items of concern is that we will be suffering this loss and it is going to happen over a two-year period. Many Liberals from Tasmania have said in recent times that we have a very vulnerable, very fragile economy and yet we cannot easily take the sorts of savage cuts that are forced on us without a period of adjustment. If these cuts had to take place it would have been desirable for them to have taken place over a five-year period, which is the suggestion from the Municipal Association of Tasmania. I support that suggestion. It seems to me to be very difficult for Tasmania particularly to cope with that cut over such a short period.

Another matter of concern is the level of control which the Commonwealth will exercise over the distribution within the States. It is commendable that each State be allowed to formulate its own set of principles. This allows the States to take account of their particular attributes in regard to expenditure requirements. It is of concern to me that the Minister retains the power to revoke or alter the principles if he sees fit. Another matter of concern on that same line is that no guidelines are produced for the formulation of those principles. I will read briefly from a letter I have received from the Municipal Association of Tasmania on that aspect. It states:

The role of the Commonwealth in this respect should be one of producing guidelines or principles for States Grants Commissions to interpret, bearing in mind the special needs of their own States. This is of course different from the prescription of the Bill which involves the formulating of principles by the States which are then submitted to the Federal Minister for approval.

I draw that suggestion to the attention of the Government. I also draw the Government's attention to the recommendation in the Self report concerning review. That recommendation was that interstate distribution arrangements should be reviewed from 1987 and a review of the effect of the guidelines for intrastate distribution and the level of funding in 1988 should also be carried out. The Australian Council of Local Government Associations in general terms supported the report's review schedule, but it emphasised that it was desirable to review the level of funding and its method of calculation after the trilogy commitment expired in mid-1988. I am concerned that this review will take place only after 1992. The explanatory memorandum claims that this is the earliest practicable time for a review, but I reject that claim. I do not believe that that is facing facts. The review is being put too far down the track. Too much damage can be done in that period.

In conclusion, I am afraid that as a Tasmanian I am getting to the stage of waking up in the morning and wondering what the Government has done to us today. I suppose we will wake up tomorrow and find out what it has done to us this day. I have great fears. We seem to bear the brunt of savage cuts, and now we are also faced with a reduction in real terms in the level of funding to local government. Goodness knows what our Premier is facing right now at the Premiers Conference in the other chamber. Tasmania has a fragile economy. We do not have a big population base. It is difficult for us to adjust easily to cuts, certainly over a short term. The Government should know that and it should make provision for it. There was provision in the Self report for this to happen and the Government has not taken advantage of that opportunity.

Recently the Federal Treasurer told our State Labor Opposition Leader, Mr Neil Batt, that he was not up to date with developments in the Tasmanian economy. He also said he was not aware of the very special nature of our economy. I am appalled that we should have this admission from the Federal Treasurer. When we have that sort of admission and then see that this Bill, with what would otherwise be seen as reasonable and fair provisions, contains once again this same sort of treatment of Tasmania, it looks as though the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, Mr Uren, must be in the same boat as the Treasurer. I urge him to look again at the disadvantages imposed on Tasmania by the provisions of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill 1986. Of course, the Government would have us believe that this legislation is the natural product of the report of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance and that this legislation is a reflection of the recommendations of that inquiry. Of course, that is not the case. This legislation is a compromise designed to restrict and cut expenditure. Although naturally I am in support of maintaining Commonwealth distribution of general purpose assistance grants for local government, I must say that I have grave misgivings regarding the degree of equity this Bill will promote amongst local governments and, indeed, between States. While the findings of the Self Inquiry have generally been accepted by the Government, I find its adherence to the guidelines, and its interpretation of them, disappointing.

SPEECH.PARA: When general purpose financial assistance for local government was first established under the Whitlam Government through the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 the grant was, of course, for the purpose of enabling local government bodies to function at a standard not appreciably below the level of other regional organisations or other local government bodies. In other words, it was for the purpose of general horizontal equalisation. Grants for each region were thus allocated on an individually assessed basis according to need, on a weighted per capita basis. Under that formula Western Australia and Queensland, quite naturally, were thus allocated a larger proportion of the total share in recognition of their larger size, decentralised populations and inherent costs that would be borne by them as a result of those factors.

This system of fund allocation was generally maintained when the determination of total fund size was altered by the introduction under the Fraser Government of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976. That is, the proportional allocation of local government funds to the States was still apportioned according to relativities. The only difference was that, rather than the funding going directly to the States, there was an aggregation of the total revenue that in the past had gone to individual States, which went in bulk to the States for distribution by them to the various local governments-again on the basis of need as well as on a per capita basis. So the proportional allocation of local government funds to the States was still made according to relativities. The Bill before us dispenses with the need to maintain that relativity. As a consequence, Western Australia and Queensland are to be considerably disadvantaged. In addition, Tasmania, although it is not encumbered by a factor of size, will suffer a gross reduction in its level of funding. That reduction in funding will be a great deal more than for any other State.

The broadly defined recommendation of the Self committee was that Commonwealth assistance should be maintained for local government, with the aim of continuing to promote a system in support of horizontal equalisation. The factors of need, the capacity to raise funds and the requirements of expenditure are all to be taken into consideration. In so doing, the local government authorities are compensated for disabilities associated with such deficiencies. The purpose was to ensure that there was an average standard among all local governments. Yet this Government, in accepting the findings of the Self committee that local government funding should be continued, has looked at only one half of the equation set down by the Self inquiry. It has taken the answer but it has brushed aside the reasoning.

By the year 1988-89 the distribution between the States will be solely on a per capita basis. The needs factor will be removed from the equation. From 1989-90 onwards, State shares will then be distributed exclusively on that criterion. This means that by 1988-89 Western Australia will have incurred a 1.4 per cent reduction in its share of total funds and Tasmania's share, as has been stated by Senator Newman, will be reduced by 10.4 per cent. Victoria, however, which is one of our smaller but more populous States, will receive 5 per cent more than its current share. South Australia will also receive a greater slice of the cake by way of a 3.2 per cent increase.

The legislation provides for a guarantee in real terms only for the first two years until 1987-88, while it is guaranteed that for 1988-89 the rise in local government grants will be equal to that received by the States. That means that local government from that point onwards will be reliant upon State efforts to maintain their real level of funding. That simply means that if the State does badly, local government does badly. If the State has a windfall, local government has a windfall. While there is no relationship between the two, they will be inextricably tied. Even under the assumption that payments are at least maintained in real terms for the full three years, translating the altered percentage distributions into real money terms will mean that Western Australia's share of funds will drop from approximately $50m to $49m by 1988-89. Tasmania's share will fall from $17m to $15m, and Queensland will also lose about $1m. Victoria will do very handsomely under the arrangement-it will add about $7m to its bank-and South Australia can count on an additional $2m. If a 2 per cent rise in real terms were included in the estimates, Western Australia would be as well off now as it was then, Tasmania would still lose about $1m, Victoria would gain about $8m instead of $7m and South Australia would gain $3m instead of $2m. But, of course, that will not be the case.

While the Government announced a couple of days ago that there would be a 2 per cent increase in real terms in State financial assistance grants and general health grants, it did not include the allocation of general purpose capital grants. While we will not know until today what they will be, if I can believe the front page of the Australian there will be a $1 billion cut. I am not saying that there will be a cut only in capital grants, but no doubt capital grants will be significantly affected. If we include that in the equation, it is not an increase of 2 per cent in real terms; it is considerably less. On that basis, of course, local government will be considerably worse off in the future.

As I said earlier, the purpose of local government assistance is to promote a system of equalisation between local governments which is based on maintaining a set minimum standard. It is obvious that a reduction in the total pool share allocated to my State of Western Australia will mean that those standards and community expectations will have to be considerably lowered. Equalisation, therefore, will still occur in each local government region within Western Australia, but the inequities of the system of distribution will mean that the set minimum standards uniformly will be lowered. We will have equalisation in Western Australia but it will just mean that everybody will be worse off under the present system.

Additionally, it ought to be remembered that, as the method of determining total local government funds was altered for the 1985-86 period, allocation was reduced from 2 per cent to 1.76 per cent. Last year that saved the Government about $52m. That was because it appeared under the old formula that there would be a windfall profit for the States, and that in turn would have meant a windfall profit for local government. That was cut off at the pass. The figure on which the calculations are being based has been considerably reduced. It is below that which it may have been under normal circumstances and, of course, each State has been denied its additional share.

Had the Bill maintained the original formula of the 2 per cent personal income tax sharing scheme as a basis for allocation to the States, as I have said, Western Australia would have been $5m better off in the next financial year than it will be now. Of course with the Government struggling to meet its trilogy commitments, this method of allocation is quite out of the question. Once local government authorities understand the formula and once they understand what they will receive, many of them will be lobbying the Government to create a new formula and a new base.

It is quite obvious to me that the Government has taken the recommendations of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance to suit itself. The final report recommended that a review of payments to the States should consider the differences of functional responsibilities and the consequences of the equalisation purpose of the grant. The 1986 Bill does not address itself to the differences in functional responsibilities between the States. If it had, Western Australia would have been getting a larger share in accordance with its needs, related to its physical size, its population densities and its relatively higher cost structure.

In saying that, I remind honourable senators that Western Australia occupies one-third of Australia's total land mass, it has 8.9 per cent of the total population, it has 29 per cent of the national highways, yet it receives only 10.5 per cent of Federal funding for national highways. It has 17.8 per cent of all public roads in Australia, yet it receives only 12.19 per cent of Federal funding. In spite of all that it still provides 20 per cent of Australia's export earnings. It is being denied fair, equitable and reasonable funding under the proposal that is before us.

Many Western Australian local government authorities, given their isolation and their disabilities, will be forced under this formula to lower the standards of community services which they have provided in the past. Many simply do not have the capacity to raise their revenue basis. Therefore, the cost will be carried by the entire community. That is not the purpose of equalisation. Western Australians should not have to make do with a general standard of community services which undoubtedly will be appreciably lower than that of some other States.

I wanted to touch upon two other matters. One matter has been touched on by Senator Newman; that is, the question of pegging, which has not been addressed in this legislation. I suspect that it is all too hard for the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren). It is a popular issue in New South Wales but it is not one that has been addressed in this report as it was required to be addressed. The other matter that concerns me in respect of this legislation is that there is absolute power for the Minister ultimately to impose his own guidelines or to veto State recommendations and proposals for allocations to local councils. In principle, I support the purpose of the Bill. However, its discriminatory nature against some States, particularly Western Australia and to a lesser extent Tasmania, I believe is not in the spirit for which Commonwealth general purpose assistance for local government was intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak for only one minute. I know that my intervention at this stage will not have an effect on what is to be done in the chamber today. I acknowledge that we are pressed for time and I will limit my remarks. I believe that what has been said by Senator Newman is what I, and I am sure many other senators from Tasmania, would have desired to say. The widespread concern that has been expressed by local government councillors and administrators in Tasmania is well justified. I believe that this Senate and the Government should take on board what has been said by local government in Tasmania. The Government should also take on board a further assessment that is required for revenue to flow to local government on the basis not only of per capita arrangements but also the revenue and income capacity of particular councils for their roads and other needs.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I simply say that we should do this on the basis of giving local government recognition as near-democracy. I am a great believer in the principle of subsidiarity-namely, that power should reside with the smallest group that is capable of efficiently performing the functions for which the power is required, so that those over whom the power is exercised have closer, more direct control over those who exercise the power. In that way we will have near-democracy in Australia. But if we starve these groups of the funds they deserve, we will not be acting in the interests of democracy in this country. I believe that the Government probably understands that and I would like the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) to give the matter consideration and pass it on to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Harradine's concerns that the purest and best form of democracy is in fact when the smallest sensible unit has power. I wonder what his views are about Tasmania with our 40-plus local government units in a population of 450,000. I wonder whether he, like me, considers that some of those groups are a little small. Perhaps if we put our house in order in Tasmania we could assist the situation a bit.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate and their support for the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986. The Government has been criticised, particularly by Senator Vigor, for breaking away from the previous commitment to a constant share of personal income tax receipts. We make no bones about what we are doing in this Bill. We are moving towards the provision of general purpose financial assistance, rather than general revenue sharing. In doing this we have accepted the main recommendation of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, which was to provide a program of general purpose financial assistance to local government on terms at least as favourable as the general purpose assistance to the States. In doing this, we are introducing stability and certainty into the arrangements compared with the volatile system of changes in the levels of funds which occurred previously. That volatility also had an effect on the budgeting process of the Federal Government and was a problem for previous governments as well as this one. That problem was recognised by the Self Inquiry.

I remind honourable senators that before 1974 when a Labor government introduced Commonwealth funding to local government, there was no such provision of funds. I remember well the criticisms that we received at the time from the Opposition benches for taking such a step. However, we believe that local government deserves the assistance and we have demonstrated our commitment by increasing the tied and untied assistance to local government by about 57 per cent to more than $1 billion, by establishing the first portfolio with specific local government responsibility, by establishing a local government development program aimed at strengthening the capacity of local government to undertake its functions and improving co-operation within local government, by introducing the national awards scheme for innovation for local government and by consulting local government nationally on economic issues--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it right that Ministers are allowed to read their speeches?

—Yes, they are actually. Senator Lewis knows that I would like to have that standing order changed because I think senators should be able to read their speeches. We have continued to pursue constitutional recognition for local government and I believe that in those ways we have demonstrated our commitment to local government.

SPEECH.PARA: I can accept that Senator Newman, Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Harradine have a duty as senators for their States to come here and make special pleadings for those States. I have no argument with that. However, I think that there has been a general failure to recognise that the Self Inquiry recommended that the distribution between States contained in the present personal income tax sharing legislation should be changed. The Inquiry felt that if it was not practical for the Commonwealth Grants Commission to undertake a study and recommend new State relativities, those relativities should revert to a simple per capita distribution. The Commonwealth Grants Commission has been consulted in this matter and has indicated its belief that the results of such a review would not justify the time and effort involved. In a review conducted in 1979, the Grants Commission concluded that a per capita distribution should be the basis on which interstate distributions should occur because of simplicity and predictability. It also considered per capita distributions to be consistent with the equalisation principle. This does not support the view that the Government has ignored equalisation principles in setting State relativities. We have accepted the view that State shares in this area should be based on population shares.

I remind honourable senators that my own State of Tasmania, under other funding arrangements, receives considerably more per capita than any other State. When talking to local councils in Tasmania and to people at the Municipal Association dinner in Launceston a couple of weeks ago, I was impressed with the fact that although of course no council in Tasmania likes to have its revenue cut, there was a general recognition that this was inevitable in this particular area. There was general appreciation of the fact that we accept that changes which occur need to be given time to adjust, that the councils have the capacity to predict for planning purposes what those changes will be and for that reason we have incorporated into the legislation this gradual phasing of State relativities towards the actual population distributions by 1989-90. It is expected that this phasing will avoid the possibility of any State having a reduction in funding from one year to the next. There is a general acceptance by those eminently practical people who serve in local government in Tasmania that this change was inevitable. Of course they do not like it, of course they have made their very reasonable protests and of course honourable senators who represent them here have also made very reasonable contributions to this debate, pointing out the difficulties.

I remind honourable senators that it is inconsistent to stand up in this place and advocate huge cuts in government expenditure all over the place, but at the same time stand up, as Senator Crichton-Browne has done, and say: `We want cuts in government expenditure but not in my State or my local government areas-no way'. I have done that too. We have all done that sort of thing. I think that the new system is fair and particularly predictable. I will pass Senator Harradine's concerns on to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) who, I believe, has the same view as Senator Harradine. I thank honourable senators and urge an early passage of this legislation.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Vigor's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have several short questions on which I seek clarification from the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes). In respect of clause 6, I would like some indication from the Government as to what items will be covered under the item `identified health grants', referred to in sub-section (5).
—`Identified health grants' are grants which were previously paid to the States under the hospital cost sharing agreements as well as payments for the community health and school dental programs.

—Clause 7 indicates just what proportion of the general revenue funding is to go to each State. The Government has adopted a smooth phasing-in of the adjustment of relativities on a strict per capita basis. Victoria, South Australia and the Northern Territory will pick up a slightly larger share as a result. The interesting point is that nowhere in the Bill does it say when the money is to be paid to the States for passing on to councils. There is also no statement that the money will be forwarded in one lump sum. I ask the Minister for an assurance that the transfer will be in one lump sum and I also ask for some type of statement as to when we can expect this transfer to take place.

—The payment arrangements will be similar to those in 1985-86, that is, one lump sum payment, possibly followed by a small adjustment later in the year. The notification by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of the estimated factor to the States is required to occur before 31 August. I refer to clause 5 of the legislation. This triggers the payment process which occurs in late September or early October, depending on how quickly the States submit the proposed allocation of funds between councils.

—I have two questions on clause 8. If there is an underpayment to the States in a particular year, will the catch-up paid by the Commonwealth be distributed as part of the overall funding for the following year or will there be some other type of method of distribution? Secondly, if the estimated factor proves too large and the States have to pay some money back, will that amount be subtracted from the pool available to councils in the following year or will councils have to make a special payment back to the States?

—Senator Vigor asked when, if the Commonwealth underpays the States, the catch-up will be made. It will be made within the payment of the following year. Clause 8 (3) makes that clear. If the Commonwealth's initial payment is too great, clause 11 (a) requires a State to pay each local government its full allocation for the year. It is up to the State to determine whether and how it recoups the overpayment. It is not up to the Commonwealth.

—My last set of questions deals with clause 9, particularly sub-clauses (2), (10) and (11). In sub-clause (2) (b), there is reference to `a standard not lower than the average standard of other local governing bodies in the State'. Is it the Government's intention to stop the local government grants commissions doing separate sums for different categories of councils, as happens now in some States? Is `average' in the clause to be taken in the strict sense of mean values? Could it also be interpreted as median values; or is there some other sort of weighting which would be applied in these cases? Let me point out the reason for this question. We have problems if we start to include very large councils such as Adelaide City Council in amongst all the councils in South Australia. That is why I am asking this question. What is the significance of 1 July 1991 in sub-clauses (10) and (11) and what do those sub-clauses allow to happen in fact beyond what is allowed in sub-clauses (1) to (9)? I really fail to understand what sub-clauses (10) and (11) add and it would be nice for the Minister to give us some enlightenment on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try. The word `average' in clause 9 is a matter which will be clarified and has to be clarified in the principles that are to be developed by each State and approved by the Commonwealth Minister. As Senator Vigor implied, I think, we are geographically and demographically a diverse country, even when comparing States, and the principles in each State, because of the different nature of local government, will also vary. That is a matter that has to be determined in each State and by each State.

SPEECH.PARA: He asked what is the significance of 1 July 1991 in sub-clauses (10) and (2) of clause 9 and what do these sub-clauses allow to happen beyond what is allowed by sub-clauses (1) to (9). The date sets the maximum time by which the principles under clause 9 are to come into effect. In other words, it stipulates the length of the phasing-in period. The drafting may not be clear, as drafting is often not clear to people like me, but that is the purpose of it, and I am assured that that is what happens.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:
That the order relating to the luncheon suspension of the sitting this day be varied to enable the Senate to sit between 12.45 p.m. and 2 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE (INTERIM PROTECTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Amendment Bill. It is one of those very brief pieces of legislation contained on a single sheet of printed paper and it seeks only to repeal section 33 of the principal Act. It is unusual because the principal Act is named as an interim protection Act precisely because it was offered to us as an interim Act to fill a gap and to offer immediate protection. It contained a sunset clause which meant that it would cease to have effect, I believe, on 25 June or some date close to that. What the Government has done is not seek to extend the sunset clause or to renew it but to repeal it, and this amendment, if it passed, would convert the original Act, which was an interim Act, into a permanent Act, an Act which would continue to operate as an Act without a sunset clause for ever.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition opposed the principal Act when it came before the Parliament as a Bill, and we opposed it for reasons which we set out then at length and which are valid today. With the Government simply seeking to repeal the sunset clause and to make this into a permanent piece of legislation, our opposition continues, and the Opposition will continue to oppose the legislation for the reasons we set out last time. Those reasons include sloppy drafting in the legislation, unnecessary encroachment upon State responsibilities-and I will come back to that in the Committee stage-unfettered discretions which were given to the Minister, and the potential for frivolous and vexatious claims to be made pursuant to the Act. The Opposition makes clear now, as we did previously, that we do not oppose the protection of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage. We do not oppose, as it were, the purposes which lie behind legislation of this kind, but we are not happy with the approach that the Government has taken to the legislation, and this of course is one of the valid roles of opposition. We think the Government, in pursuit of what might be a reasonable end, has used means which are inappropriate.

We are concerned still by the substantial matters which led us to oppose this legislation in the first place. One of the most important objections is, of course, that it seeks to override legislation in the States which already seeks to protect Aboriginal heritage. This has been pointed out by State Premiers and, I believe, Western Australian Ministers who say that they already have in their States legislation which seeks to protect Aboriginal heritage and which will be overriden by this Act. I refer to section 9 of the principal Act which contains provisions which we believe give the Minister enormous power to make declarations which would override State or Territory legislation.

We will be moving in the Committee stage some amendments-if we are unsuccessful in opposing the second reading of the Bill-which would seek to make what we think are more realistic arrangements for the operation of this Bill. I will be arguing these in Committee, but I might just advert to a couple of them because they are very important matters. For a start, as the Bill is drafted it seems to us that, to take an extreme case, an urban Aboriginal living in Redfern might, under section 9, be able to make an application to the Minister in relation to a heritage matter in the Kimberleys. Section 9 simply says that `where the Minister receives an application made orally or in writing by or on behalf of an Aboriginal or a group of Aboriginals' seeking certain things, the Minister may then do certain things. There is no requirement for the application made by Aboriginals to be necessarily relevant to the area about which the application is being made. We will move in the Committee stage amendments to try to tidy up some of these things.

I do not wish to hold up the Senate unduly, but I reiterate that the opposition we had to this legislation when it came in first as an interim measure remains. We understand that some of the provisions have been opposed by most of the States, by the Northern Territory, by interested industry groups including the Australian Mining Industry Council, by the National Farmers Federation, by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, by the Australian Archaeological Association and by many Aboriginal communities. Because we think that the principal Act is an inappropriate vehicle to achieve the goals, however desirable, we will oppose the removal of the sunset clause, which is the sole purpose of the Bill before the Senate. If we are unsuccessful in that, we will move amendments in the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Amendment Bill involves the continuation of the Bill we passed two years ago.
