The operation of the Act has been a major disappointment to Aboriginal people around Australia. However, in my consultations with the various communities there seems to be no option other than to support the entrenchment of this legislation. It is not so much that the communities feel that the legislation is a problem but the way in which it has been handled. It is as part of a much more general situation that this legislation has to be seen. Proposals floating around the corridors of power to amend other land rights Acts-for example, those in the Northern Territory-indicate where this Government may be heading on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have made it very clear that, minimal as the rights of Aboriginal people are, they cannot be taken away or modified. That is totally unacceptable to us. The only independent inquiry in the Northern Territory on the operation of land rights has recommended, as have all inquiries, the retention of the veto on exploration of mining rights. It is interesting to quote what Mr Justice Toohey said in his report `Seven Years On':

There are compelling economic arguments in favour of ensuring certainty for those investing and engaging in mineral exploration and development. Equally compelling are arguments based on the principle that Aboriginals should control activity on their land which could have significant economic, social and spiritual consequences. The arguments, although proceeding from different premises, are not necessarily or always in conflict. Material and other advantages can flow to those groups permitting mining on their land.

I will spell out in a little more detail a recent interesting exercise. People approach this Bill in a way that is modified greatly by what might be public opinion on this matter. I will look first at the statistics on mining exploration in Australia. Anybody who studies these will have noticed that in 1983-84 the statistics showed that money spent on mining exploration for minerals in the Northern Territory was down by a huge 60 per cent from the previous year to approximately $12m. These statistics, published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, were subsequently revised, as statistics often are, but in this case the revision was not minor. It was so major that the Bureau took the trouble to publicise the changes. The $12m in 1983-84 turned out to be twice that amount-$24m-or just 5 per cent less than in the previous year. That 5 per cent drop is significant because there was an overall 5 per cent drop in mining exploration across Australia. In other words, the drop in the Northern Territory was identical with the national drop.

I suspect that the Department involved knew that before the figures were released. A statement has been made by a senior person within the Bureau that those figures were available prior to the release of the $12m figure. This seems to be part of the general softening up of the community for a change in policy. For example, on 4 March, about three weeks before the ABS admitted its mistake, Senator Gareth Evans announced Cabinet approval of changes to the Act to which I have referred. He said that the reason was the `log-jam in the processing of exploration applications in the Northern Territory'. He went on:

There is no doubt that the present Northern Territory Land Rights Act and some of the administrative arrangements under it, have contributed significantly to the slowdown in exploration activity in the Territory in recent years, although other factors-the decline in international commodity prices, and the Labor Government's uranium policy-have been equally if not more important.

These inaccurate, possibly false, figures have had a considerable effect on Government Aboriginal land rights policy and Aboriginal rights in general and have been used by the mining companies to lobby the Government. The ABS has said that it is embarrassed over the inaccurate figures but lays the blame firmly at the door of the mining companies. As I have pointed out, a spokesman for the ABS has claimed that the anomaly was noticed before the publication of those figures, but when the Bureau checked with the mining companies who supplied the figures it was told that they were correct.

The ABS in Darwin had a different story. It said that the difference was due to anomalies of late returns from the mining companies. The implications of that one event are obvious. To back up this misinformation and its political use, parts of the Press have claimed that the vast majority of Australians do not want uniform land rights legislation or the extension of Aboriginal rights in any shape or form-part of which is included in this legislation. This has now become a bit of received wisdom around this place. This view, which rests on extraordinary evidence, threatens any political movement for justice for Aboriginals.

One of the grounds for this widespread view almost certainly is the confidential report by Australian Nationwide Opinion polls, commissioned by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and finalised in January 1985. The existence of the survey was first made public in August 1985 after the 64-page report was leaked to the Australian newspaper. Under the front page headline `Few Support Aboriginal Land Rights', the Australian concluded from the survey findings that less than one in five Australians supported the granting of land rights to Aboriginals and that 61 per cent agreed with the argument that land rights would be unfair to the non-Aboriginal population. Over the following weeks the one-in-five finding entered Australia's political myths. In September, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Clyde Holding, lamented the negative attitude of white Australians. He said:
It was found that many saw Aboriginals as a privileged group and less than 20 percent had strong feelings of support for Aboriginal people and their aspirations.

There was a widespread view that everybody should be treated equally. Although it has been largely unquestioned, there was reason for caution about the interpretation of the data, even as it was presented in the Australian newspaper. The table reproduced on the front page from the ANOP survey disclosed that only 18 per cent of the sample strongly supported land rights, but this was far from indicating that everybody else was opposed. Only 24 percent were strongly opposed. The majority-52 per cent-were, to quote from the ANOP, `intending to opposition or in favour'. That is an imprecise and incredibly confusing category if there ever was one. The ANOP saw the poll as indicating a very large middle group, not strongly committed either way. That was the correct interpretation. The Australian's headline was the subject of complaint to the Australian Press Council, which found that the headline `Few Support Aboriginal Land Rights' was misleading. I quote from the judgment of the Press Council:

In the largest group of 52 per cent is an unknown number of people who support land rights with reservations, and who cannot be dismissed, as the paper's argument goes, as people who do not support land rights. One might have thought that the striking result of the poll was that the majority of Australians did not have strong views one way or another.

What I find incredibly difficult to understand is how the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Clyde Holding, allowed a wholly negative interpretation to go unchallenged, since he has had a copy of the confidential poll longer than anyone else in this country.

The Australian chose not to report that in this poll 56 per cent of the respondents agreed with the proposition that land rights will help Aboriginals keep their culture and help the survival of the race-56 per cent, not reported. Fifty-two per cent agreed that Aboriginals should get land rights because it is important for their traditional way of life-52 per cent, not reported. Questioned on the level of assistance provided to Aboriginals by the Federal Government, 42 per cent believed that too much was provided, but a larger number, 44 per cent, thought that the existing level was about right or too little. I ask any fair person, looking at that survey as a whole, to ask: What was going on in the Australian newspaper, and what was going on in this Government that it used the survey in the way that it did to allow a type of racist operation to get going in this country immediately afterwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think that we need to change the words `land rights' and to make it `secure land tenure' or something?

—I do not believe that we should change the term `land rights' at all. That is what we are talking about. Let us go back a little over what we are talking about. For those people who last night saw the video with regard to apartheid and those people who saw the declaration today, on television, of the state of emergency in South Africa, I say let us not get too pompous in this country about how good we are and about what goes on in South Africa. If they have watched television, let them listen to this and try to work out whether this is a description of the types of things that they have been seeing on television about South Africa, or whether this is a description of what goes on in Australia. It is the latter. It is a description given by an Aboriginal woman, Helen Boyle, and I shall read it in full:

SPEECH.PARA: Every year you get the police going round causing a riot, the last one being at the Princeton Hotel. I happened to be in the middle of things that night because there was an Aboriginal band playing, one of the top Australian bands at that time, and the hotel was just packed out with Aboriginal people, and everyone was feeling very good about being there. Just before closing time, I left and as I walked from the hotel to the street where my car was parked, about eight vans pulled up. There were a lot of cops inside, and they started running out with their batons up in the air, hitting people on the head and whacking them around and putting them into the police wagons. My friend had been with me all the time, but she stayed behind in the hotel. When she put her head outside to see what all the commotion was, she got a baton smacked in her face. She lost two top teeth and the bottom teeth were forced through her bottom lip. She had to have stitches. There was another 16-year-old girl who was there who had a miscarriage, because she got whacked in the stomach with a baton. It was all provoked and instigated by the cops-some of the vans that were there had come from twenty miles away. They had a crown sergeant there, who is in charge of ten police stations, directing the whole thing, but none of them ever have their numbers on them, so you can never identify any of them. A lot of Aboriginal people were charged under the Intoxicated Persons Act. There were some Aboriginal women there who don't drink, who called the Aboriginal medical service doctor to take blood samples which, of course, came out negative. They were then threatened with charges of prostitution. So they had to accept the charge of being drunk. They were then locked up. Most of the people picked up were women, and they were sexually abused in terms of the cops putting their hands up their dresses, and their batons up their dresses and that sort of thing, and feeling them when they did the searches. Then, not content with that, the police went to Redfern housing company and ran through there; people who were asleep in their beds were arrested and charged with causing a disturbance to the peace. They ran dogs through there as well, which were going around biting everybody.
That is a description of something that happened in the major city of this country.

In terms of this legislation, we should understand that since the British invasion of this country Aboriginal people have been subjected to wholesale massacre and disease; they have been left to die; they have been inflicted with various policies of paternalism and forced assimilation. They were not even granted rights to be people until 1967. On every index-health, mortality, employment, income, housing, education, welfare, and so on-they suffer appallingly in comparison with the white population. At Palm Island, in my own State of Queensland, there are 150 government houses and about 2,200 Aboriginal people. There are up to 37 people in one house. The houses are windowless and are built of asbestos. The people who are not in those houses are in shanties. The black unemployment rate on the island is 87 per cent. There are virtually no facilities, apart from the council-run beer canteen. The 315 sons and daughters of the island are taught next to nothing of their culture because they are in a State school and that is not permitted.

As far back as 1837, a British House of Commons report declared that the Aboriginal people have a `plain and sacred right to their land'. Every small gain that has been made since that time has been made at the cost of enormous effort on the part of the Aboriginal communities themselves and under a constant and mounting threat from powerful vested interests in this country that seek to overturn the small gains that are made. Australia's history has been based on the intentional and unintentional destruction of Aboriginal traditional society and culture. There have been massacres. Aboriginals have been used as slave labour. They have been pressed into slave prostitution. Six times as many Aboriginals as whites are in our prisons now, although they are only one per cent of the population. The life expectancy of Aboriginals today is 20 years less than that of whites. So the list goes on.

Then we come to this Bill-this innocuous Bill, this Bill that seeks to do nothing other than what is done for every white religious person, and that is to protect their sacred heritage. And we have whingers; and we have back-downs. Do honourable senators realise that any group of white people in this country can buy a piece of land and erect on it a church, and it instantly becomes a sacred site for the purposes of the law? Do they realise that the offence of desecration in some States can attract a sentence of 14 years in gaol? What do we have in this legislation? It is a fine of $2,000.

Will there ever come a time in this country when the white population will look at themselves and look at what is happening in South Africa, and ask: If the Aboriginal population had been in the majority in this country, would the situation in Australia be identical to the one in South Africa? What we would have to answer, if we were to answer truthfully, would be yes. We do not have beatings, we do not have murders, we do not have detentions, we do not have those types of shanty towns on that scale; but we do have the slow, purposeful, unrelenting strangulation of Aboriginal culture. It is very unfortunate that we cannot have an Aboriginal in this place to constantly remind us white Australians of these matters.

The Australian Democrats will support this Bill because we cannot do anything else. But in looking at the way it has been implemented, and at the abrogation of the responsibility which was handed to the Federal Government in the 1967 referendum, one wonders whether this Bill is not merely a drop in the ocean. I plead with the Government to look again at the decisions it made during the last election campaign and to look at its policy. It should seek to make, in this area, some of those hard decisions which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was talking about the other night. It has been well illustrated in the figures on mining and in the poll to which I have referred that there are massive forces in this country ranged against the Aboriginal people and the very little they are able to do in defending themselves. This Government has the moral and political responsibility to take up that fight. It is not a matter for States; it is a matter, as the people of Australia said, for the nation. We do not look at South Africa and say: `Is it happening in Natal, in Cape Town, or in the Transvaal?' We look at South Africa and say: `It is happening in South Africa'. I, for one, do not want people around the world looking at my country and saying: `It is all very well for you to talk, but why do you not do something yourselves?'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Amendment Bill 1986. This legislation flows from earlier legislation introduced and passed in 1984 which was at that time described to us as interim by nature. At that time, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is an interim measure which will be replaced by more comprehensive legislation dealing with Aboriginal land rights and heritage protection.
He went on to say:
As evidence of the Government's intention to legislate more comprehensively, the Bill before the House is expressed to have effect for no more than two years from the date of its commencement.

In other words, the original legislation was interim legislation. The Holding uniform land rights legislation was to be introduced within the two-year life of the original legislation. It was Holding de facto land rights legislation. That uniform land rights legislation has not come to pass, because, in my view, of a political judgment by the Government that it would be unpopular and politically unwise to pursue the introduction of land rights in that way. That is not to say that steps have not been made in terms of land rights in Australia, notwithstanding the hypocritical statement that was made by the Premier of Western Australia during the last State election. He said: `I will resign as Premier if land rights are introduced by a Labor government in Western Australia'. Immediately following the election, Mr Holding announced the allocation of $100m for the purpose of purchasing land. The only difference between that style of approach and the acquisition of land under a uniform land rights is the type of title. The benefits which go with the land, for all intents and purposes, are exactly the same. The intention of this legislation is to create uniform land rights. The effect of its application will be, in every practical sense, to place in the hands of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs almost unfettered power to implement unilaterally the setting aside of land exclusively for the use and benefit of Aboriginal Australians. The legislation overrides all other State legislation.

To begin to understand the extent and reach of this legislation it is useful to look first at the definitions. By definition, the area to be included in this legislation applies to all land within Australia and its external Territories and the territorial sea of Australia, and the territorial sea of our external Territories and of course the sea and the continental shelf of Australia. There are no exclusions. All land and sea is included whatever its tenure and irrespective of what title is held and by whom. Naturally, this includes pastoral land, farming land, mining land, rural land, urban land and any type of metropolitan land. One might ask what the definition is of `significant Aboriginal area'. It means an area of land in Australia or in or beneath Australian waters; water in Australia; or an area of Australian waters, being an area of particular significance to Aboriginals in accordance with Aboriginal tradition. Having learnt that `significant Aboriginal area' includes all land and water within or without exclusion over which Australia has jurisdiction, we look to see what `Aboriginal tradition' means. We are told in the 1984 Bill that `Aboriginal tradition' means:

. . . the body of traditions, observances, customs and beliefs of Aboriginals generally or of a particular community or group of Aboriginals, and includes any such traditions, observances, customs or beliefs relating to particular persons, areas, objects or relationships.

The definition is so wide that it encompasses anything that any Aboriginal has ever done for whatever reason and for whatever time. It is the breadth of those definitions which gives me the greatest anxiety about this legislation. As I said, it is de facto legislation. By those definitions, virtually any piece of land can be set aside unilaterally by the Minister. In fact, it can be as the result of a request not only in writing but also by a telephone call.

I now touch on one matter which is of some significance to me and that is the concept of the Aboriginal lifestyle prior to 1788. It was Professor Radcliff-Brown's anthropological studies that were the premise upon which the Northern Territory land rights legislation was based. Since then, a very well world-recognised anthropologist, Dr Gumbar, has disputed the findings of Professor Radcliff-Brown:
Anthropologists are really quite a cloistered bunch. They are sometimes not amenable to new ideas.

The reason I raised these matters of conflict is to demonstrate the absurdity of providing `Aboriginal tradition' with such a wide definition as to allow every real and perceived notion of the ordinary functioning of the pre-1788 Aboriginal lifestyle to be embraced when some of these rather quaint notions are the conceived notions of poor, incompetent anthropological assumptions. I quote Lesley Maynard, the anthropologist for the northern region of the National Parks and Wildlife Service in New South Wales. She gives an example from the Pilbara region of Western Australia. She says:

I have been doing some work on prehistoric rock engravings at waterholes. There are also artefacts scattered and these cover the general range of domestic occupation and even more interesting there are smooth abraded patches on the same outcrops as the engravings and these have been used for grinding seeds. As if people were carrying out very, very domestic behaviour. It's undoubtedly women who were grinding the seeds and here you have these engravings around the periphery-this is a little contradictory to a general tendency to regard rock art as religious, set aside, sacred. If there is rock art there is goodness, it must be a sacred site, a special place, a set aside place.
She concludes:
And I think that would indicate something about the role of rock art in the prehistoric culture that made it.
As Pat Vinycombe of the University of Western Australia stated:

It's important to stress that not all Aboriginal art, now or long ago, is necessarily sacred. As Lesley Maynard has found sometimes pictures have been found right next to living sites and seen to be part of everyday life, not hidden away in secret or sacred places.

I labour the question of the distinction drawn by the various anthropologists and archaeologists of the notion of what is mystic, sacred or religious or simply a drawing, doodling or evidence of a past presence to show not only how embracing the definition is, but also the wide interpretation that many experts would put on it as to what represents tradition within the meaning of this Bill.

I do not argue with the fact that there are sites, quite sacred, that have a religious significance in nature to the Aboriginal community, but I do argue that we must clearly understand, as much as we pretend to understand, the lifestyle, the cultural activities and the things of religious significance of the Aboriginal community prior to 1788. It is an evolving understanding, an evolving knowledge, and we ought not set in concrete our definitions and our beliefs of what is intrinsic, and what was intrinsic to the Aboriginal community prior to 1788. For that reason, as I said in 1984, I have grave reservations about the legislation. In my view this legislation provides for de facto land rights and its extent, its reach, goes far beyond that given as its reason for being in the second reading speech. In my view it is a substitute by Clyde Holding for his uniform land rights which he was unable to have passed through his Caucus or through the Cabinet. It is with a great deal of reservation that I see this legislation now to be no longer an interim measure, as it was in 1984. Now the sunset provision, section 33, is to be removed; the legislation will now become permanent on the statute books. In my view a great many areas in this legislation ought at least be amended if it is to have the function claimed by the Minister to be its purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. I understand that Senator Peter Baume has indicated the Opposition's opposition to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Amendment Bill. I understand some of the points he made. He sought clarification on who can make an application. I understand that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has undertaken to consult with the Aboriginal people who have traditional affiliations in this area. He talked about overriding the States but it is my information that Premier Burke, whose State I suppose has had the most difficulty in this area, said in a letter to the Minister on 11 April that there is no reason at all why the respective State and Federal agencies cannot co-operate under their respective pieces of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne expressed his well-known and often expressed opposition to this sort of legislation. We do not accept at all that it is land rights in disguise. Any declaration in this area is subject to parliamentary scrutiny. Declarations do not affect the root title. Compensation is payable to a landholder whose rights are adversely affected. To suggest that we tried to freeze Aboriginal tradition in pre-1788 days is nonsense. But I understand Senator Crichton-Browne's strong objection, and I am aware that nothing I say will make any difference to it. I thank honourable senators for their contribution.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Amendment Bill 1986 is a very simple Bill and the amendments which have been drawn by the Opposition are listed as just one large amendment. It would not be my intention to move the whole of the amendment which has been circulated but to move initially that proposed new clause 3a be inserted and subsequently move amendments to each of the clauses in order to keep the debate in good order. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, after clause 3, insert the following new clause:
`Interpretation
`3a. Section 3 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after the definition of `Federal Court' in sub-section (1) the following definition:

`` `interested Aboriginal' or `interested group of Aboriginals' means, in relation to a significant Aboriginal area, an Aboriginal or a group of Aboriginals, as the case may be, to whom that area is of particular significance in accordance with Aboriginal tradition;''.

The purpose of our first amendment is to introduce the definition of an interested Aboriginal or an interested group of Aboriginals into the principal Act. We do this with the genuine intention of trying to assist with the operation of this legislation and to achieve what we think is the Government's aim and in so doing to hose down what we think are some of the concerns in the community about the way in which the Act might operate. We would envisage that such an Aboriginal, or group of Aboriginals, as we would seek to have included in our definition would be people who have a special interest in an area because it is of particular significance to them in accordance with Aboriginal tradition. For example, if there were an area of heritage in the Kimberleys, as I have mentioned, we would want someone who had some interest in that area to be the kind of person who could take action under this legislation.

This amendment ties in with amendments we intend to move later particularly in relation to section 9 (1) (b) of the principal Act to require an applicant under that sub-section to be an interested Aboriginal or to be part of an interested group of Aboriginals for the purpose of making an application. We believe that the making of emergency declarations as envisaged under section 9 of the principal Act should be made only where the applicant is an interested Aboriginal or an interested group of Aboriginals. Otherwise we are concerned that this power might give rise to frivolous or vexatious claims.

I remind honourable senators that under the operation of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 there was an unintended consequence when an Aboriginal community acquired a property known as Beetaloo. Another group of Aboriginals immediately made a claim for that property under the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act. That claim which was made on Beetaloo would have had the effect of depriving the Aboriginal leaseholder of his interest. We are trying to make sure that those who make applications under this legislation will be people who have some interest in the heritage. I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate that we are not terribly keen to see, for example, an urban Aboriginal from Redfern, who might be a member of an Aboriginal legal service and who has no association with a Western Australian heritage area, being the person making an application under section 9 of the principal Act. However, that is precisely what could happen as the Act is presently written. Unless the definition of an interested Aboriginal or interested group of Aboriginals is included in the legislation this situation will continue. We believe that an emergency declaration, such as that provided under the principal Act, is a very powerful instrument and that it should be able to be used only in appropriate and limited circumstances. We think one of the limitations that should be placed on it is that those who seek emergency declarations should be those who have an interest. Other than the interest of being an Aboriginal Australian he should be an Aboriginal Australian who has a particular interest in the area or in the heritage which is the subject of the application.

Our experience in the Northern Territory has certainly indicated that there are interested Aboriginals for most areas of heritage or most objects which we could identify. I do not think any claims under the Land Rights Act have failed because people who are interested under the quite tightly drawn provisions of the Northern Territory Act cannot be found. We think it is reasonable to ask that those are the people who make a complaint if they wish to activate section 9 of the principal Act. For those reasons I ask for support for what we have put forward as a reasonable and reasoned definition to be added to the principal Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept the amendment moved by Senator Baume. I think the Opposition is drawing a very long bow when it raised the possibility of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) or any other Minister not consulting with such Aboriginal groups as those which Senator Baume referred to in his amendment. He has given an undertaking to do so but I think it is a bit ludicrous to give the example he did that a Minister would make a declaration on an application by someone from the Redfern Aboriginal Legal Service about an area in Western Australia without consulting with the Aboriginal groups which are interested parties, as I think the definition that Senator Baume wants put in the Act would describe them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not accept the amendment for all the reasons that Mr Holding has given in the past and the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, has given in this place. We believe that there is adequate protection in the legislation. In this case over legislation ends up not protecting anyone but results only in paralysis of action. The Minister has given undertakings and has indicated by his actions that he will consult with interested groups. I think he will continue to do so. The possibility of the hair-raising example that Senator Baume gave is not a sensible one. We cannot accept the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has said that the Government will not support the Opposition's amendment. I point out to the Minister that the legislation, as drawn, makes it perfectly possible for the kind of situation I envisage to occur. Clause 9 requires only that the Minister receive an application made orally or in writing on behalf of any Aboriginal or any group of Aboriginals. It requires only that he be satisfied that the area is a significant Aboriginal area and that it is under serious and immediate threat of injury or desecration. If the Minister is willing to give assurances that he will take the extra step of consulting with interested Aboriginals there is absolutely no logic, apart from the logic of political numbers, to indicate any reason why the Government will not accept this amendment. I understand that the Government will not accept it. I can count the same as the Minister can.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause negatived.
Proposed new clause 3b.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not seek to divide the Committee on proposed new clause 3a. I move my second amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, after clause 3, insert the following new clause:
``3b. Section 5 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section substituted:
Application of Act
``5. (1) Subject to sub-section (2), this Act extends to every external Territory.
``(2) This Act does not extend to a State or Territory unless there is in force a declaration under sub-section (3) in respect of that State or Territory.

``(3) The Minister may declare, in respect of a specified State or Territory, that he is satisfied that there is not, under the laws of that State or Territory, effective protection of significant Aboriginal areas or objects from the threat of injury or desecration.
``(4) A declaration under sub-section (3) shall be published in the Gazette.

``(5) Sections 48 (other than paragraphs (1) (a) and (b) and sub-section (2)), 49 and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply to a declaration under sub-section (3) as if in those sections references to regulations were references to declarations, references to a regulation were references to a declaration and references to repeal were references to revocation.
``(6) Declarations under sub-section (3) shall not be taken to be statutory rules within the meaning of the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903.
``(7) Section 5 of the Evidence Act 1905 applies to a declaration under sub-section (3) as that section applies to an order made by a Minister.''.

The second amendment I have moved seeks to give a Federal context to this legislation. This legislation operates in a federation made up of the States and the Commonwealth. We believe that powers in matters relating to Aboriginal Australia are co-equal and shared powers. I believe that Senator Macklin has misstated, as have many people in this place, the effects of the 1967 referendum. The referendum did not lead to the removal of State responsibility or State authority in the area of Aboriginal Australia. It merely allowed the Commonwealth to move in and act in the same area.

We wish to recognise the existence of complementary State legislation which may be equally capable of protecting Aboriginal heritage and culture as the Federal Act, which is being amended today. The Federal Act should not, in those circumstances, necessarily override a State Act or Territory Act unless the Minister makes a declaration-this is what we are seeking to do by way of our amendment-that he is not satisfied that the laws of the State or Territory provide sufficient protection. We are not trying to leave any area unprotected. However, we ask that recognition be given where protection exists under a State or Territory law. The Minister can make a declaration if he thinks the protection is not adequate. We think in that way the Federal Government would be acknowledging and giving some kind of respect to State actions and authority and to the capacity of a State to legislate in these areas. We believe that where the States have legislated, the existing State legislation should be used if it provides sufficient protection.

I can see no reason for not agreeing to this amendment. The Minister retains a complete capacity, if he so wishes, to make a declaration that State legislation is insufficient, and in that case this legislation would apply. We think some people who are centralist by nature would rather see this handled on a single national basis. We know what happened when the Australian Labor Party tried to move to institute land rights on a single national basis. All we are seeking to do here, as an earnest of good will, is to recognise that some States and Territories have, indeed, moved to protect Aboriginal heritage and, where they have such laws, those laws should continue to apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not accept this amendment because, as Senator Peter Baume knows, this legislation is a form of Commonwealth appeal under the Constitution of the Commonwealth for those who feel that they are not being effectively looked after by the States. The mere fact that there appears to be effective legislation on the statute books in the States is not enough. That legislation should be applied. If a State government has what anyone would consider respectable legislation but does not use it or does not apply it, there still should be the capacity for individuals or groups in those States to come to the Commonwealth. If a State has effective legislation and if it is providing effective protection, obviously there will not be any applications from that State. If a State has such legislation and chooses, for whatever reasons-political or ideological-not to apply it, then we believe that this legislation should apply. We think that this is in the spirit of federation. It is certainly in the spirit of the constitutional change brought about by the 1967 referendum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is desirable that we circulate the Hansard record of this debate to everyone we know in the States and let them determine, from what Senator Grimes and I have said, whether or not they agree that State interests are being adequately recognised.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause negatived.
Proposed new clause 3c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, after clause 3, insert the following new clause:
``Emergency declarations in relation to areas
``3c. Section 9 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by omitting from sub-paragraph (1) (b) (i) `and';
(b) by omitting from sub-paragraph (1) (b) (ii) `desecration,' and substituting `desecration;'; and
(c) by inserting after sub-paragraph (1) (b) (ii) the following new sub-paragraphs:
`(iii) that it would be in the public interest that he make a declaration under this sub-section,'.

Our original amendment sought to insert sub-paragraph (iii) which began with the words `that the applicant is an interested Aboriginal'. That sub-paragraph was consequential on an amendment that has been determined and there is no point in seeking to insert those words. The second limb of the original amendment is contained in what was sub-paragraph (iv). I suggest to the Clerk that sub-paragraph (iv) should now become sub-paragraph (iii). Sub-paragraph (iii) will now read:
`That it would be in the public interest that he make a declaration under this sub-section,'.

I indicate to the Committee that certain other of our amendments that have been circulated stand or fall on this amendment as well. We introduce here the concept that the Minister should give consideration to the public interest before making a declaration under section 9 (1) (b) of the principal Act. We believe that that section of the Act, which provides for emergency declarations, is, as I have said, a very powerful tool, and it should be made only where the Minister believes that it is in the public interest so to do. While the term `public interest' is somewhat vague, it appears in numerous pieces of legislation, it has been subject to judicial interpretation, and it is understood. However, putting aside the legalese and matters of judicial interpretation, people understand that what we are asking the Minister to do is to take into account the interests of the community as a whole, the interests of all the parties who might be involved, when he is making a decision as to whether or not he should issue an emergency declaration under section 9. He has to weigh the importance of the application by an Aboriginal or a group of Aboriginals with the public interest as he sees it. We believe that all the interests involved should be weighed together by the Minister before a decision is made as in some circumstances-I imagine not very often-he may wish to determine that the public interest is better served by not making the declaration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the adviser, to use a dreadful pun, that emergency declarations are in fact holding operations for 30 days. This procedure has been applied only once and that was in the case of an object that was coming up for auction. It has not been applied to areas. Certainly, the public interest comes into play after the 30 days and the following sections of the Act are used to ensure that the public interest is considered. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) does not see that an amendment is necessary in respect of an immediate emergency 30-day operation to prevent damage or something drastic happening. I believe that the Minister has administered this legislation very sensibly. I think any Minister will do the same. We do not believe that an amendment of this type is necessary in respect of the 30-day period.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause negatived.
Proposed new clause 3d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, after clause 3, insert the following new clause:
``Other declarations in relation to areas
3d. Section 10 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by omitting from sub-paragraph (1) (b) (i) ``and'';
(b) by inserting after paragraph (4) (e) the following paragraph:
``(ea) the amount of compensation which should be paid to any person whose proprietary or pecuniary interests would be adversely affected by the making of a declaration;''.

Again, parts of our original amendment have been deleted because of decisions that we have already taken. We have deleted sub-paragraphs (iii) and (iv) of our original amendment, which were consequential on amendments already disposed of. Again, this is a perfectly simple proposition. We are looking at ensuring equity for all the parties. The amendment seeks to add a new paragraph to section 10 (4) of the principal Act to give recognition of the need to provide compensation to those parties, whether Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal, who may have had their proprietary, pecuniary or other interests curtailed or abridged because of a declaration made by the Minister, whether it is a holding operation or not.

Under section 10 (4) (e) the Minister must specify the effects on the interests of those persons when making the declaration. In order to facilitate the compensation of those people for their loss at the earliest opportunity, we seek to include a new clause 3d (c) (ea) requiring the Minister to specify the amount of compensation to be paid to those people whose proprietary or pecuniary interests have been affected. I suggest that there will be people whose interests are affected. It may be decided that it is in the national interest or the public interest to make a declaration, or the Minister may simply decide anyhow to make a declaration. However, if other people have their interests adversely affected and there is a question of compensation, it is only fair that people whose property is adversely affected by the Commonwealth declaration are quickly and properly compensated for their loss. This amendment would facilitate the provision of quick and adequate compensation. For that reason, the amendment should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not accept the amendment. We believe that to put such an obligation on to, say, the consultant making the decision may well result in grave injustices. We think the legislation as it is, leaving that decision to the Federal Court, is a more effective and better way of doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause negatived.
Proposed new clause 3g.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We no longer propose to move our fifth and sixth amendments, earlier amendments having failed. I proceed now to our seventh circulated amendment, concerning the publication and commencement of declarations, and move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, after clause 3, insert the following new clause:
Publication and commencement of declarations
``3g. Section 14 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by omitting from paragraph (1) (b) `on the date of publication in the Gazette or' and substituting `not earlier than 30 days after the date of publication in the Gazette or on'; and
(b) by inserting after sub-section (2) the following sub-section:

`(2a) A notice in writing given under paragraph (2) (a) in relation to a declaration made under sub-section 10 (1) shall include a response to the matters dealt with in the report under sub-section 10 (4) in relation to the area to which that declaration applies.'.

The Opposition seeks to provide a period of 30 days within which people likely to be affected by a declaration might make representations to put their case before the declaration comes into effect. I commend that amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's response is that such an amendment in fact would highlight the area and give people 30 days to wreck it if they so decided. Therefore, we do not think it is a very wise amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause negatived.
Proposed new clause 3h.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the Opposition's eighth amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, after clause 3, insert the following new clause.
`3h. Section 16 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section substituted:
Statement of decisions of the Minister

``(16). (1) Where the Minister refuses to make a declaration under this Division, the Minister shall cause to be served on the applicant or applicants a written statement setting out his decision and his reasons for that decision, including his findings on any material questions of fact, and referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based.

``(2) A written statement under sub-section (1) in relation to a decision of the Minister refusing to make a declaration under sub-section 10 (1) shall include a response to the matters dealt with in the report under sub-section 10 (4) in relation to the area to which the application for the declaration relates.''.

The present section 16 allows the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to make what could be a very weak response to those applicants who complain about a likely injury to an Aboriginal area or object. It is typical of what we think is the unnecessary and unfettered power that this Bill proposes to give to the Minister. The Bill actually undermines ministerial accountability to the public and the Parliament by not requiring a more adequate response. Those Aboriginal applicants who take the trouble to complain about potential injury to an area or to an object deserve an adequate response from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. We do not believe it is enough for the Minister merely to be required to take what the Bill calls `reasonable steps' to notify them. We think that they require more than that.

The repeal of the present section 16 and the substitution of the Opposition's proposed new section would, in fact, strengthen the hand of genuine applicants. They would then have the full range of administrative law remedies available to them. The Minister would be obliged to give a written statement setting out his decision. He would be obliged to give his reasons for it. He would be obliged to give his findings of fact and any evidence that he had based these decisions on. He would have to give a response to the report as required under section 10 (4) of the Act. Under that proposed new section it would be much easier for the applicant to obtain a review under the provisions of administrative law and to go to court. In fact, it would empower the applicant more adequately than is provided by the present provision. It would help applicants. This is not something to help industry, miners or pastoralists. It is designed to help those who might make applications under the Act. We think it would be in their interests if it were agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We think this amendment is unnecessary. In fact, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has given reasons, detailing and fact sheets on every decision he has made. He is required to do so under the administrative law of this country as it exists now. He will continue to do so. We think that this is an unnecessary addition to the legislation and we do not support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause negatived.
Proposed new clause 3j.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the Opposition's ninth amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, after clause 3, insert the following new clause.
`Repeal of Division 2 of Part II
`3j. Division 2 of Part II of the Principal Act is repealed.

The Opposition's amendment seeks to repeal the whole of Division 2 of Part II of the principal Act. This is the Division which deals with declarations made under the Act by officers-not by the Minister-authorised by the Minister. It is a question of delegated authority. The Opposition totally rejects the concept of declarations being made by authorised officers. As I stated earlier, the declarations are very powerful instruments and should be used only in fairly limited circumstances. They should be made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I have been Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I know that there are no occasions on which I could not in an emergency make such a declaration. We think it is inappropriate that these declarations, which would be made only rarely, should be delegated on any occasion to officers. It should not be burdensome for the Minister to make that declaration personally. There will always be a Minister or an Acting Minister available, either at the end of a telephone or obtainable some other way. Modern communication is so quick and direct that I cannot understand why it is not incumbent on the Minister to make the declaration personally. We do not believe that it is appropriate to delegate this authority to officers, no matter how admirable they are. I know that the officers of the Department or Aboriginal Affairs are first rate officers; nevertheless, it is not appropriate to delegate the authority. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that it is appropriate that the declaration not exceed 48 hours. The one case in which this provision was used involved an object which was to be sold and removed from the country which we thought should not have been sold and removed. We think that the 48-hour restriction, even in these days of modern telephonic communications, is a worthwhile amendment to the Act. Quite frankly, I think that to do what Senator Baume wants to do really is a bit of a farce when we have a situation in which an Acting Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who knows nothing about the matter, would be required to okay something over the phone when it would be much better to wait within that 48 hours until the Minister, who actually knows something about the matter and who can be advised properly and sensibly, can make the final declaration.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause negatived.
Proposed new clause 3K.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the Opposition's last amendment, which seeks to insert a new section 31A to make it clear that appeals lie to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from any decisions by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for declarations made under section 10 (1) or section 12 (1):

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, after clause 3, insert the following new clause:
`3K. After section 31 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted in Part IV:
Application for review
``31A. (1) Applications may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of-
(a) a decision of the Minister under sub-section 10 (1) making or refusing to make a declaration; or
(b) a decision of the Minister under sub-section 12 (1) making or refusing to make a declaration.

``(2) Where the Minister makes a decision of a kind referred to in sub-section (1) and gives to the person or persons whose interests are affected by the decision notice in writing of the making of the decision, that notice shall include a statement that, subject to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of the decision to which the notice relates by or on behalf of the person or persons whose interests are affected by the decision.
``(3) Any failure to comply with the requirements of sub-section (2) in relation to a decision does not affect the validity of the decision.
``(4) In sub-section (1), ``decision'' has the same meaning as in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.''.'.

This amendment covers the same ground as matters I raised earlier in regard to other amendments I moved. It seeks to replace the unfettered discretions of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs with more oversight and accountability for administrative decisions that might be taken. In this case we are seeking an opportunity for those people who may be affected by decisions of the Minister, or by the Minister's failure to make a decision, to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As a declaration or the failure to make one could have serious adverse consequences for Aboriginal people, Aboriginal communities or other people affected, it is appropriate that the Tribunal ensure that the Minister act properly in making whatever decision is taken. This is the kind of administrative discretion which goes to the very heart of the setting up and operation of an administrative appeals structure. The Australian Labor Party and Labor senators have supported the administrative appeals structure very strongly. I really cannot see why they would not wish to support this amendment to ensure that the AAT is the correct agency to hear the kinds of appeals to which I have referred in this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, we think this is an unnecessary amendment. Certainly the advisers believe that this legislation does come under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Certainly it comes under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. People can find out further information under the Freedom of Information Act. In fact, declarations are subject to parliamentary scrutiny. While not accepting the amendment, I will refer the matter to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) for further comment.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) and I have nothing further to add. We wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) is one of those omnibus Bills that are brought in during most sessions of Parliament to make changes to a number of Acts. The changes are supposed to be purely administrative. It is very unfortunate, as sometimes there are a number of small errors in the changes put forward, that such a Bill should be brought forward at a time when the House of Representatives cannot be called upon to agree to sensible amendments that may be made by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, one of the matters I want to raise relates to the Public Service Act 1922. As the result of a similar mess at the end of the last session, the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill was put through this House. An amendment to improve the reporting processes, the annual reports that are required from departments and statutory bodies, was moved by me and supported by the Opposition; hence the Senate passed the amendment. The Bill then returned to the House of Representatives, which turned down the amendment because apparently the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, and the Department of Finance were not happy about having more reporting to Parliament and were not happy with some of the figures concerning details of staffing and expenditure within the Public Service being considered in this place. When the Bill came back, a tripartisan agreement was made because certain aspects of the Bill were very important. One such aspect was the Government's ill-fated Priority One program. We agreed, out of deference to the Government's enthusiasm for this program, to pass the legislation on one condition-that the Minister should include in the next statute law amendment Bill a proposal for annual reports to be referred to the Parliament through a committee.

In this Bill we have at page 47 an amendment to change the text of the Public Service Act, which at that stage was unable to be changed by the Senate. Sub-section 25 (7) currently states `approved by the Prime Minister and presented to the Parliament'. The Bill seeks to change the wording to `presented to the Parliament by the Prime Minister after approval by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts'. However, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is currently terribly overworked. The guidelines apparently are somewhere in the pipeline and likely to reach the Committee in the next couple of months after the Senate has risen.

The Joint Committee on Publications is very interested in taking over this reference. There has been tripartisan agreement amongst the members of the Committee that this should happen, that is, that the process of dealing with annual reports should be handled by the Publications Committee rather than the Public Accounts Committee. I would have, or the Government could have, put forward a simple amendment to achieve this end. But, unfortunately, the House of Representatives is not sitting so we will have to adopt a different procedure. An amendment in my name seeks to change `Joint Committee of Public Accounts' to `Joint Committee on Publications'.

There are other provisions in this Bill that should not really be in such a Bill. I refer to the provisions concerning the Audit Act. The Government has decided suddenly that a whole lot of statutory authorities will be able to be audited by auditors from the private sector. That is provided for in this Bill and there have been complaints from the Auditor-General that this will slacken the amount of perusal of those accounts by audit people and the Parliament because private or company auditors do not have the same stringent conditions imposed upon them as are required of the Auditor-General. On pages 6, 7 and 8 of the Bill there are substantive amendments to the Audit Act which I thoroughly support. They make it clear that private company auditors must follow the same types of standards as are set down for the Auditor- General. I believe this should have been the subject of a separate Bill and should have been discussed thoroughly by the Parliament. Because that provision is in this Bill, and I support it, I do not want the Bill to be held up.

So, if the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) is willing to give an undertaking, which I understand he is, that the proposal in this very small amendment concerning the reference to a committee will become government policy and will be included in the next statute law amendment Bill, which, I hope, will be brought up when we still have a chance to amend it in case there is a problem, I will not move that amendment in the Committee stage. I hope that the Minister can give us that undertaking and, thereafter, that we can move to refer consideration of those annual reports to the Publications Committee. Apart from that, the Democrats support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support for the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1986. On the understanding that the situation in respect of the Standing Committee on Publications is as Senator Vigor has described it, I am happy to give the undertaking he seeks that the legislation will be appropriately amended in the next session, presumably by the further omnibus Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill that is due during that period. I hope, on that basis, that we can proceed rapidly and expeditiously to the passage of this Bill.

Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) for his undertaking. On that understanding, we will not move the amendment which has been distributed.
