DEBATE.TITLE: FUTURES INDUSTRY BILL 1986FUTURES INDUSTRY (FEES) BILL 1986COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FUTURES INDUSTRY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am reluctant to commence debate on this rather important matter just two minutes before we commence Question Time. I wonder whether the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) would prefer me to proceed or whether we can move into Question Time. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., under sessional order, I call on questions without notice.

—Mr President, I do not know whether my failing eyesight is giving me problems. I want to ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I suppose he is on his way. We were talking over lunch about the theatre of politics so the late entrance of the Leader of the Government is welcome. I refer the Leader of the Government to today's release of the balance of payments figures for May which put the current account deficit for the 11 months of this financial year at about $13.25 billion and virtually ensure, in the absence of a remarkably good figure for the current month, that the full year result will exceed $14 billion. I remind the Minister that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, said last month that the figure of $14 billion would not be reached. In view of the likely effect that the result will have on the value of the Australian dollar, which hit a new low against other currencies only yesterday, and its implications for the economy as a whole, will the Government urgently reconsider its failure to take more decisive action to restore confidence in the Australian economy? I ask the Minister whether he agrees that the figures demand real action from the Government rather than the vague statements of intention in the Prime Minister's address to the nation, and, for example, will the Government consider, as a matter of urgency, the possibility of an early announcement of definite cuts in government expenditure?

—As one might anticipate, Senator Chaney has drawn attention to the May balance of payments figures. Those figures are in line with the average for the first four months of 1986. To that extent, they are better than the April figures. I do not want to sound too much like the late Phillip Lynch in describing them. I think it is likely, on the basis of the cumulative figures, that the $14 billion figure will be approached or exceeded. The point of the question is whether the Government will go into top gear or reverse gear--
—It has to get into gear.

—Or into any other gears which might seem to Senator Chaney to be appropriate as a result of the publication of these figures and particularly whether the Government will be announcing fiscal cuts in advance of the August Budget. I think it unlikely that we will do that. I think that answers the only specific part of the question that the honourable senator asked me.
—I gave that as an example.

—Senator Chaney said that he gave that as an example, but I do not see it as my task to conjure up all the other possible examples in response to a question of that kind. I do not hesitate to say that the situation is of continuing concern to the Government. I suspect that it is not a situation which will be redressed by any immediate measures, but it is our responsibility to consider those matters in the light of the May figures, and we will do so.

—I thank the Leader of the Government for that answer, but I ask: Does that mean that he suspects that there will be no further announcements of any changes in economic policy between now and the August Budget?
—I do not want my answer to be construed in that way. I think it unlikely; I do not say that it is impossible.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to the proposal by the Federal Office of Road Safety. Will the Minister explain what the new four-stage graduated driver licensing concept will involve? Does the Minister agree that, in the national effort to reduce the road toll, much greater emphasis must be placed on drivers acquiring road and car craft skills?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The four-stage licensing program involves the provision of a learner's licence at a much younger age-I think in New South Wales and the Northern Territory the age for acquiring the learner's licence is 16-and lengthening the learning stage. So there would be a longer learning period during which people develop driving skills and in which they are supervised by a driver with skills. The second stage extends the period during which the driver can drive without complicating factors such as late night driving, peer group pressure and alcohol, so that people will have a further restricted period of driving. Also, the restrictions are gradually removed as experience is gained. The method used is not the same in each State where it is applied. But the advantage is that it gives a longer learning period for developing simple vehicle control skills. It gives more chance to practise the more difficult skills of looking ahead and anticipating safety conditions. It gives a greater understanding of the risks involved in late night driving, peer group pressure, driving unwisely and drinking. It gives experience with social driving under an alcohol prohibition. It is believed that under these circumstances-I think it has been demonstrated under these circumstances-people are more likely as a result to continue sensible behaviour as adults.

ANSWER.PARA: Progress in introducing this program has been much faster than envisaged. A low or zero blood alcohol limit for young drivers has been implemented in all States. The Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory are now considering changes. The Federal Office of Road Safety has initiated a research project to establish the impact of the scheme and evaluate the scheme. New South Wales has reduced its learner age to 16. Victoria has a package which it will release very soon. Queensland is investigating the concept. The Western Australian and South Australian governments are interested in Federal Office of Road Safety research in these areas. Tasmania is assessing the Victorian scheme, and the Northern Territory has also reduced the licensing age to 16. Gradually, it looks as though we will have consistent laws in this country in this very important area, we will have a graduated driver licensing concept in all States and, hopefully, much better, more skilled and safer drivers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to the Government's recognition, and his own recognition, of the urgent need to encourage industries which make a significant and growing contribution to Australia's export earnings. Is the Minister aware that the gold mining industry is an industry which is rapidly increasing its contribution to Australia's export earnings and that its contribution now stands at over $600m a year and will, if its present development is not impeded, earn up to $1 billion a year in overseas earnings in the next few years? In those circumstances, will the Government remove the threat to the future development of the gold mining industry as a result of its proposed tax on the income of gold mining, and abandon the current inquiry into such a gold tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition said-I think it was in about August last year-that he would tax gold if he were Prime Minister or Treasurer. I have previously tabled that extract from the West Australian newspaper. But I do not have it with me now, so I cannot give a precise figure. For the record, it should be noted that the Leader of the Opposition has said that there should be a tax on gold and if he were running the country, there would be such a tax. The Government will not make any decisions prior to considering the Gutman report. It could be the case that full corporate taxation might stop some marginal projects from proceeding. Such an objection, of course, would not apply to a rent tax. There is no economically valid argument against a rent tax on gold; absolutely none.

ANSWER.PARA: Let it also be noted for the record who is the major beneficiary of the tax exempt status of gold. That definition needs some qualification. It is tax exempt. It is exempt from Federal taxes; it is not exempt from States taxes in any State other than Tasmania or in the Northern Territory. Gold income is already taxable, by way of State royalties, in every State except Western Australia. It is, however, totally exempt from Federal Government taxation. The major beneficiary of that total exemption from Federal Government taxation is the United States Treasury. Mines which have United States equity partners remit dividends to the United States. It is a one to one transfer of tax on income which could have been levied in Australia to the United States Treasury. Given also that virtually all, if not all, of the large mines that produce in excess of 80 per cent of the nation's gold have heavy United States equity holdings of around 50 per cent on average, it becomes apparent that something over one-third of the total revenue that would be yielded by a corporate and personal income tax on gold income is being transferred direct to the United States Treasury. If Senator Durack is concerned about current account difficulties and balance of payments problems, that is something he ought also to take into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations seen an Australian Associated Press report yesterday that the Premier of Queensland had defended his Government's administration on the question of the dramatic rise in unemployment in Queensland by attributing this to the onset of winter? If so, can the Minister respond to the Queensland Premier's claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen an AAP telex on this subject which is headed `Sir Joh blames winter for jobless upsurge in Queensland'. A few inches further down the AAP printout it is mentioned that Sir William Knox, the Leader of the Queensland Liberal Party, accused the State Government of refusing to acknowledge the depth of the economic crisis-an accusation which is endorsed by the Federal Government, by the State Opposition in Queensland and, I would have thought, by anybody who looks at the figures on the state of the Queensland economy. It is even more disturbing, I think, that the Premier wakes up one morning, discovers it is winter, and the next day he discovers that winter causes unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: The Premier's performance during the rest of the news conference did nothing to alleviate anybody's forebodings about the Premier's state of mind. Indeed, given the rapid outflux of young people of prime working age from Queensland, if the Premier does not step down soon to make way for a younger successor, there will not be anyone left in Queensland who is younger than he; they will all have gone south looking for a job because they cannot get jobs in Queensland. The Premier used to claim for a long time that his excuse for Queensland having the highest, or very close to the highest, unemployment rate in the nation was that people were moving from the south: Dole bludgers and others were moving from the south to bask in the Queensland sun. Whatever truth there may have been in that claim-I do not believe there was ever any truth in it-it is palpably untrue now, because in the last 12 months for which figures are available, more than 5,000 people in the prime working age group of 20 to 34 left Queensland to go south. So the young, fit, potential workers are voting with their feet; they are leaving Queensland and moving south.

Before the last Queensland election 14.8 per cent of the nation's jobless lived in Queensland. Now an appalling 19.9 per cent of the country's unemployed are in Queensland, notwithstanding that there is a net outward migration of people of prime working age. Queensland's share of the total labour force is 15.9 per cent and its share of the number of unemployed is 19.9 per cent. Finally, according to the AAP report, the Premier-having assured everybody that his administration was entirely blameless for the 0.6 per cent rise in unemployment in Queensland for May to 9.8 per cent, against the national trend of 7.9 per cent, and disregarding the fact that Queensland's unemployment figures have been appalling in the summer months as well-went on to say that Queensland had produced the best figures for new jobs. I do not know what the best figures were, but if best is highest, he was wrong on that as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. In an allegedly sophisticated Australia in 1986, is the Minister concerned that an extraordinarily successful and massive fear campaign based on lies, distortion and innuendo has been waged against the proposed Bill of Rights? Is it not true that the real motivation of the groups behind the campaign is to prevent the enactment of that proposed section of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill which would stop gerrymanders, particularly in places such as Queensland?
—You are attacking the Catholic Church. This is disgusting.

—Not all of the Catholic Church, just part of it. Has the Minister noted in the correspondence he has received-I have received some 25,000 letters on it-that the same kinds of people are opposed to the affirmative action legislation, the fringe benefits tax, the abolition of the free lunch, the introduction of industry-based superannuation and other social justice measures such as the liberalisation of censorship, the relaxation of abortion laws, support for single parents and in vitro fertilisation programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government shares the honourable senator's concern and distaste at the fear campaign which has been waged against the Bill of Rights and I thank him for once again demonstrating his concern for the protection and advancement of civilised community values in this country, as he has so often during his parliamentary career. The distortions have been so immense and so outrageous in what has been said about the Bill of Rights that one simply cannot attribute them to ignorance alone. How can it be ignorance for someone such as Professor Geoffrey Blainey to claim in carefully chosen words, in the same way as his earlier utterances on the immigration question-words carefully chosen to appeal to the lowest common denominator of prejudice in this country-that under the Bill of Rights any Australian can report any other Australian to the Human Rights Commission for an alleged breach of rights, when he must know that the Bill of Rights will not apply to individuals dealing with one another but only to complaints against governments or government agencies? How can it be ignorance for so many people to assert that no rights will continue to exist other than those expressly set out in the Bill, when the legislation expressly and quite unequivocally preserves such other statutory and common law rights as do exist?

ANSWER.PARA: How can allegations of Star Chamber proceedings credibly be made when precedents for the conciliation of complaints and resolution procedures of the kind almost exactly identical to those contained in this legislation have worked so well for so many citizens making so many kinds of complaints against governments through the agency of the ombudsman, the sex and race discrimination commissioners or similar machinery which operates now in most jurisdictions in Australia, with the spectacular exception, as always, of Queensland? How can it be claimed that we do not need protection for civilised rights when statute law can remove rights at any time, as is constantly being alleged by those opposite and those concerned about some legislation that passes through this and other parliaments from time to time; when the common law is either non-existent when it comes to the protection of these things, or is unavailable or ineffective to override breaches of rights made by governments through the legislature, whether in the area of criminal process, privacy, invasion of free speech or any of the other things which governments, for better or worse motivations, do from time to time?

There are a whole variety of motivations evident in those who have waged the campaign to which Senator Chipp referred. In some cases I have no doubt whatsoever that that opposition has been very genuinely motivated through some kind of fuzzy belief that the existing common law is all that we need. In some cases also the opposition is premised on a perhaps understandable cynicism that no legislative measure is likely to be particularly successful in dealing with values of this kind and their protection. Overwhelmingly I have discerned from my correspondence, and I suspect this experience has been the same for just about everyone in this chamber-certainly it has been Senator Chipp's experience-that those who have spoken out most stridently against the Bill of Rights, that is the Bjelke-Petersens, Blaineys, Katharine Wests, Ruxtons, Santamarias, Eric Butlers and, I regret to say, so many of those who sit opposite, have been motivated by an unquestionable mixture of political hostility combined with a very obvious distaste on their part for the very values the Bill of Rights is all about; fair and equal democratic procedures, free speech, assembly rights, fair treatment, fair trial for criminal suspects and in particular equality and non-discrimination for everyone in this country.

I believe that the eventual passage of this legislation is as good a test as we could possibly have of the quality of democracy in this country. There will always be those who regard the protection of these kinds of values as a lesser priority than getting the economy right or getting more dollars in their pocket, but most decent Australians, when they think about it, realise just how supremely important these values are. If we succumb to the ravages of what I described the other day as the forces of darkness-the intellectual and cultural Huns, Visigoths and Vandals of this country-and if we let the forces of the far Right call the shots--

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop attacking me.

—Whether within the Government or outside it, and if we retreat from coming to grips with these problems and find ourselves intimidated into silence, I believe, with Senator Chipp, that we will have much to hang our heads in shame about as far as future generations of Australians are concerned.

—The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs is no doubt aware of the dramatic developments in South Africa that are now occurring. Does the Minister agree that international economic sanctions are now one of the few measures left which can prevent disaster, as argued by the Eminent Persons Group? Will Australia now put more diplomatic pressure on those countries in the Commonwealth still refusing to consider sanctions as an option?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will know that the Eminent Persons Group released its report in London last night. That report is a comprehensive and very thorough account of the Group's work during the past six months. Its language is very strong, its message is very compelling and I am sure that the Government will heed both and act accordingly. It should be said that the report gives a fascinating insight into the allegedly reformed apartheid system and into the nature and underlying causes of the cycle of violence which has taken hold in South Africa during the past two years. The members of the Group undertook the task given to it by the Commonwealth heads of government to foster a process of negotiation with a view to establishing a non-racial and representative government with sensitivity, energy and no illusions about the enormity of the task before them. The extent to which the Group won the confidence of a great variety of political groups in South Africa was a remarkable achievement in an increasingly polarised society.

ANSWER.PARA: The Group's report confirms that there were at one stage grounds for optimism because the South African Government told them `categorically that it was prepared to contemplate negotiations with a completely open agenda'. In the end, however, the Group concluded that the South African Government was not yet prepared to negotiate fundamental change, to countenance the creation of genuine democratic structures, nor to face the prospect of an end to white domination and white power in the foreseeable future. Tragically, the Group was given no option but to conclude that the obduracy and intransigence of the South African Government wrecked the Commonwealth initiative and that there is no present prospect of a process of dialogue leading to the establishment of non-racial and representative government in South Africa. The Group infers that the Commonwealth should impose further measures against South Africa without specifying what they should be because, while the South African Government is concerned about the adoption of effective economic measures against it, if it is able to conclude that it will always remain protected against such measures it will continue to defer real change and the descent into violence will be accelerated.

The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, set out the Government's preliminary views on the Group's report in his statement last night. He said that Cabinet would again be considering Australia's relations with South Africa before the Commonwealth Heads of Government meet in London from 3 to 5 August to consider what further measures should be adopted. Unless there is a dramatic change before that meeting, Mr Hawke expects to take to London the view that further strong measures should be applied on a Commonwealth-wide basis.

All I can add, in specific response to Senator Foreman's question homing in on the subject of economic sanctions, is this: The Government agrees that international economic sanctions are one of the few measures available to the international community to bring pressure on the South African authorities to adopt more reasonable policies. Sanctions depend for their effectiveness on the strength of their international support. There is little point in Australia adopting unilateral measures unless these will have real impact on the South African authorities. Such international support is most appropriately expressed through the United Nations, but groups such as the Commonwealth, by virtue of their composition, have an obvious role as well. The Government is working very closely with all members of the Commonwealth to bring about a consensus on the steps that now need to be taken. It is certainly our hope that the most recent actions of the South African regime itself will convince all countries of the need for firm and united action.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — My question, which is directed to the Minister for Finance, relates to the answer given to Senator Chaney yesterday when he sought details or clarification of the Prime Minister's statement that the Government had identified in excess of $1 billion in expenditure reductions. Since we have known for three months that the Treasurer is aiming at spending cuts of at least $1.4 billion, I ask the Minister whether the Prime Minister's quoting of $1 billion was a lowering of expectations about spending cuts and, if so, is the Minister receiving the support of the Prime Minister in the Expenditure Review Committee to achieve the earlier target? Further, are any savings in payments to the States outlined at today's Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting included in the $1 billion, or are the additional to it?

—In response to the last part of the question, the Prime Minister said `in excess of $1 billion' had been identified at the time he made his address on Wednesday night, and that was inclusive of Premiers Conference savings.
—Inclusive or exclusive?

—It included those savings. The earlier part of the question was whether the figure of more than $1 billion mentioned by the Prime Minister represented a downgrading of expectations. The answer to that is no. It simply reflects the fact that the Expenditure Review Committee and the Budget processes are not completed. For example, as a result of decisions taken by the ERC yesterday and subject to these being confirmed by Cabinet of course, some $200m additional savings were achieved in the 1986-87 Budget. Those decisions made by the ERC yesterday will mean that the savings will be a figure in excess of that in the following year. The $1.4 billion target still stands, as far as I am concerned and, I believe, as far as the Treasurer and the Prime Minister are concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Can he confirm that the Commonwealth has signed an agreement with Tasmania to allow licences to be issued for the export of woodchips?

—Yes, an agreement was signed last night. It represents a significant advance in Commonwealth-State relations and will lead to the protection of National Estate values. The Prime Minister has given his commitment that all the Commonwealth's powers will be used to ensure that protection. I have a copy of the agreement with me. It is a lengthy document and, rather than trying to describe its contents, I will table it.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Why should the public have any more confidence in the Prime Minister's commitment earlier this week to argue for discounting at the next national wage case when the Government broke a similar undertaking in last year's Budget speech to press for discounting at the September 1985 wage case? In view of the fact that Mr Kelty has now joined Mr Crean in ruling out absolutely any further discounting of wages, will the Minister give a guarantee that the Government will not succumb to union pressure, as it did last year, and change its mind about pressing for discounting at the next wage case?

—Perhaps I misunderstand Senator Short's question, but it seems to contain some higher interpretative elements-if I might use that charitable description of what I believe he has done. I do not believe that the Government made a commitment as such for discounting in the September 1985 case. I believe that that was a matter that the Government agreed to negotiate under the accord. I do not think that there was any commitment which was subsequently backed away from. I doubt that very much. However, assuming that everything Senator Short says is correct for the purposes of answering his question, I emphasise that the Government will not back away from any commitments made in the Prime Minister's speech. The fact that Mr Kelty and Mr Crean are currently on record as disagreeing with the Government should upset Senator Short, because he has accused us of always agreeing with them. The fact is that their disagreement will not dissuade the Government from the course that has been announced. That is quite clear.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and arises out of the question asked earlier by Senator Foreman. In view of the recent deterioration of the situation in South Africa, including the declaration of a state of emergency on 12 June, and the South African Government's obdurate and destructive response to the work of the Commonwealth Eminent Persons Group as revealed in the Group's report, does the Government propose to take any immediate steps to demonstrate its condemnation of the actions of the South African Government and the support of Australians for the legitimate aspirations of black South Africans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government is gravely disturbed by the apparently rapidly deteriorating situation in South Africa. As a mark of its deep concern, in protest at South African Government actions and to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the Soweto uprising, the Government has decided that the Australian Embassy offices in Cape Town and Pretoria will be closed for that day-next Monday, 16 June.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government totally condemns the South African Government's actions in denying blacks the basic democratic freedoms of political expression and association. The declaration of a state of emergency and widespread crackdown on black political and community leaders would, in our view, exacerbate, not resolve, South Africa's problems. It would deepen black anger and lead to further confrontation and bloodshed. More than 1,600 people have died in political unrest in South Africa in the past 18 months. The South African Government's repressive security measures and the previous state of emergency have singularly failed to ease the township crisis or to silence legitimate black protest. It is tragic that the South African Government continues to refuse to acknowledge that apartheid is the cause of black anger and that only the dismantling of apartheid and granting political rights to the majority black population will create conditions for the restoration of stability.

The Government is deeply concerned that at a time when the international community is fostering efforts to bring about peaceful change, the South African Government has demonstrated its complete contempt for black political rights and the whole process of dialogue. For the past month, as we know, the South African Government has mounted raids against neighbouring Commonwealth countries, its security forces have behaved aggressively and provocatively in Crossroads and elsewhere, and it has resorted once again to draconian powers of arrest and detention against its black opponents, the most sweeping exercise of such powers in South Africa's post-war history. These actions have all but destroyed any prospect of a negotiated settlement in the immediate future. The South African actions came as black South Africans prepared to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the Soweto uprising on 16 June 1976. Soweto Day is the day when blacks remember those who were killed in the crack-down following protests which began in Soweto in June 1976. It should be remembered that some 600 people died in clashes with police in the weeks following the uprising.

Soweto Day is an important symbol for South African blacks in their struggle for freedom from the oppression of apartheid. The commemoration of Soweto Day occurs at a time when South Africa faces the most serious intensification of violence and repression in its history. It follows the regrettable failure, as I have already mentioned, of Commonwealth efforts for peaceful change. The anniversary of Soweto dramatically underlines the urgent necessity for an end to violence in South Africa. It is a stark reminder of the brutality and human cost of apartheid and a tragic legacy of the unwillingness of the South African authorities to learn the lessons of Sharpeville, Soweto and Uitenhage.

As a mark of protest of the South African Government's actions, as I have said, the Australian Embassy in South Africa will be officially closed on 16 June to mark Soweto Day. By its action in closing its Embassy offices, the Government expresses its support and that I believe of the majority of Australians for black South Africans in their efforts to end apartheid and gain their legitimate political rights.

Finally, the situation in South Africa over the next few days has the potential to degenerate into even worse violence and bloodshed than has already occurred. This would be a tragedy. The Australian Government hopes that it is still not too late to appeal to all sides, but particularly to the Government of South Africa, to exercise maximum restraint in an attempt to defuse the immediate crisis. Such restraint would, of course, need to be followed by the demonstration of a will to enter into genuine negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and refers to the final report by the Industries Assistance Commission on the inquiry into vegetable and vegetable products, included in which was a reduction in tariff applying on imports of navy beans, used, as no doubt all honourable senators would know, for baked beans. Is the Minister aware that the recommendation in regard to the tariff level to apply to navy beans is different from that recommended in the draft report, because in the draft report the Commission recommended that the tariff applying to navy beans be reduced from 25 per cent to a minimum of 10 per cent, but in the final report it was reduced from 25 per cent to minimum rates? Does he realise that the application of minimum tariff rates could jeopardise the future of the navy bean industry in Australia in view of its small production base, compared with major world production areas, notably North America? In conclusion, in view of the Prime Minister's suggestion that we buy Australian made and no doubt that we eat Australian grown, will the Minister please look at this decision of the IAC to reduce the tariff applied on the import of navy beans to see whether it is possible to reduce the tariff from 25 per cent to a minimum of 10 per cent, as recommended in the draft report, rather than to minimum rates as suggested in the final report?

—I am, on one occasion, grateful for the content of the question because I really was not across the navy bean business. I now regard myself as an expert, having listened to Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question. I am not aware of the reasons which the IAC gave in either its draft report or its final report for the proposed tariff on navy beans. I am asked whether the result will be the demise of the Australian navy bean industry. That is quite likely, I suppose. The only part of the question which I did not really understand-it was not as lucid as the rest-was the suggestion that the navy bean industry is dependent on volumes of scale. I would have thought the Chinese would have a very good navy bean industry on small plots, but I am not sure. I will look at the decision of IAC as appropriate in due course. I am sure the Government will take into consideration the speech the honourable senator made in the course of asking that question.
—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen a Press report in yesterday's Hobart Mercury--
—I will bet that he knows what navy beans are.

—Yes, I am sure he does. Has the Minister seen a Press report in yesterday's Hobart Mercury in which a mutual friend of ours, Mr Alan Evans, in his capacity as Secretary of the Tasmanian Public Service Association, is quoted as saying that the proportion of the Tasmanian work force employed by the State Government is 22 per cent and not 28.3 per cent as suggested by the Minister earlier this week? As this statistic is a straight matter of fact, will the Minister please explain what is the situation and will he get in touch with Mr Evans and settle the differences between them over a beer when he is next in Hobart?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would expect be doing what was suggested at the end of the question in any case, Mr President. I have not yet spoken to Mr Evans. I have perhaps been remiss in not doing that. I think he has included in his proportionate figure the self-employed persons in Tasmania. I think that that was done and that his figure is probably correct as well. My figures refer to the total employed people in both public and private employment. I think his figures probably include the self-employed as well. That does not alter the conclusion, however, that all the other State figures would have to be adjusted if the self-employed are to be counted in the ratio.

ANSWER.PARA: Although the figures would be changed, the same conclusion remains; that is, that Tasmania has a far higher proportion of both wage and salary earners and the self-employed, or of wage and salary earners alone, in State Government employment than has any other State. It is some 6 or 7 per cent higher than the lowest State figure, which, from memory, is the figure for New South Wales. On the figures that I used the other day, New South Wales's figure was something under 20 per cent and Tasmania's figure was 28.3 per cent. That was for the September quarter 1985. All of the other States fell between those ranges. From memory, the State coming closest to Tasmania had close to 26 per cent of its employed in the labour force in State Government employment.

I did not, as Mr Evans initially suggested, add Commonwealth Government and local government employees in Tasmania to the figures that I used. The figures change a bit from quarter to quarter, but the Australian Bureau of Statistics bulletin No. 6248.0, which was issued on 17 February, shows on page 6 a State Government employment figure for Tasmania of 40,400 and a total of employed wage and salary earners of 142,000, that is, 28.3 per cent. The bulletin issued on 23 April, of the same catalogue number, shows, again on page 6, a State Government employment figure of 40,100 out of a total wage and salary employed figure of 146,700. That comes out as something just under 28 per cent, but it fluctuates a bit above or below 28 per cent. It is by far the highest figure on either basis-that is, net of the self-employed or inclusive of the self-employed-of all the State figures.

That is probably one of the reasons that the Commonwealth Grants Commission-the independent body that it is, of course-decided in 1984 or early 1985 that the relativities should be changed in a way that would require $60m to be taken off Federal grants to Tasmania. The Grants Commission, a completely independent body, recognised that Tasmania had been treated too generously by the Commonwealth in the past and that $60m had to be taken off it. I note the humbuggery of Senator Townley, Senator Newman and Senator Walters in particular, who bleat and demand in this chamber that Commonwealth Government expenditure be reduced-but not, of course, for Tasmania. They remind me of Saint Paul who said something like this: `God make me pure, but not yet'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Saint Aquinas.
—Saint Aquinas?
—Saint Augustine.
—Saint Augustine; I am sorry. The Tasmanians remind me of that when they say: `Cut government expenditure, but not for us or anything that we want to preserve'.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given that South Africa is facing a bloodbath of unbelievable proportions, why has the Government not introduced a schedule of automatic economic sanctions and, in particular, placed a ban on fish and diamond imports, given notice of cessation of South African Airways flights to Australia, imposed a ban on the promotion of tourism to South Africa, banned the buying of all South African goods by government and government agencies, begun its promised program of vocational training of South African blacks, and ended all South African Government representation in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not quite remember the last time-I guess it was following the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-that the Government considered this matter, and a variety of statements were made about the South African situation at that time. As I recall it, the Government's view articulated by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs at the time was that Australia stood ready to impose sanctions and to take a variety of other steps, but at that stage we were, if anything, in the vanguard of world commitment to act in that way and it was felt that it would not be very meaningful for Australia to act in isolation without the full and committed support of other Commonwealth countries including, if possible, the United Kingdom. That position was quite clearly expressed at the time and recent events in South Africa will inevitably lead to a reappraisal and further development of the Government's commitment made on the previous occasion.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister last night issued a Press statement which provided a response to the situation now obtaining in South Africa. As soon as the Government can consider this matter in further detail, we will do so. I cannot give a response to each of the parts of the honourable senator's question and there are a number of other things in addition to those things mentioned in the question which the Government was considering on the previous occasion when this matter was before it. I have no doubt that it will be a priority matter for consideration when the Cabinet resumes deliberations, probably next week.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance whether his attention has been brought to an article in today's Melbourne Age newspaper by columnist Terry McCrann which, in part, states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . don't get rich or we will slap you down with the most punitive capital gains tax in the world, various disguised wealth taxes and a range of other imposts . . .

Is it factual to say that the Australian capital gains tax is the most punitive in the world? Will the Minister give a comparison of the tax levels in this country with those of other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do we even dignify McCrann by commenting on him? He is not worth it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly not correct that Australia has the most punitive capital gains tax in the world, and I have no idea what Mr McCrann means by his reference to `various disguised wealth taxes'-no idea at all.
—He would not know either.

—I do not quite share Senator Chipp's view of Mr McCrann. I do not put him in the ratbag Right with Des Keegan, Katharine West or David Barnett, but certainly he sometimes allows his right wing prejudices to crowd out the facts. The article to which Senator McKiernan has drawn attention and the article which he wrote the day before demonstrate that. The one he wrote the day before referred, among other things, to the glorious days of the 1960s when the Australian economy was roaring along in a very healthy fashion. The truth, of course, is that it was at that very time that Black Jack McEwen was putting in place and cementing in the structural defects in the Australian economy which continue to plague it to this day. It was not just a question of McEwen being a high protectionist; it was a question of the type of protection he went for. If one had tried to design a policy which would maximise the amount of structural damage for any given level of protection, it probably would not be possible to design one more effective than McEwen's local content plan for the motor vehicle industry, the damaging effects of which are being whittled away by my colleague Senator Button and by the Government in general.

ANSWER.PARA: Referring now to today's article about the capital gains tax, it is certainly not true to say that it is the most punitive capital gains tax in the world. Almost every OECD country has a capital gains tax. The rates vary but they are usually around 30 per cent, with the exception of the United Kingdom. But there is one crucial qualification-they tax nominal gains, not real gains. Only in the United Kingdom, and then only for the last 12 months-it is one of Thatcher's redistributive measures, that is redistributive towards the rich-is the base indexed. In other words, in all countries other than the United Kingdom and Australia nominal gains are taxed, not real gains. If one assumed that an asset was purchased today for $100,000, that the market price of the asset and the inflation rate remained constant at 5 per cent for 14 years and that the asset was then sold, the tax levied under the Australian system would be zero. The tax levied under the common OECD-type tax, that is, a flat rate of 30 per cent, would be $30,000. Certainly the figures change if one makes different assumptions. For example, the same $100,000 asset held for 14 years with a 5 per cent inflation rate and a 10 per cent compound increase in the value of the asset-and they are highly unlikely assumptions, I stress-under the 30 per cent rate common in the OECD the tax paid would be just under $90,000 and under the Australian system it would be just under $98,000. So the Australian tax, under those highly unlikely conditions, would be slightly higher than the sorts of taxes that would apply in the OECD generally. With any ratio of inflation to asset value increase less than the 1 : 2 ratio which is cited in that hypothetical example the Australian tax would be lower than under the common type of capital gains taxes which prevail in the OECD.

—I ask the Minister for Education about some significant features of Commonwealth expenditure on government and non-government schools, referring in particular to the expenditure figures released by her Department in March and the enrolment figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in April of this year. Will the Minister explain, in the light of the Prime Minister's contrary assurances to non-government schools prior to the last election, how it now has become clear that the highest point in the proportion of Commonwealth schools money going to non- government schools was the 1983-84 financial year and how, in the two years since then, the non-government schools proportion has dropped? Why for the very first time was there this percentage drop in Commonwealth expenditure for non-government schools, especially when there was in the same year a 2.4 per cent increase in non-government school enrolments and a 1.3 per cent decrease in government school enrolments, these developments reflecting Australian families exercising choice in education? Finally, at the forthcoming Australian Labor Party Conference will the Minister be boasting that she has established the high-water water-mark for non- government schools and that she is now trying to turn back the tide?

—I do not have the figures before me that Senator Teague was referring to but I think his interpretation of them must have been wrong because the overall expenditure on schools, government and non-government, has increased each year that we have been in government. The rate of increase has been higher for government schools than for non-government schools. The reason for that is that when we came to government the level of recurrent support for government schools was very low; it had actually been cut during the period of the Fraser Government. Because our policy is needs-based we legislated for higher proportional increases over the four-year funding period than for schools in the non-government sector which had received, in many cases, very large increases during the period of the Fraser Government. But the only non-government schools that are not receiving increases in the level of funds are those schools in categories one and two. The schools in all the other categories-that is, the majority of non-government schools-are receiving legislated increases each year. If Senator Teague would like a fuller explanation of this I think he should place that question on notice.

—Is the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of the recent kidnapping of 13 members of a West German construction team and the murder of a Spanish health worker by Nicaragua's United States-backed Contra rebels? Is he also aware that this is part of a deliberate and announced policy of terrorism against international aid workers, an increasing number of whom are Australian? Have Australian aid workers expressed their concern in a letter to the Prime Minister? If so, what is the Australian Government doing to communicate its abhorrence of this policy which flies in the face of the norms of international relations and which receives covert support from the United States Administration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of particular concern that Contra attacks in Nicaragua in recent months have involved non-Nicaraguans working there. On 16 February a Swiss aid worker was killed in a Contra ambush of a truck in northern Nicaragua. On 17 May eight nationals of the Federal Republic of Germany were kidnapped by Contras in the course of an attack on a rural co-operative in south central Nicaragua. Three other Germans and a Chilean were reported to have been captured at the same time but managed to escape. A Spanish volunteer health worker was killed, along with nine Nicaraguans, when the truck in which he was travelling struck a mine on 25 May.

ANSWER.PARA: These and other incidents indicate a continuing pattern of indiscriminate attacks and serious human rights violations by the Contras which do nothing to improve their already sullied reputation. This is all the more worrying in the light of measures reportedly taken by the political leaders of the umbrella Contra organisation-the United Nicaraguan Opposition-to clean up the Contras' act. I expressed the Government's disapproval of the Contras in the Senate on 12 March as did Mr Hayden in the House of Representatives on 18 March. I am happy to be able to report, however, that the eight West Germans were released, unharmed, on 10 June after strenuous and high level diplomatic efforts. The Australian Government trusts that there will be no further incidents of this kind.

As regards Contra policy towards international aid workers, a Contra spokesperson was quoted recently in the Press as saying that the capture of the West Germans was a message to the internationalists. I understand that there is also a Contra document setting out rules for the treatment of prisoners of war which lists internationalists as a category to be regarded as combatants. It is not clear, however, whether this is intended to refer to foreign volunteer workers or, for example, foreign military advisers assisting the Nicaraguan armed forces. It does not appear at this stage that the Contras have made a policy decision to treat volunteer foreign workers as fair game. In the present case I understand that there was concern among the Contra leadership that no harm should come to those captured. But the Government would attribute this to concern for the Contras' international reputation rather than the welfare of the volunteers. Nevertheless, the risks to foreign volunteers in combat zones are obvious.

I have not seen the letter to the Prime Minister referred to by Senator Giles but the concerns of Australian aid workers in Nicaragua were conveyed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs two weeks ago through our Embassy in Mexico City. An officer of that Embassy is at present in Nicaragua on a regular visit and intends to be in touch with the Australian aid workers there. As Acting Foreign Minister I strongly advise Australians in Nicaragua to avoid combat zones or areas where Contras are known to be active. These are concentrated along Nicaragua's southern and northern borders.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other day Senator Harradine raised a question about the continued operation of the Sex Discrimination Act after 1 August 1986 and the issue as to what the status of certain Commonwealth and State laws and regulations possibly in breach of that Act would be under the exemption provisions of the legislation. I undertook to Senator Harradine to provide him with an answer in my capacity as the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I now do so, Mr President, and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
OPERATION OF SEX DISCRIMINATION ACT AFTER 1 AUGUST 1986

The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 rendered unlawful acts of discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status and pregnancy in certain specified fields subject to Commonwealth legislative power in respect of those fields. The Act in effect exempted acts done in direct compliance with existing Commonwealth and State laws for a two-year period of grace after the Act come into force on 1 August 1984 (paragraphs 40 (1) (a) and (b)). The Act also provided for prolongation of the period of grace by Regulation (sub-section 40 (2)).
Consistent with the objects of the Act, the Government instituted steps so that in the period of grace Commmonwealth and State laws that were exempted for the period of grace would be
amended to remove the inconsistencies, or
preserved by regulation under the Act where their continuation is justified.
The steps that were instituted to this end were-
(a) a letter from the Prime Minister to State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory on 4 September 1984.
(b) a letter from the Attorney-General to all Ministers on 25 October 1984.
These letters invited review of State and Commonwealth laws to identify any laws that needed to be preserved.

Follow-up action was taken particularly regarding the States and the Northern Territory: the Attorney-General raised the matter in the Meetings of the Ministers on Human Rights (Standing Committee of Attorneys-General). The Acting Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department wrote to the heads of all Departments, in December 1985, to remind them of the matter.

Given the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, the Government's position is that it should only preserve laws that the responsible (Commonwealth) Minister or the responsible State Government indicates it wishes to be preserved.
Commonwealth Legislation

In the Commonwealth sphere, there has been an extensive review of legislation by the responsible Departments. Departments have indicated the laws that need to be preserved. Regulations will be made preserving those laws. In a number of instances, laws have been amended to remove discriminatory provision. Other laws requiring amendment are dealt with in the Sex Discrimination (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986.
State Legislation

The existence of discriminatory provisions in State legislation is a matter for State Governments. Four States now have their own anti-discrimination legislation. South Australia and Western Australia have their own anti-discrimination legislation which overrides inconsistent State legislation. No State has sought a continued exemption for inconsistent legislation.

It must be assumed that all States accept that the Sex Discrimination Act will apply according to its tenor in relation to inconsistent State legislation (if any). The Government has agreed to a 12 months' extension of the exemption for certain State protective employment legislation which was in force at the commencement of the Sex Discrimination Act (see attached list which includes weight lifting restrictions for women in State legislation in force on 1 August 1984 and which has been sent to the States for their comments and/or additions). This extension can be implemented by regulations made under the Sex Discrimination Act.
Territory Legislation

The Department of Territories has been conducting a review of discriminatory A.C.T. and external Territory legislation. Amendments are being made as drafting resources allow. Regulations will be made under the Sex Discrimination Act to extend the exemption for certain Ordinances to allow completion of the review of those Ordinances (see attached list).
Senator Harradine's Request

While Senator Harradine might feel more comfortable with a list of overridden and retained provisions it is not really necessary that such a list be published. The fact is that the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 stands as the law that is to be followed after 31 July 1986 except to the extent that regulations are made pursuant to Parliament's mandate contained in sub-section 40 (2) of the Act.

Nevertheless, so far as the Attorney-General's Department is aware, no other Commonwealth Department has proceeded on the basis that there is an inconsistent Commonwealth law that is to be overridden by the Sex Discrimination Act. All other Departments have given written responses regarding the reviews of Commonwealth laws undertaken by them so there is a `nil return' to the demand for a list of overridden provisions. The provisions to be retained will be set out in regulations (list is attached).

Senator Harradine gave two instances of laws in the Act in respect of which there could be uncertainty in the event of the application of the Sex Discrimination Act. It is certainly true that questions could arise in the first instance if the Act were to be invoked, i.e. in court proceedings. The view of the Attorney-General's Department is that the Act would have no application in the first instance. It deals with ``Acts'' by ``persons'' and thus has no application in court proceedings. (Also, the Act declares acts unlawful, it does not render other provisions nugatory). The procedure under the Act-complaint to the Human Rights Commission etc- illustrates the non-applicability of the Act.

In the second instance, the Act would not apply since the provision was there to deal with the customary change of a woman's name upon marriage. There was no custom for the husband's name to change. There is no discrimination (the circumstances of the two sexes is are not the same).
In both instances, the laws are covered by what is said above regarding the review of Territory laws i.e. the laws are being reviewed and regulations will be made as appropriate.
Commonwealth Legislation to be Exempted from Operation of Act
Regulations are to be made under the Sex Discrimination Act to preserve the exemption for the following Commonwealth legislation:
National Health Act-payment of benefits to women at 60 but to men only at 65; exemption on the ground of cost;
Student Assistance Act-allocation of student allowances by reference to marital status; exemption on the ground of cost;
Defence Service Homes Act-benefits for female but not male dependants of members of the Forces; exemption on the ground of cost;
War Gratuity Act-payment of gratuities to female, but not male dependants, of men who served in World War 2;
Marriage Act-different marriageable ages for men and women; restrictions on marriage of females overseas; exemption for different marriageable ages justified by earlier maturity of women;
Defence Act, National Service Act-call up of men in time of war; exemption reflects existing exemption under SDA for women from combat duties;
Taxation legislation-a further exemption for 12 months to allow a review of discriminatory provisions to be finalised.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the rising of the Senate today will mark the completion of 40 years continuous broadcasting of Parliament by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The first broadcast was on 10 July 1946. Since then ABC stations in all capital cities have carried proceedings whenever Parliament sat-either the House of Representatives or the Senate. During the 40 years an estimated 22,500 hours of debates, questions and answers, notices of motion, urgency debates, censure motions, personal explanations and any other element that makes up a day in Parliament have been heard in homes all over Australia. Parliament is not only Australia's longest running radio program; it probably holds a world record for the number of hours broadcast.

INTERJECT.PARA: The late Stan Bancroft helped set up the technical equipment and was one of the first operators. Mr Casey Visser has been in the booth for 21 years, and the present operator in charge, Mr Athol Dale, has been here for 19 years. Some of the well known ABC broadcasters who have been associated with Parliament are Eric Coleman, Malcolm Naylor, Arthur Wyndham, John West, Graham Conolly, Martin Royal, Kevin Chapman, Geoff Howard and Bruce Webster. I am sure that honourable senators are interested in those comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave, Mr President, to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the requirements for the broadcasting of exerpts of Parliament is that fairness and accuracy should at all time be observed. I wish that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal could look at fairness and accuracy in broadcasting as far as talk-back commentators are concerned. I draw the Parliament's attention to ill-informed remarks made about me by a so-called expert on South Africa, John Tingle, on radio station 2GB Sydney. Mr Tingle referred to comments that I had made earlier in the week on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program and, after attacking my views on the African National Congress, he said that I had never been to South Africa and he implied that I knew nothing about that region. He then proceeded to interview Senator Jessop, who has just returned from South Africa and therefore knew all about the situation there.

SPEECH.PARA: If Mr Tingle had contacted my office or me, he would have been informed that since I was first elected to the Senate and to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I have had a long involvement and a keen interest in the southern African region. Let me give some examples. I was Deputy Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Sub-Committee that produced the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee reports on Namibia and Zimbabwe and I was Chairman of that Sub-Committee when it produced three other reports on African references. I visited southern Africa as a member of two parliamentary delegations, and as Chairman of the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee I led the Australian delegation to the South African Development Co-ordination Conferences in 1985, in Swaziland, and 1986, in Zimbabwe. Recently I represented the Australian Labor Party at a special Socialist International conference on South Africa, at which I had discussions with the Chairman, Willie Brandt, who had been in South Africa prior to the conference talking to Botha and other prominent South Africans, including Winnie Mandela.

I have visited South Africa. On the way to SADCC in 1985, and with the assistance of the Australian Embassy, I visited Soweto and other black townships, spoke to academics, businessmen, officials of the UDF-some of whom were subsequently charged with treason-the Black Sash organisation, and others. Earlier this year at SADCC in Harare, I specifically spoke to business and banking personnel who had head offices in South Africa-for example, Anglo-American, Barclays and Standard Chartered banks. I also spent some time in two areas of that country with white farmers, some of whom had returned from South Africa to live in Zimbabwe.

I believe that on southern African issues I would be as well informed as, or better informed than, any member of this Parliament. At a more appropriate time, I shall place on the record my opinion of Mr Tingle's recent broadcasts from South Africa. Perhaps Mr Tingle did not contact me because he would not have liked the views that I would have expressed. However, I wish that he had had the decency not to misrepresent me in the way in which he did. I ask the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to look at a fairness and accuracy code. If it cannot accede to that request, it should look at the fairness and accuracy of the John Tingle program when the licence of 2GB comes up for renewal in public hearings. I trust that you, Mr President, will convey my views to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy).

TALK.START.PARA: -I present the 252nd report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, entitled, `Job Seeker-Computer Acquisition by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report contains the findings of the Committee's inquiry into the job seeker computer acquisition and related aspects of the automatic data processing operations of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I intend to precis my statement and at the conclusion of my remarks I will seek leave to have the full text of my statement incorporated in Hansard. The Committee's principal concerns about the job seeker compute acquisition were reported to the Parliament in a statement I made to the Senate on 3 December 1985. I seek leave to incorporate a copy of that statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Parliament is aware that the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts has been given a standing reference to examine and report on major ADP acquisition proposals which exceed $5 million before they proceed to Cabinet for funding approval. When examining these proposals the Committee aims to ensure that they are properly planned and justified. However, it also recognises that if the Commonwealth is to get `value for money' from these proposals, subsequent purchasing action must also proceed in line with approved procedures.

The Committee has been conducting an inquiry into the Job Seeker Computer Acquisition and related aspects of the ADP operations of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. The Job Seeker project is intended to provide storage and update facilities for job seeker registration records through a network of computers located in Commonwealth Employment Service offices throughout Australia.

This inquiry resulted from advice to the Committee of an unusual level of disquiet in the computer vendor industry about the conduct of this tender and, from serious criticisms made by the Auditor-General in his September 1985 Report about the adequacy of planning, cost/benefit justification and financial management supporting a previous ADP project in the Department, Job Bank.

The Commonwealth's purchasing procedures are there to ensure, among other things, that public tendering is conducted in a thorough and impartial fashion. If these procedures and their purpose are not respected, the reputation of the Commonwealth in the market place for fair and responsible purchasing practices will be at risk. Responsibility for the proper observance of these procedures rests primarily with the purchasing Department although the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services, as the Commonwealth's Contracting Authority, also has a clear responsibility for ensuring that Government purchasing procedures are followed.

The Committee has been concerned to avoid unnecessary delay in its examination of the Job Seeker acquisition. It has therefore expedited its inquiries and is now in a position to provide a statement to the Parliament about its conclusions.
The Committee's concerns about the Job Seeker Computer Acquisition are twofold.

Firstly, the Committee has serious concerns about several documented instances during the evaluation of tenders, where proper procedures were not followed. The Committee has also noted some unusual and, in its view, unacceptable features of the recommended tender and proposed contractural arrangements with the recommended tenderer.

Secondly, the Committee is not satisfied that adequate planning and evaluation was undertaken to support the particular implementation strategy chosen for the Job Seeker project. It has also noted the serious criticisms made by the Auditor-General of the Department's past performance in the conduct of proper planning and evaluation for the Job Bank project.
The Committee will be providing a full report to Parliament on these matters in due course.

The Committee has concluded that the tendering procedures may have compromised the impartiality of the tender recommendation, but it has also given careful consideration to the considerable costs resulting from tender cancellation and the consequent delay in the implementation of the Job Seeker project. Reluctantly it has concluded that these costs would outweigh the benefits resulting from the conduct of a new tender.
The Committee is therefore recommending that the Job Seeker purchase proceed, subject to certain amendments being made to the proposed contract with the recommended supplier.

The Committee is also recommending that before any further ADP procurement action is taken by the Department, it undertake a comprehensive re-evaluation of its future ADP needs and represent the outcome in a revised ADP Strategic Plan. This should be supported by full documentation of the planning and justification for all proposed ADP acquisitions over the next three years. Of course, the Committee would expect that any ADP acquisition proposal costing more than $5 million will be referred to the Committee for examination and report under its standing reference.

The Committee will be communicating its recommendations on these matters in greater detail to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services.
For further information telephone Canberra (062) 727455.
Canberra
3 December 1985

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee's principal concerns stated at the time were: That proper planning and evaluation had not been undertaken to support the particular implementation strategy chosen for the job seeker project; there were documented instances during the tender evaluation where proper tendering procedures were not followed; in consequence, the impartiality of the tender result could not be guaranteed; and certain features of the original contract with the successful tenderer, Wang Computer Pty Ltd, were improper. The Committee, having given careful consideration to the costs resulting from the cancellation of the job seeker tender, recommended that the job seeker purchase proceed, in spite of its concerns. Since then, the concerns of the Committee have been reinforced and are a substantial part of this report.

SPEECH.PARA: I must report also that there have been some disturbing new developments with the job seeker acquisition since the Committee finalised the conclusions and recommendations contained in this report. Recent advice to the Committee from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services has indicated that Wang will not now be able to deliver certain critical outstanding functionality, as it contracted, by the due date of 30 June 1986. Wang has now lodged a claim for excusable delay with the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services and has requested that the completion date for the supply of the outstanding functionality be extended by 12 months.

In the light of these developments, the Committee strongly recommends that, unless Wang can demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services that this delay has occurred for reasons outside its control, the Commonwealth should seek liquidated damages from Wang for any delay in delivery beyond 30 June 1986. The Committee is also of the view that, in the event of non-delivery of the outstanding functionality by 1 January 1987, the contract should be cancelled and full compensation should be sought by the Commonwealth for the major delay and dislocation which the non-delivery of this functionality will cause to the Commonwealth's employment and labour force programs.

In the interim, the Committee endorses the stand taken by the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services in not approving any further acquisitions from Wang for the job seeker project or other projects in the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations which require standardisation on Wang equipment, pending a satisfactory resolution of the uncertainties about Wang's contractual commitments. The Committee believes that, notwithstanding the urgency of the job seeker project and other projects in that Department, it would be indefensible for the Department to purchase further equipment and consequently make a greater commitment to standardising on Wang equipment, while there remains uncertainty about Wang's ability to provide the full functionality required for the job seeker project.

In conclusion, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has undoubtedly moved with great speed over the last few years in implementing computer-based information systems to support and expand the services it provides to its clients. However, in the case of the job seeker project, the Committee believes that this speed and the Department's disregard for proper planning and procurement procedures have undoubtedly resulted in much greater delay and cost than would have occurred had planning and procurement proceeded at a more considered and responsible pace.

This is an important report and I thank the staff of the secretariat for their services and in particular I thank the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, for the preparation and dedication which are displayed in this report. I commend the report to honourable senators. I seek leave for the full text of my statement to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

There have been some disturbing new developments with the Job Seeker acquisition since the Committee finalised the conclusions and recommendations contained in this report. In the light of these developments the Committee strongly recommends that, unless Wang can demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services that this delay has occurred for reasons outside its control, the Commonwealth should seek liquidated damages from Wang for any delay in delivery beyond 30 June 1986. In the interim, the Committee endorses the stand taken by the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services in not approving any further acquisitions from Wang for the Job Seeker project or other projects in the Department of Employment and Industrial relations which require standardisation on Wang equipment, pending a satisfactory resolution of the uncertainties about Wang's contractual commitments.

The Committee believes that, notwithstanding the urgency of the Job Seeker project and other projects in that Department, it would be indefensible for the Department to purchase further equipment and consequently make a greater commitment to standardising on Wang equipment, while there remains uncertainty about Wang's ability to provide the full functionality required for the Job Seeker system.
In summary, the findings contained in the Committee's report fully confirm the concerns which I stated on 3 December 1985 to the Parliament.

The Committee has concluded that the Department of Employment and Industrial relations and in particular, the Secretary of that Department, must carry principal responsibility for the improper manner in which this tender was conducted. The Department of Local Government and Administrative Services and its Secretary, given the clear responsibilities of that Department for ensuring that procurement proceeds in line with government purchasing practices and policies, must also carry major responsibility in this matter.

The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has undoubtedly moved with great speed over the last few years in implementing computer-based information systems to support and expand the services it provides to its clients. However in the case of the Job Seeker project the Committee believes this speed, and the Department's disregard for proper planning and procurement procedures, has undoubtedly resulted in much greater delay and cost than would have occurred had planning and procurement proceeded at a more considered and responsible pace.
I commend the report to honourable senators.
