DEBATE.TITLE: FUTURES INDUSTRY BILL 1986FUTURES INDUSTRY (FEES) BILL 1986COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FUTURES INDUSTRY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Futures Industry Bill 1986, the Futures Industry (Fees) Bill 1986 and the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment (Futures Industry) Bill 1986. These are important measures. They are low profile Bills, I suppose, to regulate a very high profile industry. They flow largely as a result of the changes made in banking regulations in December 1983 when the futures market became accessible to international clients. That was a most important factor in the development of this market. As the title of one of the Bills implies, this legislation forms part of the National Companies and Securities Commission package. In the sixth annual report of the Commission, the Chairman records:

SPEECH.PARA: Trading in futures is developing rapidly and there are major opportunities for Australia in establishing international links. Competitive pressures create a particular urgency in this area. Both the market operators and the NCSC recognise the importance of the Australian futures market being seen to be efficient, competitive and fair by potential international collaborators. As recommended by the Campbell Committee, a Futures Bill is being produced which will create a new regulatory framework for the industry. It has been welcomed both by Australian and overseas operators.

It is also welcomed by the Opposition, which will be giving the Bill its complete support. It is a long, complex and very detailed Bill-perhaps unnecessarily so in some respects. It runs to 160-odd clauses over 136 pages. It is interesting to compare that with the Ontario legislation which the Government claims it used as a model. That has a mere 66 sections in 39 pages. Indeed, this is the third Bill in the sequence. There were draft exposures of legislation prepared in both 1984 and 1985 which were subject to very extensive public comment and, in particular, to detailed analysis by bodies such as the business law section of the Law Council of Australia. Its recommendations have had a great influence in shaping the final nature of this Bill.

The principal provisions of the legislation include the following: A system of licensing for all futures brokers, futures advisers and their representatives, whether or not they are members of the Sydney Futures Exchange Ltd; a wide definition of `futures contract' which will cover new forms of contract not yet developed and ensure that all trading in futures contracts is subject to similar prudential requirements; so-called anti-bucketing provisions, with a penalty of $10,000 or two years' gaol or both, for future brokers who trade off-market or outside the rules of the futures exchange or futures association of which they are members; an insider trading prohibition similar to section 128 of the Securities Industry Code; general anti-fraud provisions based on the United States of America Commodities Exchange Act and similar criminal penalties for market manipulation, false trading, market rigging, false or misleading statements, fraudulent inducement to deal in futures contracts and dissemination of information about illegal transactions; compensation for clients who suffer losses because of prescribed offences; powers for the National Companies and Securities Commission similar to those in the Securities Industry Code; the establishment of a Futures Consultative Committee to advise the Ministerial Council of Commonwealth and State Attorneys-General; and requirements for brokers to maintain records, appoint auditors and keep clients' funds separate from their own. All of those are important provisions. Again, as I say, all those provisions have the support of the Opposition.

The necessity for this legislation, I suppose, develops in an area where the increases in technology, particularly the technology of communications, have led to the establishment of world or, indeed, global markets. The first similar organisation specialising in dealing in futures was the Chicago Board of Trade, which started operating in 1848. It was only in 1960, however, that in Sydney the Greasy Wool Exchange Ltd was established and it became apparent fairly early in the piece that there was no major piece of legislation which regulated the operation of that exchange. Indeed, there was some suspicion that the New South Wales Gaming and Betting Act 1912 was the only piece of legislation which might be used to regulate the industry. So in 1979 the New South Wales Government enacted the Futures Market Act. That was a very short Act, subsequently amended in 1982. It ran to, I think, only 11 sections and a couple of Schedules spread over eight pages of legislation.

The operation of the futures exchanges in Australia at the moment is fairly limited. The agricultural commodities traded include wool, trade steers and fat lambs, precious metals such as gold and silver and financial instruments of the 90-day bank accepted bill, two-year Treasury bonds, United States dollars, and share price index futures based on the Australian stock exchanges all ordinaries index. When that is compared with the rest of the world where articles as diverse as barley, iced broilers, butter, cattle, cocoa, coffee, copper, corn, cotton, eggs, frozen orange juice, gold, oats, palladium, petroleum, plywood, pork bellies, potatoes, silver, soya beans, stud lumber, turkeys, wheat, wool and zinc, among other things, are already traded on futures exchanges, it can be seen that the area of potential development of new agricultural and mineral commodities on the exchange is very extensive indeed.

There has already been great progress made in the development of the growth of the futures exchange in Australia. For instance, one reads in the Chairman's message in the 1985 annual report of the Sydney Futures Exchange Ltd that the volume of trading in the Exchange's two most active contracts, the 90-day bank bill and the all ordinaries price index, and also the overall volume, rose by 140 per cent to an unprecedented 1.24 million contracts. The Chairman, Mr Oliver, goes on to indicate that the Exchange itself was very supportive of the Bill currently before the Senate. The Chief Executive in his report said:

The volume of trading in 1985 increased more than two fold compared with the previous year, and for the first time in its history, overall volume on the Sydney Futures Exchange exceeded one million contracts.

It is also worth noting that the Sydney Futures Exchange features in the table of the ten top stock index futures and option contracts in the world by volume in 1985 and the top ten interest rate futures and options contracts in the world by volume in 1985. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two brief tables taken from the Futures Exchange annual report which indicate the volume to which I have been referring.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As I indicated, the area for expansion of the operations of futures exchanges hopes to be able to establish in the near future a United States Treasury bond futures contract compatible with the one traded on the Chicago Board of Trade. The volume of activity in this contract, the most active futures market in the world, and the fact that a similar contract is also traded on the London International Financial Futures Exchange, indicate that a Sydney contract in United States Treasury bonds would prove very attractive to international participants. I think it is important to understand that the great advantage we have in terms of the development of the futures industry in this county is simply that we happen to be situated in a very convenient time zone. The honourable member for North Sydney, Mr Spender, said in the debate in the House of Representatives on 29 April:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian market is now significant in international terms at least partly because of its position in the international time zone, its ability to trade when European and North American exchanges are closed and also the fact that when, in particular, North Americans and the British wish to trade, they can trade on a market where English is the spoken language; that makes it very simply a simpler operation for them.

To that extent I think it is important that we realise that the futures industry is one of those areas in terms of an expansion of services of a financial nature which are potentially in a position to bring great revenue and great expertise into Australia and, in fact, to make their own contribution to the recovery of the Australian economy from the very parlous state in which we find it at the moment. It is part of the process by which financial markets are being opened up in Australia. For instance, quite recently the Sydney Stock Exchange approved 57 companies whose shares for the first time, in a quite legitimate and open fashion, could be subject to short selling. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Certain matters are excluded from the operations of this legislation. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his second reading speech indicated certain areas which I think simply need to be mentioned. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph 10 of the explanatory memorandum sets out the regime that will apply in relation to the futures industry and the securities industry. At this stage, it is not proposed that the futures industry legislation should cover deliverable commodity options that are not traded on a futures exchange. If it becomes apparent that these or related arrangements are being used to circumvent the purpose and spirit of the legislation then the Ministerial Council will consider extending the scope of the legislation.

So at this stage it is true to say that the legislation is not entirely an all-embracing document but that the Government has indicated that, if in the future it becomes necessary to review the operation, it has an open mind on that. I am very pleased to see that.

There is only one matter I wish to raise with the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who represents the Attorney-General, in order to seek his comments when he replies, that is, the representations which have been made on behalf of the Australian Merchant Bankers Association. The Association has indicated in a letter addressed to Senator Durack its concern that moneys which are held by futures brokers, funds which must be deposited with the broker to cover both the deposit needed on any contract and any calls-you will be aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, that calls must be made; the broker must call margins from clients as soon as the losses potentially exceed 50 per cent of the original deposit-are invested in a number of financial institutions. In fact, the legislation provides, through the guidelines operating in the Sydney Futures Exchange, for investment of client funds by brokers provided they are within the list of what are called `approved corporations'. The Australian Merchant Bankers Association makes the point that in the legislation as currently drafted the list of approved investments excludes all merchant banks. It goes on to demonstrate why it believes that merchant banks should be included. For the sake of time, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the letter from the Australian Merchant Bankers Association to Senator Durack.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-

Dear Senator Durack,

The Futures Industry Bill 1986 is now before the Senate. The Bill is a complicated and lengthy document which attempts to regulate all sections of the futures industry with a view to protecting the investor who is involved in these areas. The Australian Merchant Bankers' Association is concerned that the Bill contains a provision which restricts the permitted areas of investment of brokers' trust funds to a degree which unfairly and unreasonably disadvantages merchant banks.

When clients conduct business with a futures broker, funds must be deposited with the broker to cover the deposit needed on the contracts, and to also cover any calls for funds which may arise if losses occur on the contracts. Clients funds also accumulate when profits are made. Under the Futures Industry Bill these funds are referred to as segregated funds and must be kept in a trust account.

The present Sydney Futures Exchange guidelines for investment of client funds by brokers provide a list of ``approved corporations'' and brokers are allowed to invest funds with companies which are included on this list. The majority of these corporations are merchant banks, and are mainly Members of the Australian Merchant Bankers' Association.

As the legislation is currently drafted, the list of approved investments excludes all merchant banks. AMBA believes that provision should be made in the Bill to allow the arrangement to continue, and that futures brokers should not be prevented from investing trust funds with merchant banks. The Sydney Futures Exchange supports AMBA in this matter.

Merchant banks, who are all classified as Money Market Corporations within the Financial Corporations Act, hold over 6% of the assets of all Australian financial institutions, a total of over 27.3 billion dollars. Merchant banks in Australia are a sound group, with the impressive parental backing of some of the world's largest financial institutions.

AMBA understands that the provisions of the Bill are, in the main part, designed to protect the investor. The accomplishment of this aim is not assisted by the exclusion of merchant banks from the list of approved investment options for brokers' trust funds.
AMBA suggests that the Bill be amended to allow for the inclusion of merchant banks in the list of approved investments. This could be accomplished by a number of methods for example:
(a) As suggested by the Sydney Futures Exchange, in section 86 (5) (d) of the Bill a sub-paragraph (vi) could be added, which states:
``(vi) On deposit with any other corporation which has been prescribed for that purpose''.
This amendment would give the government the power to prescribe corporations or groups of corporations, e.g. Members of the Australian Merchant Bankers' Association, as eligible investments.
(b) An alternative to this approach would be to permit the Sydney Futures Exchange to specify approved investments, the additional paragraph could read:
``(vi) On deposit with any other corporation which has been approved by the Sydney Futures Exchange as an approved investment''.
This would relieve the authorities of the burden of vetting companies for the purpose of this section and return the onus of selection to the Sydney Futures Exchange.
(c) A third approach to this problem would be if the client was given the ability to approve areas of investment for his funds:
Sub-paragraph (vi) could read:
``(vi) In a manner in accordance with the written directions of a person entitled to the money''.
This would enable the broker to continue to invest trust funds in all the companies which are on the Sydney Futures Exchange's current list of approved investments, if the client gives his approval.

The removal of merchant banks from the areas of approved investments for brokers' trust funds, seems contrary to other government initiatives designed to encourage the development of Australia's financial markets, and the governments' attempts to remove artificial and arbitrary barriers which unnecessarily distinguish between different sections of the financial community.

Members of the Association have had a long established relationship with futures brokers and do not wish to have to curtail their involvement with the industry as it enters into the new and exciting phase of its development as a world class futures centre which this Bill will allow.
We would be pleased to discuss this matter in further detail at your convenience.
Yours faithfully
John A. Hall
Executive Director

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I hope that the Minister will be able to indicate the basis upon which what I presume is a specific government decision has been made that this exclusion should apply.

SPEECH.PARA: I will bring my remarks to a conclusion by saying once again that the Opposition is in support of this legislation. Although it is a piece of regulatory legislation and, therefore, perhaps not as entirely fashionable as regulatory legislation used to be in past days, it nevertheless marks a further step in the maturity of Australian financial dealings and Australian financial institutions. It provides some protection for those who are investors, those who are speculators, those who are short sellers, and those who are hedgers who wish to take advantage of international trends and to become more properly and, I hope, more profitably, part of the international financial community.

The increase in telecommunications in terms of its sophistication and speed and the unique position of the Australian market because of the time zone to which I have referred should bring about a development of the futures industry which will be profitable to those who invest and speculate and also to the nation as a whole. Therefore, the legislation is most welcome. We look forward to observing how it works and hope that the Government will keep an open mind on any future amendments which may be necessary. Under those circumstances, I have much pleasure, on behalf of the Opposition, in commending the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In June 1982 the Ministerial Council of the National Companies and Securities Commission resolved to propose legislation regulating the futures industry. Draft legislation was circulated for comment in October 1984 and again in November 1985. Changes have been made to the legislation on the basis of those comments. The Futures Industry Bill, the Futures Industry (Fees) Bill and the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment (Futures Industry) Bill bring about a system for regulating future exchanges, clearing houses and future brokers. The Australian Democrats, who are not ideologically committed to either of the extremes in the regulation debate, have no difficulty in supporting regulatory legislation where it can be demonstrated that it is for the greater good of Australian business.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe it is appropriate for government to protect innocents who can easily be fleeced when they get involved in complex financial transactions and investments. Of course, it is not just in the futures industry that people can lose a lot of money when they act on advice given by shonky financial advisers. I believe there are good grounds for regulating all financial and investment advisers. People investing their savings and superannuation on retirement ought to be confident that the professionals who advise them are bound by a strict code of conduct; that their advice is designed to benefit the client rather than themselves; and that action can be taken against financial advisers who seek to profit at the expense of their clients. In a complex deregulated financial environment, there are very good reasons to regulate financial advisers.

The Futures Industry Bill forms part of the national uniform companies and securities scheme which established a Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities consisting of representatives of the Commonwealth and each of the States. This legislation is therefore before the Parliament following its unanimous approval by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, representing Labor, Liberal and National Party governments. Each State has undertaken to apply this legislation and if we were to amend it such changes would have to have the unanimous agreement of the Ministerial Council. Hence the powers of this Parliament to amend this Bill and others which form part of the national uniform companies and securities scheme is conditional upon the willingness of the Commonwealth Attorney-General to take any amendment back to the Ministerial Council and then upon the unanimous approval of that Council in relation to initial legislation or the approval of a majority in the case of subsequent amending Bills.

The Democrats do not seek to amend this legislation, although we have in the past sought to amend such legislation. Our problems with the legislation are set out in very great detail in the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills today. It is an extraordinary report. Again it draws attention to a whole range of matters. The Democrats are becoming increasingly unhappy that, when a committee of this chamber brings down an excellent report that we believe ought to be acted upon, we find that we are unable to do so. It seems that the veto which operates for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee comes for delegated legislation to the Ministerial Council-which is another matter about which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is concerned.

I wonder whether in reply the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) might be able to suggest some mechanisms by which the Ministerial Council might have more regard to the types of items that come forward from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It is not a closed book by any means, or a well-kept secret, that the types of items which come before us from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee have come before us on innumerable occasions in the past. I would have thought that the time would be long since past when we would have had to continue with the charade of saying that we cannot do anything about an excellent report from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I hope that on future Bills which emanate in such a way following a report we will seek again to move amendments and hope that then they might be carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to hear Senator Macklin's remarks about the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I wish to raise some serious matters of principle that emerge from the report that clearly we are unable to deal with, and I regret that. I strongly support the concept of the Futures Industry Bill, the Futures Industries (Fees) Bill and the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment (Futures Industry) Bill but I am concerned about the diminution of the powers of Parliament involved and certainly the allowing of excessive control to the Executive and to interstate commissions of the kind to which the Executive is responsible but over which the Parliament appears to be given no effective powers of supervision. That is a totally improper way to run a country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Scrutiny of Bills Committee reported that the Bills form part of the national uniform companies and securities scheme. The power of the Commonwealth Parliament to amend Bills forming part of that scheme is conditional upon the willingness of the Commonwealth Attorney-General to take any amendment back to the Ministerial Council of the National Companies and Securities Commission. The unanimous approval of that Council is needed for initial legislation such as these Bills, or for the approval of the majority for subsequent amending Bills. Failing such approval the national uniform scheme would be placed in jeopardy. I stress that in the first place it is up to the Commonwealth Attorney-General to decide whether to take any amendment that we recommend back to that body. The operation of this aspect of the uniform legislation places the Parliament in an invidious position. If it amends legislation forming part of the uniform scheme or rejects such legislation it may bring the national uniform scheme to an end. On the other hand, if it fails to amend or reject such legislation, however compelling the grounds for action, it may be said to have delegated legislative power to the Ministerial Council without retaining even the equivalent of a power of disallowance.

To the extent that it is possible for parliamentary amendments to be taken back to the Ministerial Council for approval, it may be said that it is the Ministerial Council which has a power of veto over the legislative action of the Parliament. Accordingly, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee drew this aspect of the national uniform scheme and of the Futures Industry Bill, as an element of that scheme, to the attention of the Senate in that it might be considered to constitute an inappropriate delegation of legislative power. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has responded:

The futures industry in Australia strongly supports the Bill and has called for its enactment as soon as possible in the public interest. In its submission on the Bill the Sydney Futures Exchange stated: ``The Exchange strongly supports the implementation of the Bill at an early date and would not wish enactment of the Bill to be delayed. The Exchange believes that it is important that the industry is, and is seen to be, appropriately regulated.
We would agree with that-
The Exchange is ready to perform its own role in the co-regulatory process.
The Attorney-General goes on:

Experience with the administration of the N.S.W. Futures Markets Act, the manner in which some members of the Sydney Futures Exchange have promoted and conducted their business, and the failure of some futures brokers, have indicated the need for Australia-wide legislation in this area.
None of us on this side would disagree. No-one on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would disagree. However, the Attorney-General went on:
Most of the provisions in the Bill-
that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has drawn to the attention of honourable senators-

are based on the corresponding provisions in the Companies Act 1981 and the Securities Industry Act 1980. To amend any of the provisions in the Bill would require the unanimous agreement of all the parties to the co-operative scheme. Not only would any attempt to amend the Bill result in a serious delay in its enactment, I am also not confident that all the States and the Northern Territory would agree to the amendment, particularly as it would be undesirable to have disuniformity between corresponding provisions in the companies, securities industry and futures industry legislation.

We accept that. However, this response simply underlines the problem of the manner in which the Senate's powers are being diminished or being held hostage to decisions of the Executive. There are many areas where changes should be made to the manner in which this legislation operates and the detailed response of the Attorney- General to the concerns of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has in no way diminished these concerns. Questions such as the reverse onus of proof and self-incrimination are very serious matters which still exist and which make this legislation, in my mind, flawed legislation no matter how worth while and proper its objectives are. For example, this legislation empowers the Commission or a person authorised by the Commission to require various persons to produce books relating to dealings in futures contracts and like matters at a time and place specified in the direction of the Commission or by the authorised person as the case may be. Failure to comply with a requirement without reasonable excuse is an offence punishable by a fine of $10,000 or imprisonment for two years, or both. It is not, however, stipulated in the legislation that the time and place specified by the Commission or the authorised person should be reasonable. The Committee recognises that the specification of an unreasonable time and place may give rise to a reasonable excuse for failure to attend and produce books, but it would prefer to see the requirement that the time and place be reasonable specified in the standard form of such provisions.

Another clause provides that it a defence in a prosecution for an offence against sub-clause 15 (2) relating to furnishing information or making a statement which is false or misleading in a material particular if it is established that the defendant believed on reasonable grounds that the information or statement was true and not misleading. The effect of this sub-clause is to place upon the defendant the burden of exculpating himself or herself by establishing a defence on the balance of probabilities. Our view clearly is that the burden of establishing a defence-that is, the persuasive onus-should not be placed on defendants in criminal proceedings, but rather they should merely be required to bear the evidential onus, that is, the onus of adducing evidence of the existence of a defence, the burden of negativing then being borne by the prosecution. In the present case, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee noted that the usual form of provisions relating to false or misleading statements in Commonwealth legislation requires the prosecution to establish that the defendant made the false statement knowingly or knowing that the statement was false or misleading. The Committee questioned why in this case it had been considered necessary to reverse the onus of proof and, given that decision, why it had been considered necessary to impose on the defendant the persuasive onus of proof rather than merely an evidential onus. The Committee observes that its concern is that too great a burden should not be placed on the accused, thus reversing the presumption that a defendant is innocent until proved guilty.

There are many other instances, such as the one on self-incrimination. A person is not excused from making a statement relating to the compilation of books required to be produced under section 13 or section 14, or as to any matter to which any such books relate on the ground that the statement might incriminate the person. This departs from the usual form of such provisions in Commonwealth legislation in that it stipulates that the proviso applies only where the person required to make a statement claims before making the statement that it may tend to incriminate the person. The Committee suggested that the requirement that a person claim the privilege is better suited to situations where a person is being examined before a court or a quasi-judicial tribunal rather than to administrative contexts like the present. The Committee suggested that the authorised person should be required to caution the person to that effect before seeking the statement. These objections go on and there is very little time to make them, unfortunately. The Committee has written to the Attorney-General asking him to consider revising the customary form of such provisions with a view to strengthening the protection accorded to persons who may be required to incriminate themselves.

Another sub-clause creates offences where a person in purported compliance with a requirement of an inspector or appearing before an inspector for examination furnishes information which is false or misleading in a material particular. Neither provision contains the usual requirement that the defendant know that the information is false or misleading with the result that under this Bill a person might be liable even if he or she quite innocently provided wrong information. The Committee cannot concede that the provisions are not ones of strict liability. To adopt the interpretation advanced by the Attorney-General in his response to the Committee would mean that, in the usual form of provisions relating to the furnishing of false or misleading information in Commonwealth legislation, the words `knowingly' or `knowing that the information is false or misleading' are superfluous. Moreover, if it is not intended that the offences be ones of strict liability, the Committee can see no reason, other than uniformity with the Securities Industry Act 1980, why it should not be made an express element of the offence that the defendant knew that the information furnished was false or misleading.

I would like to make a couple of final points. Another clause prohibits insider trading in futures contracts concerning bodies corporate. It provides that, where a prosecution is instituted against a person for an offence because the person was in possession of insider information and dealt in a futures contract, it is a defence if it is established that the other party to the dealing also knew, or ought reasonably to have known, the relevant information before entering the dealing. The effect of the sub-clause is to place upon the defendant the burden, once again, of exculpating himself or herself by establishing this defence on the balance of probabilities. There are so many instances of such serious matters as more reversals of the onus of proof and more abrogations of customary rights, particularly the one whereby in fact the inability under this Act to obtain an undertaking as to damages from the Crown or its representatives may result in a court declining to grant an interim injunction since the giving of an undertaking is a major factor in determining the balance of convenience. The Committee's concern is that the court should not be prevented in appropriate cases from requiring an undertaking as to damages, as it would be under this legislation. In general, we cannot fix all these unfortunate parts of this Bill. We cannot make this flawed Bill totally acceptable in detail, even though it is in principle. I regret that. I believe that the Senate should take appropriate action to assert its rights in such matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Any reputation I might once have had for talking in this place under water with my feet enmeshed in concrete is being fast overtaken by the contributions now being regularly made by Senator Michael Baume, Senator Puplick, Senator Teague and God knows how many others who have burdened us with contributions this week. But I thank honourable senators for their participation in this debate and for their support for the measure. I will quickly respond to some of the matters which have been raised. Senator Puplick was fussing about the size of the Futures Industry Bill 1986 with its 160 provisions and compared it unfavourably with the Ontario Futures Act, which he said was only some 66 clauses long. I am advised by those on my left who know more about these things than I do, the departmental advisers, that the Ontario Bill is accompanied by regulations the size of half a telephone book, which is not intended to be the case here, save for some forms. Necessarily, this sort of legislation is complex. It cannot be done in quite as streamlined a fashion as people sometimes allege, and that is true of this particular measure.

SPEECH.PARA: The general objections we have had to it the do not go to the policy but rather to the drafting with a lot of concern being expressed about not meeting the standards set out by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills as appropriate for some of these procedural clauses. I simply make the point that not only is there a requirement for this sort of legislation to conform to the majority position of the other jurisdictions, which makes it difficult to amend it in a forum such as this, but the more immediate constraint on the drafting of this particular measure was the desire, for obvious reasons, to bring it into uniformity with the Companies Act 1981 and the Securities Industry Act 1980, both of which were drafted under the tenure of the Fraser Government. Any concern for a falling short of standards thought legally appropriate in some of these measures can be sheeted home elsewhere, I suggest, than to this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do to fix it all up?

—If it is to be fixed-and that is not to make any concessions that, in respect of all of these clauses, the points can be made with equal vigour about matters in issue-I think realistically it is going to be only in the context of an overtaking of the present co-operative schemes by national Commonwealth legislation, which gets us straight back into the territory of the most appropriate way of legislating in the companies and securities and related areas. I would have no difficulty at all, as honourable senators would know, with the proposition that we ought to abandon this Heath Robinsonian nonsense which we have been saddled with now as a result of the obsession of the previous Administration with matters federalist and get on with devising a system of corporate regulation in this country which does not subject itself to the problems of lines of responsibility and legislative impotence which arouse indignation every time one of these Bills come into this place. I simply make the point that all of this is now at last the subject of a detailed reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I hope and expect that the sorts of concerns that have been expressed today would be raised in that forum and that in due course we can get to the stage of having a genuinely national system of corporate law rather than the muddle that exists at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of the criticisms made by Senator Michael Baume should not go unanswered by the Government, and rather than dealing with them in any detailed way now I simply seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a reply made by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to Senator Tate, as Chairman of the Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, on 11 June.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
11 June 1986
Dear Senator Tate
I refer to the letter from the Secretary of your Committee dated 30 April 1986 enclosing the extract from the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 6 of 1986 concerning the Futures Industry Bill 1986.

The issues the Committee has raised warrant careful consideration. Accordingly, I have set out my response below in relation to each of the specific matters together with several general introductory comments about the Futures Industry Bill and the particular considerations we have to take into account in relation to legislation falling within the co-operative companies and securities scheme.
General introductory comments

The futures industry in Australia strongly supports the Bill and has called for its enactment as soon as possible in the public interest. In its submission on the Bill the Sydney Futures Exchange stated:

`The Exchange strongly supports the implementation of the Bill at an early date and would not wish enactment of the Bill to be delayed. The exchange believes that is is important that the industry is, and is seen to be, appropriately regulated, and the Exchange is ready to perform its own role in the co-regulatory process'.

Experience with the administration of the N.S.W. Futures Markets Act, the manner in which some members of the Sydney Futures Exchange have promoted and conducted their business, and the failure of some futures brokers, have indicated the need for Australia-wide legislation in this area.

An important aspect of the prudential controls in the Bill, is to ensure, in the public interest, the full investigation of matters peculiarly within the knowledge of one party. To this extent, the Bill corresponds with the Securities Industry Act 1980. Many of its provisions derive, of course, from that piece of legislation.

To enable the National Companies and Securities Commission (`NCSC') properly to discharge its functions under the proposed legislation, and to ensure public confidence in the securities and futures markets, it is essential that the NCSC has adequate powers of investigation.

Uniformity in the State and Territory law and administration relating to companies and the securities and futures industries is a major goal of the co-operative companies and securities scheme. The goal of uniformity is expressly referred to in Preamble (A) to the Formal Agreement between the Commonwealth and the States establishing the co-operative scheme.

Most of the provisions in the Bill that your Committee has drawn to the attention of Senators are based on the corresponding provisions in the Companies Act 1981 and the Securities Industry Act 1980. To amend any of the provisions in the Bill would require the unanimous agreement of all the parties to the co-operative scheme. Not only would any attempt to amend the Bill result in serious delay in its enactment, I am also not confident that all the States and the Northern Territory would agree to the amendments, particularly as it would be undesirable to have disuniformity between corresponding provisions in the companies, securities industry and futures industry legislation.
Sub-clauses 13 (3) and (4)
The NCSC power to require the production of various books relating to the futures industry under clause 13, is based on section 8 of the Securities Industry Act.

It is not considered that sub-clauses 13 (3) and (4) trespass unduly on personal rights and duties: although it is not specifically stated in these sub-clauses that the requirement to produce must be reasonable, it would appear to be an implicit requirement.
Sub-clauses 13 (3) and (4) should be read, moreover, in conjunction with clause 15 of the Bill.

This requires compliance with a request made under sub-clauses 13 (3) or (4) unless with `reasonable excuse'. There would be little doubt that `reasonable excuse' would include `an unreasonable requirement to produce'.

It follows that these sub-clauses do not restrict the court's power, when hearing a charge arising out of non-compliance, to take into account any alleged unreasonableness affecting the legality of the requirement.
Sub-clauses 15 (3), 18 (10)

The Committee claims that the legal onus of proof has been shifted in these sub-clauses, contrary to the recommendations made by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its Report, The Burden of Proof in Criminal Proceedings (Parliamentary Paper No. 319/1982).

The approach adopted in these provisions is derived from similar provisions contained in the Securities Industry Act 1980: it is an approach attributable to and justified by the complex nature of the industry which it is sought to regulate. There are dangers in comparing provisions of this proposed legislation with clauses contained in Bills as diverse as the Veterans' Entitlements and Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Bills.

More specifically, the element of intent or lack thereof in both these sub-clauses is more appropriately established by the person from whom production of documents is sought. The production of books and other documents and the provisions of information about their compilation is a vital aspect to the enforcement of the prudential controls under the legislation. This could be placed in jeopardy if too great a burden were to be placed on the prosecution.
Sub-clauses 15 (6) and 18 (5) and (6)

These sub-clauses provide that questions must be answered notwithstanding the fact that they may tend to incriminate. It is further provided, however, that where, prior to answering the question, the person claims that the answer might tend to incriminate, then the answer is only admissible in proceedings under the relevant clause. Similar provisions exist in the Securities Industry Act 1980.

The Committee claims that the effect of the provisions is to trespass unduly on personal rights and duties: it compares the approach with that adopted in sub-clause 25 (2). There, formal notice must be given of the above.

The distinction may be attributable to the fact that the exercise of the powers of the Commission and its agents is less formal under Division 1 than under Division 2: action under Division 1 is initiated by the NCSC whereas Ministerial involvement is required under Division 2. Clauses 15 and 18 are concerned with comparatively limited and clearly defined areas. The implications of investigations under clause 25 are far-reaching and arise from considerations of public or national interest. Experience with similar provisions in State companies and securities legislation suggests that special investigations are likely to result from recommendations arising out of investigating under the general powers of discovery contained in Division I.

Although sub-clauses 15 (6) and 18 (5) and (6) abrogate the privilege against self-incrimination in so far as it might be available to avoid making a statement concerning books seized or information disclosed, they provide a safeguard against indiscriminate use of any incriminating statement or disclosure against the person making or providing it. Where a person claims that making a statement might tend to incriminate the person, the statement is not admissible as evidence in criminal proceedings other than in proceedings in respect of false or misleading information given by the person.
Sub-clauses 25 (6) and (7)
The Committee claims that neither of these provisions contains the usual requirement that the defendant know that the information furnished to an inspector upon examination, is false or misleading.
Sub-clauses 25 (6) and (7) should be examined in the context of Division II as a whole.

Clause 22 clearly indicates that investigations are matters of some gravity: sub-clauses (1) and (2) refer to ``public'' and ``national'' interest respectively. The Bill clearly anticipates that Division 2 proceedings will be quasi-judicial in nature: clause 26 provides that investigations will be deemed proceedings for the purpose of the application of the laws of evidence, and under clause 27, a record of examination may be made.

Investigations are confined, by clause 23, to the matters specified in the instrument directing that they be held. Further, the persons required to assist with an investigation belong to a limited class: the persons considered to be in the best position to furnish the information required.
Having regard to the above, it is not considered that the obligation cast on a prescribed person under these two sub-clauses is inappropriate.

Furthermore, the construction of the clause may not support the strict liability interpretation cast upon it by the Committee. In both sub-clauses, the word `furnish', suggests an active participation by a prescribed person: the word `purports', used in sub-clause 25 (6) suggests an element of pretence or deception in the context of criminal proceedings, and section 36 of the Crimes Act 1914, applicable by virtue of sub-clause 25 (3), supports the inclusion of an element of `intent' or responsibility.
These clauses are couched in language similar to sub-section 19 (5) of the Securities Industry Act 1980.
Sub-clause 25 (10)
The Committee claims that by removing the privilege against self-discrimination, this clause trespasses unduly on personal rights and liberties.

The rights of the individual must be weighed, however, against those of the public at large: if material is not disclosed because it may be incriminating, an investigator will not be in possession of all relevant information. It would be undesirable if attempts to regulate the futures industry were endangered by claims of privilege against self-incrimination.

The area in which privilege is abrogated is clearly defined: it does not affect the claiming of privilege in any other area. Furthermore, as mentioned by the Committee, sub-clause 25 (2) ensures that sub-clause (10) is drawn to the attention of potential examinees. Sub-clause (10) ensures that any evidence given to an inspector which is claimed to be self-incriminating will be confined in its consequences to proceedings under clause 25.
Sub-clause 129 (10)
Comments made by the Committee here are similar to those made in relation to clauses 15 (3) and 18 (10).

The prosecution must prove all elements of the insider trading offence to secure a prosecution, including the fact that the defendant had possession of price sensitive information that is not generally available. It would be too difficult in the context of futures trading if the prosecution had to go further and prove that the other party to the dealing did not know about the information before entering into the dealing. Insider trading offences are notoriously difficult to prove-in fact in Australia there have been very few successful prosecutions to date under the corresponding provisions of the Securities Industry Act 1980.
Sub-clause 133 (2)

Paragraph 133 (1) (d), to which this sub-clause refers, involves the recording or storing of information that the person knows to be misleading in a material particular, that results in inducing or attempting to induce a person to deal in a futures contract or class thereof. The provision is couched in similar terms to section 126 of the Securities Industry Act 1980.

The defence to an offence under paragraph 133 (1) (d) rests on establishing that at the time when the defendant recorded or stored information, he or she had no reasonable grounds for expecting that the information would be available to anyone.

The offence therefore already contains an element of `intent' to be established by the prosecution; it would be unreasonable to impose upon the prosecution the further obligation to establish that the person charged ought to have had reasonable grounds for expecting that the information would be available to any person. That person is clearly in the best position to establish whether or not this was so.
Sub-clauses 144 (2) and 145 (2)

Clause 144 deals with the concealing, destruction, mutilation or alteration of books relating to futures contracts, and clause 145 with the falsification of records. The defences to both offences necessarily involve an examination of the intention of the perpetrator of such actions: again, it is considered that that person is clearly the best person to explain his or her actions.
Sub-clause 157 (7)

The Committee claims that sub-clause 157 (7) would abrogate the customary right of a defendant against whom an injunction is granted to seek an undertaking from the plaintiff as to damages in respect of any loss flowing from the granting of an interim injunction. The sub-clause is similar to section 149 of the Securities Industry Act 1980.
In fact, in cases involving the Crown or its representatives the granting of damages remains discretionary at common law: it is not an absolute privilege.

Actions taken under this proposed legislation have no counterpart in ordinary litigation between subject and subject: here, breach of the law is harmful to the public at large, or at least, to a component thereof. The NCSC moreover, is not seeking to promote its own schemes, but to properly discharge its responsibilities under the legislation.
Yours sincerely
LIONEL BOWEN
Senator M.C. Tate
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee for the
Scrutiny of Bills
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —The final matters I seek to deal with are the concerns expressed by the Australian Merchant Bankers Association to which Senator Puplick referred which went to the limitations in this legislation on the way in which surplus funds in clients' segregated accounts may be invested. The scheme of the Bill is to enable surplus funds in such segregated accounts to be invested with entities similar to those in which a liquidator may invest surplus funds under section 426 of the Companies Act rather than the full array of investment avenues available under the present regime of the Sydney Futures Exchange. Some concessions have been made to open up the pool of investable funds by enabling investment in cash management trusts and clearing houses. That is in the nature of a compromise.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for those two categories of investment opportunity being made available are simply that, in the case of cash management trusts, they themselves are subject to regulatory regimes of the Companies Act and the Securities Industry Act. Prospectuses are issued and approved and all the rest of it, so we have the kind of notional equivalent of a gilt-edged trustee investment security operating, so it is argued there. So far as the clearing houses are concerned, a particular clearing house that does operate for the Sydney Futures Exchange and the futures operation of the Melbourne Stock Exchange is International Commodities Clearing House Ltd which itself is owned and controlled by a consortium of six of the major British clearing banks and as such is thought to be a sufficiently rock solid investment opportunity to justify its being treated in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I detect a note of cynicism and mirth on the other side, but I do not want to start a run on any particular institution so I will not endorse that. The difficulty is that our merchant banks are not subject to the same sorts of regulatory requirements, and while some would no doubt satisfy any conceivable regulatory regime there may be others in respect of which it would not be thought so appropriate to have them as available fund sources.

SPEECH.PARA: So the argument goes that as the moneys in the client segregated accounts are similar to trust funds, it is desirable to limit the range of investments. The additions of the clearing house and cash management trusts are reasoned extensions of that principle. It must also be said that several of the major merchant banks operate cash management trusts, so they are not completely excluded from the range of investments. In any event, although the rationale I have outlined appears to me, anyway, to be reasonable, I will seek to ensure that the representations made by the Australian Merchant Bankers Association and endorsed here today by Senator Puplick are considered at the next ministerial council meeting, and I will advise the Attorney-General accordingly. If that ministerial council agrees with AMBA's submission, an amendment can of course be made to futures industry legislation at an early opportunity. I suggest that is an appropriate way of dealing with any lingering concerns that honourable senators may have on the matter. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 March, on motion by Senator Ryan:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill. I am particularly pleased that the Bill corrects a deficiency in the original Act to enable the Director of Public Prosecutions to engage persons on contractual arrangements and not under ordinary Public Service conditions. That was an omission from the original Bill passed by this Parliament nearly three years ago. I am only sorry it has taken the Government so long to correct it, because I think one of the main purposes of the appointment of the Director of Public Prosecutions was to have him in a position to obtain the best staff possible, and clearly the opportunity of being able to engage people on short term contracts for the experience and prestige gained from working in this office is important.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage I would normally sit down and assist the Bill's speedy passage, but the Opposition is very concerned about one matter in relation to the Director's office and his person which has occurred in recent months. I refer to the sustained assaults on the position of the Director, Mr Temby, which has occurred since December last year when he announced, perhaps not with the support but at least with the approval of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), that it was the Director's decision and not the Attorney's decision to prosecute the Premier of New South Wales for contempt arising out of some remarks he made following the announcement of a new trial for Mr Justice Murphy. Mr Wran immediately commenced a sustained campaign, over a period of more than a week in December last year, of attack on Mr Temby, questioning his motives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether it may not be the case that, no doubt unwittingly, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is himself trespassing on what is forbidden on a reading of the sub judice rule in relating to the Senate matters which apparently are the subject of contempt proceedings against Mr Wran.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy President: I am not about to canvass the issue of the trial; namely, whether or not Mr Wran has been guilty of contempt. I would not dream of doing that. I propose to develop my concern about the way in which Mr Temby was attacked, and I was about to move from Mr Wran, who mounted the attack, to members of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales.

—Order! Senator Durack. There is no point of order at the moment. The rule in this chamber is that the sub judice rule applies if remarks would tend to limit the effectiveness of a fair trial. I ask you to bear in mind that Mr Wran may possibly be subject to future trial.

—I thank you; I am aware of that. I do not propose to dwell on the matter of Mr Wran but I have to refer to it because it was Mr Wran who initiated this series of attacks on Mr Temby over a period of more than a week in December last year. As I have said he was joined in a series of attacks on Mr Temby's integrity, methods and the way he was operating by the administrative committee of the New South Wales Labor Party and a group of officials from nine unions including, I regret to say, the Australian Workers Union. During the period from 12 December last year until 23 December last year the Attorney-General allowed the series of attacks to go on. He did not lift a finger or utter a word in support of Mr Temby. The allegations of political motives are quite remarkable in view of the fact that Mr Temby, who was appointed to his present position when he was holding the office of President of the Law Council of Australia, had on one occasion been a candidate for the Labor Party. The allegations of political motives by Mr Temby in this matter are quite outrageous.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Opposition moved this amendment in the House of Representatives when this Bill was there, it does not seek to continue its concern in this chamber, particularly not at this stage of the session. However, I am deeply concerned by the fact that the New South Wales Labor Party has returned an attack as recently as last weekend during its State Conference. It has again called for the resignation of Mr Temby and it is proposing to persist with this campaign at the National Conference of the ALP in a few weeks. In those circumstances Mr Bowen failed, until absolutely shamed into doing so by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)-as I have said it took Mr Bowen 11 days-to come to the defence of Mr Temby and it is necessary that he again comes to Mr Temby's defence, probably at the National Conference of the ALP. For those reasons, I move:

At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate expresses its deep concern at the Government's failure to support and defend the independence and the integrity of the office of Director of Public Prosecutions against political and public attacks against the Director calculated to bring the Director, the office he holds and the administration of justice into disrepute''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1986 which is largely of a machinery nature in terms of a range of items. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendment just moved by Senator Durack on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Durack and Senator Macklin for their support for the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1986. I am not at all indebted to them for their support for this squalid little motion which they seek to append to the Bill. I do not think it is appropriate, not least for the reasons indicated by Senator Tate that the essential subject matter of this argument will be before the courts very soon. I do not think it is appropriate for me to dignify this further little attempt to beat a drum with any kind of detailed reply.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the case that the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, has expressed his confidence in Mr Temby as Director of Public Prosecutions. It is also the case that Mr Temby is something of a public figure not least because of the very active role he has played, in a number of different senses, in the administration of criminal justice since I appointed him 2 1/2 years ago. He takes these things robustly. I do not think anyone attributes to what has occurred the same kind of sordid connotations that Senator Durack and his cohorts are all too inclined to place upon them. It is simply part of the rough and tumble of public life. I think the institutional pressures that operate on everyone in this area are well understood. I think that is where the matter ought to be allowed to rest not least because, as I have said, to the extent that potentially serious matters are involved they will be the subject of full scrutiny in a forthcoming criminal court. That should not in any way be second guessed, pre-empted or anticipated by debate in this place. There is no question of the Government accepting, without demur, this amendment. We will, of course, oppose it. We are disappointed that the Australian Democrats should feel inclined, as part of their swan song in this place, to lend their names to such an ill-conceived and ill-justified motion.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Durack's amendment) be added.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND GRANT (JERVIS BAY TERRITORY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of the Bill is to provide for the grant of inalienable freehold title to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community over an area of some 403 hectares in Jervis Bay Territory.

The Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community is an established community comprising mainly descendants of the Jervis Bay and other tribes who once inhabited the general area. The land concerned at one time was gazetted as an Aboriginal reserve and administered by arrangement with the New South Wales Aborigines Protection Board. The land has always been regarded as a distinct Aboriginal area separate from other land in Jervis Bay Territory.

Negotiations for land tenure, by way of a perpetual lease, commenced in 1973 and proceeded for about 10 years without resolution. During this period of negotiation a number of Ministers under previous Liberal Governments with responsibility for administration of Jervis Bay Territory gave support to the proposed tenure arrangements at Wreck Bay. Those Ministers included Senator Withers, the late Hon. Eric Robinson, the Hon. Tony Staley, the Hon. Bob Ellicott and the Hon. Michael Hodgman and I am sure on that basis that this Bill will have the support of the Opposition.

This Government began negotiations with the community almost as soon as it assumed office in 1983, and in 1984 offered a land package, including a grant of inalienable freehold title to an area of approximately 403 hectares, to the Aboriginal residents of the Wreck Bay community. During this time there has been ongoing consultation with the community in relation to the land to be granted and the arrangements to apply after that date.

It is appropriate in this case that, as the land concerned is under the direct control of the Commonwealth, the Government is able to give effect to its policy of providing secure tenure to land in respect of Australia's indigenous population.
Scheme of the Legislation

Under the arrangements proposed, title to the land will be vested in the Wreck Bay Community Council under a trust arrangement. The functions, powers and administrative arrangements in respect of the Council are detailed in the Bill. No sale or mortgage of any part of the land will be permitted. However, the Council will be empowered to issue leases of land to members of the community for residential purposes and other leases to persons wishing to obtain an interest in the land for commercial purposes subject to the approval of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
Public roads through the grant area will be excluded and members of the public will continue to have access to facilities in the Summercloud Bay area which they currently enjoy.

Because of the importance of some places of special significance from an Aboriginal point of view in the area of the grant the Bill makes provision for those places to be protected. In addition, the Bill provides for the grant of title to further land adjoining the grant area if justified to the satisfaction of the Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs and Territories.
Financial Impact

New or additional costs to the Commonwealth in providing title to land to the Wreck Bay Community will be minimal. Annual costs associated with the administration of the Council will be met by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Commonwealth assets on the land, including houses, will vest in the Council.
Conclusion
This Bill secures the land to be granted for present and future generations of Aboriginal people at Wreck Bay.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum for the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Bill 1986.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Public Service: Permanent Part Time Work

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, upon notice, on 7 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the various media reports of Monday 5 May 1986, including one in the Sydney Morning Herald headlined: ``Part-time work soon to be official in PS'' (Public Service) which indicates the Federal Government is on the verge of introducing permanent part-time work, initially for up to 3 per cent of its 250,000 member workforce, have any substance.
(2) What is the rationale behind any such consideration.

(3) What is the level of demand for such working conditions from (a) the trade union movement; (b) the Commonwealth Public Service Board; (c) male employees of the Australian Government; and (d) female employees of the Australian Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honour- able senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. On 6 May 1986 the Australian Government Employment Permanent Part Time Work (ACOA) Award was made by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission enabling those categories of staff employed under the Public Service Act who are covered by the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association (ACOA) access to permanent part time work in the Australian Public Service. Approximately 66,000 staff are covered by this award. However, the Government has agreed with the ACOA that, initially, the number of part time officers shall not exceed a limit of 3% of the total number of full time officers in ACOA's area of coverage throughout the Australian Public Service. A permanent part-time work award for members of the Professional Officers' Association (POA) was made on 26 May 1986. No formal limits apply to the POA award. An award is expected to be made shortly for members of the Federated Clerks' Union in the Australian Taxation Office.

(2) In its December 1983 policy paper ``Reforming the Australian Public Service'' the Government announced that, associated with its policies on equal employment opportunity, permanent part time employment would be introduced into the Australian Public Service. Permanent part time work will allow greater flexibility in staff utilisation and broaden the market for recruits. It will also make it possible for the Government to retain the skills, expertise and experience of staff who for personal or family reasons do not wish to work on a full time basis.
(3) It is difficult at this stage to assess the precise level of demand for these working conditions.

(a) Some areas of the trade union movement support the introduction of part time work. Unions with which agreement on part time work arrangements has been reached or is expected to be reached shortly are referred to in part (1) of this reply.
(b) The Commonwealth Public Service Board strongly supports the introduction of permanent part time work.

(c) and (d) Representations made to me, the Public Service Board and departmental managements suggest that there is strong interest in the introduction of permanent part time work from both male and female officers.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 May 1986 (Hansard, page 2871), Senator Archer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Science, a question without notice about a report of the Industrial Property Advisory Committee and about delays experienced and fees payable in processing patent and trade marks applications. The Minister for Science has provided the following information in response to the honour- able senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The report of the Industrial Property Advisory Committee (IPAC) was released for public comment in November 1984. The report, which makes 46 recommendations and took nearly five years to complete, followed a very wide-ranging and detailed study of the Australian patent system.

Written submissions on the substance of the report were invited from interested groups. Forty-five submissions were received in the period to August 1985, a number having been the subject of prior informal discussion with the Patent Office. The Patent Office then undertook the preparatory work necessary for formal interdepartmental consideration, which commenced in March 1986.
It is expected that a draft response to the report will be available for consideration by the Government shortly.

The current delay for processing trade mark applications is 2 years. This is largely due to the cumulative effect of previous restrictions on staff resources, compounded by a large increase in the lodgment rate of applications since 1979 when registration of trade marks for services was introduced. This situation is not satisfactory for users or the Government and in consequence the Government, in 1983, instituted a 3-year program for upgrading operations through computerisation and, in 1985, approved the recruitment of additional staff so that delays would not increase after the new staff and computer-based systems became fully effective.

In the case of patents, the Patents Act provides a system of deferred examination in which an application is not examined unless and until an applicant so requests. The Commissioner of Patents may, however, direct an applicant to request examination and, in practice, about 85% of applicants wait for such a direction to be issued. Directions are issued at present about 23 months after an application is completed. The average total of the time then taken for applicants to request examination and for a first report to be issued by an examiner is about a further 9 months.

An applicant can, however, request examination at any time after the application is completed, without waiting for a direction from the Commissioner. An applicant can also request, in certain circumstances, that examination be expedited in order to have set aside the requirement that applications be examined as far as practicable in order of request. In practice, about 15% of applicants voluntarily request examination and less than 1% request expedited examination.

In order to reduce waiting times by 1991 to 6 months in the case of trade marks and 18 months in the case of patents, the Patent and Trade Marks Offices have formulated a 5-year plan, the implementation of which is, of course, subject to normal budgetary consideration each year.

It is not possible to provide an accurate and meaningful comparison between the costs of obtaining a patent in various countries because of the differences which exist between countries in the numbers and types of fees levied at different stages between application for and grant of a patent. However, assuming that the simplest course is followed, that no additional charges are incurred, and that grant follows application in average time in each country, the latest information available in the Patent Office on the approximate costs of obtaining a patent is:

It is Government policy that the Patent Office operate in such a way that the fees it collects will cover at least its operating expenses and overheads such as notional superannuation and rent. This requirement sets the overall parameters for patent fees and, unlike in a number of other countries, involves no Government subsidy for the Office's operation.

Nevertheless, official fees payable in order to obtain patent protection in Australia are unlikely in most cases to be significant in comparison with overall costs (including those for research and development, market research, marketing, manufacture, and distribution) of bringing a new product or process on to the market.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 10 September 1985:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth's responsibilities in relation to airline schedules are primarily concerned with safety and operational matters relating to air navigation. The design of schedules to meet travellers' needs and the utilisation of aircraft fleets are matters for the airlines' commercial judgments.

In approving the airlines' proposed schedules under the Air Navigation Regulations, my Department examines such operational/safety related matters as the availability of air traffic control, flight service facilities and apron parking. In addition, my Department responds to proposed variations to specific flights in terms of its responsibilities for safety through established arrangements and procedures for the submission of flight plans and air traffic control.

The extent to which airlines amend scheduled departure times and the incidence of delays in aircraft departures are primarily matters for the airlines, which also have responsibility for any necessary corrective action.
