ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: France: Naval Base in South Pacific

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Australian Government have any indication of any plans by the French Government to set up a base which is capable of accommodating nuclear submarines in the South Pacific and particularly New Caledonia; if so, what is the Australian Government's response to this proposal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Following the then French Defence Minister Charles Hernu's visit to New Caledonia in May 1985, the French Government announced plans to improve the naval facilities in New Caledonia. The proposals include lengthening of the existing quay and the establishment of alongside facilities suitable for submarines at the Noumea Naval Base.
As far as the Government is aware, no construction work has yet been undertaken.
However, as was demonstrated by the 1985 visit by the French submarine RUBIS, arrangements can be made to accommodate visits by nuclear-powered submarines at the existing base.

The Australian Government would like to see the South Pacific region remain free of external military confrontation and rivalry. Moreover, it could not but oppose any measures which might have the effect of assisting or reinforcing the French nuclear testing program in the South Pacific.

However, while Australia has signed the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty and is actively encouraging all major nuclear weapons states, including France, to sign the Protocols to the Treaty, the Government recognises that the Treaty does not prevent the passage through the region of any ships or aircraft of any nation. Further, the Treaty allows for each signatory to the treaty to determine its own policy on ship and aircraft visits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Materials Research Laboratory at Maribyrnong taken delivery of a high voltage pulse generator during 1985 or 1986; if so, what is the name of the manufacturer of the generator, and what are its principles of operations, and technical specifications.
(2) Is the pulse generator intended for use in research on the Electro-Magnetic Railgun; if so, in what aspect of that research will it be used; if not, what is the intended use.
(3) Does the research to be conducted with the pulse generator have application to research and development of space-based weapons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the Materials Research Laboratories took delivery of a high voltage pulse generator during February 1986. The manufacturer is Pulsar Products, USA. It operates on the basis of a high voltage direct current source feeding a capacitor. A spark gap switch enables the capacitor-stored energy to be discharged through an external load. The model FRP-50 procured has the following technical specifications:
peak output voltage: 50,000 volts
source capacitor: 20 nano-farads
peak stored energy: 25 joules
pulse shape: double exponential
pulse rise time: less than and up to 10 nanoseconds
repitition rate: single shot to one shot per 10 seconds

(2) The pulse generator is not intended for use on rail gun research. Its intended use is to support experimental work on the protection of electronic and/or communications equipment from damaging electric or magnetic fields.
(3) No, my Department is not involved in research and development of space-based weapons.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Northern Territory Pastoral Properties: Aboriginal Communities

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs upon notice, on 30 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it expected that the allocation provided under Additional Estimates for the provision of services to Aboriginal groups who have obtained suitable tenure of community living areas on Northern Territory pastoral properties will be sufficient to meet the demand for provision of these services.
(2) How many applications have been received to date for excisions of land from Northern Territory pastoral properties.
(3) How many of these claims have been successful.
(4) How many of these claims have been unsuccessful.
(5) Have any claims been varied; if so how many and in what respect.
(6) How many claims are presently being processed.
(7) What is the average time taken for the processing of claims.
(8) Have there been any delays in processing claims; if so, for what reasons.
(9) Has the scheme been successfully operated on a voluntary basis between pastoralists, Government and Aboriginals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: Question 1: In the financial year 1985/86, yes.

Questions 2-9: The Northern Territory Government has stated that at 30 April 1986 there have been 95 expressions of interest in this area and 57 of these are being processed. I am informed that 27 formal agreements are in place between communities and pastoralists.

The Northern Territory Department of Lands has the primary responsibility for the administration of excisions in respect of pastoral leases and applications for living areas are being processed by that Department under Territory guidelines. It is true that there have been long delays in the processing of agreements but those delays are not necessarily confined to any one party involved to a predominant degree.

My Department does not maintain complete particulars of all expressions of interests in respect of the investigatory and processing action taken. That information is maintained by the Northern Territory Department of Lands. One title in respect of land excised from a pastoral lease has been registered to date and it is understood that other titles will be registered in the near future.

A Committee of Review has been established to resolve difficulties and reduce delays in respect of applications for living areas. The Committee provides for representation of the Northern Territory Department of Lands, the Cattlemen's Association, the Land Councils and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
To date there has been a good deal of cooperation displayed between pastoralists, Aboriginals and government agencies involved in the scheme.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 30 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs satisfied that the Northern Territory Trachoma Control and Eye Health Committee, the majority of which comprises Aboriginal people, is efficient and effectively carrying out programs to deal with trachoma in Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory?

(2) Does the National Aboriginal Health Organisation plan to seek funds to carry out similar trachoma control and eradication programs; if so, does the Minister believe that such duplication is necessary, in view of the way in which the present scheme is operating?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) On 8 May 1986, I discussed the future arrangements for the delivery of trachoma and eye health curative and preventive services to Aborigines with Professor Fred Hollows, representatives of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO), and the Northern Territory and State Trachoma Eye Health Committees. This meeting was the last of a number of detailed discussions concerning the recommendations of the Trachoma and Eye Health Report produced by a committee comprised of NAIHO, my Department, the Commonwealth Department of Health and Professor Fred Hollows.

The meeting recommended continuation of the attack on trachoma with a greater emphasis on the involvement of Aboriginals and Aboriginal Medical Services as well as the continued funding of existing services that are delivering effective programs. The Government endorses this approach.
I have therefore decided not to accept the Report's recommendations concerning a national trachoma secretariat and a national program funded through NAIHO.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are negotiations being conducted between the Northern Land Council, the Aboriginal traditional owners and mining companies to allow exploration and mining of new uranium deposits on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory.

(2) If the Aboriginals and mining companies reach an agreement that complies with all the requirements of the Northern Territory Land Rights Act, will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs approve these agreements.

(3) Has the Central Land Council made a decision to transport 60 Aboriginal people from central Australia to the Ranger uranium mine to ascertain the effect of uranium mining before considering negotiations with mining companies for new uranium mines in central Australia.

(4) Does the Government have any intention of allowing further exploration and development of uranium in light of the considerable expenses being incurred by the Northern and Central Land Councils in their quests to negotiate exploration and development of new uranium mines; if not, will the Government recompense these land councils the money they will have outlaid.
(5) If the Government has no intention of allowing further development of the uranium mining industry, does the Minister agree that the Aboriginal people involved are being led up the garden path.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(4) The Australian Government has no objection to further exploration for uranium taking place in the Northern Territory. However, miners are aware as to what the Government's policy is in relation to the development of new uranium mines and accordingly, investment decisions by miners would no doubt be made having regard to that policy. Similarly, Land Councils enter into negotiations with miners on the same basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 28 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the National Capital Development Commission have plans to include a ``Water Park'' in the plans for the Tuggeranong Town Centre.
(2) Are plans for the park available for public view; if not, when will they become available.
(3) What is the time frame for the construction of the park.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Capital Development Commission's plans for Tuggeranong Town Centre include the opportunity for a range of recreation facilities including a ``Water Theme Park'' or swimming complex. As government funding appears unlikely the Commission is proceeding on the basis that any such facility would be developed by private enterprise. The size of any such facility could vary from 0.5 ha. (traditional swimming pool) to 4.0 ha. (Water Theme Park), and its viability may need to be supported by other recreational facilities (eg. skating rink, squash courts, bowling alley etc.); the Commission has therefore asked the Department of Territories to call for Registration of Interest so that the type and size of any site release can be accurately gauged. The Department intends to advertise for Registration of Interest in the near future.

(2) Pending the submissions received in response to the call for expressions of interest, the Commission has no detailed plans available of a Water Park or swimming pool. The Policy Plan, Development Plan and other supporting material for Tuggeranong Town Centre are however available for public view.

(3) Possible sites for the Water Theme Park and swimming complex are in an area for which access will be provided by the Stage 2 roadworks for Tuggeranong Town Centre. The Commission will be seeking funds for these roadworkds as part of the 1986/87 programme appropriation.

Normally sites cannot be released to private enterprise until site servicing is complete (say 1987/88) but in the case of a community facility such as a Water Park, if there is sufficient interest from the private sector for an early development, the Commission would investigate ways of allowing temporary access for construction purposes before permanent roadworks are completed.
The approximate cost of preparing this reponse was $143.00.
